Tomb Raider 2013 is a fantastic Survival-Horror game. Unfortunately, it's a disappointing 'TOMB RAIDER' game. Having entered this game straight from TR Anniversary Edition, I could not get past the stark contrast in challenge/difficulty scale (there is none in this title) and lack of specific character traits of the iconic Lara Croft.   PROS:  * Incredible graphics and scene-scapes throughout * Top-notch art direction  * Masterful music score that really amps up the immersion and tone of the survival-horror theme, the island setting, and the fast-paced, heart-pumping action sequences.  * Fast-paced, heart-pumping action sequences.  * Weapon handling and combat are very smooth for a third-person game; weapon sounds are realistic. *Combat is engaging (no pun intended). A variety of weaponry and gadgets holds your interest and makes you eager for the next battle.  * You get to play as Lara Croft.  CONS:   * You get to play as Lara Croft. But not the snarky, confident Lara Croft you know and love. You will get to play as the bookish, squeamish, humorless, weakling Lara Croft. I get that this is an origin story & Lara's first adventure. But NONE of Lara Croft's innate personality traits are evident here. Sure, a gruesome experience like this will change anyone, but it certainly wouldn't evoke a sarcastic, snarky sense of humor or driving lust to raid tombs later on. I never really felt like I was playing Lara Croft during this game except for the last two minutes of it when the developers suddenly tried to link in a few iconic elements and personality traits.  * This game is way too graphic in its violence - superfluously so. The intense violent nature of Lara's death scenes and her realistic expressions during them are disturbing & potentially nightmare-inducing. This is definitely not a title for the wee kiddos, which is a shame since the ultra-graphic violence doesn't really add anything to the game. This from a gamer who complains there isn't enough gore in zombie shooting titles...  * CHIEF COMPLAINT* There is no challenge to this game. I have been playing video games for 4 decades, & I never played a video game with such a ridiculous level of gratuitous hand-holding before. Pathways and climbing nodes are LITERALLY white-washed in obvious paint streaks and splatters (I'm not kidding). Still stuck? No worries! Press the Q button to activate SURVIVAL INSTINCTS which will turn your entire screen monochrome except for all crucial objects, climb points, & pathways which will be ILLUMINATED IN GLOWING GOLD. What's that? You still can't find all of the collectible objects and relics? No problem! Just earn a few hundred experience points & buy the two skills that reveal EVERYTHING on your (terrible) map! Really, folks. The only way this title could get any more dumbed-down is if your game purchase came with one of the developers who visits your house & plays the game for you while you watch from the comforts of your sofa. If you are expecting a mental challenge the likes of Tomb Raider Legend or Anniversary, your brain will be sorely disappointed & REALLY BORED.  * Tomb raiding is a sad affair. The only 'tombs' you will find here are shallow caves filled with litter & junk. And you -WILL- find them. Notably because there are GIANT WHITE ARROWS (visible from space) pointing you to the tomb entrance. Once you get closer to this elusive cave -- I mean 'tomb' -- entrance, you will REALLY know you found it when LOUD BELLS start ringing madly, like a five-alarm fire in a city made entirely of kindling and newspaper. Once inside the ca- TOMB, you will *REALLY* know you found it because Lara will automatically pull out a torch and walk very slowly to gasp and marvel at such incredible sights as skeletons, stalagmites, impossibly still-lit candles, & about 3000 years' worth of empty soda bottles. Each tomb involves a simple A-B puzzle (one time it was A-B-C!) to reach a giant chest filled with (SPOILERS!) ancient LP records and rolling pins. Lara will then gasp with wanton ecstasy at the contents & take ONE large disc (assumedly with a killer B side) & put it in her under-sized back pocket. Obviously, she can't carry ALL of the treasure, silly! She has a giant hole in her side after being impaled during the intro (a wound which she ignores most of the game during leaps, rolls, & melee combat but later on suddenly bothers her so much she can't climb a ledge two feet off the ground). Plus, she's carrying five fully-modified weapons. One 'tomb' actually had a dead person in it!  * The script is banal, amatuerish at best with only a smattering of inspiring dialogue between two specific characters. Lara's comments during private speech (thinking out loud) puts Captain Obvious to shame. 'Look! This statue of a goddess behind a hundred lit candles and random valuable objects must be a shrine used for worship.' Ya think?  * The plot follows suit & is completely predictable from very early on. Stereotypical characters abound & offer no surprises here. Angry black mechanic is angry. Shady opportunist is shady.  * The map is terrible. Incremental zoom is unforgivingly absent: zoomed in you will lose 70% of viewing ability to the insets & GIANT MAP LEGEND that you cannot resize, move, or deactivate. Zoomed out, item symbols & pathways will be too scrunched together to distinguish from each other since the entire map was made with only two colors. Have these developers never used MapQuest or Google Maps before?   * Very little to no replay value. Multiplayer is a ghost town. Dear Developers: STOP wasting valuable money & resources on an extraneous, unwanted multiplayer component that nobody will play, & INSTEAD spend it on a better script, more single-player content, or - I don't know - maybe inserting actual tombs with challenging puzzles to your Tomb Raider game. A fun, animal hunting mini-game experience with challenges, etc. could have easily been implemented at less cost.  * For all the lush, breath-taking landscapes, very little of it is explorable since pathing is mostly linear and tunneled (though cleverly veiled). Game length is extended only by adding optional recovery of collectables & search-and-destroy challenges within the same linear zones. The lack of freedom to explore such environments awoke my desire to jump back into Skyrim, actually.   * QuickTime Events. Dear developers: if you are going to port over a console game to PC, transform Quick Time events to SLOW Time events. That way, my blood pressure will not spike to unhealthy levels trying to match up three shrinking, concentric circles in 2 seconds at the top left of my screen while at the same time I am squinting at the bottom center of my screen trying to distinguish between a red E and an almost identical red F. At the very least, COLOR CODE the required keypress differently!   NITPICKS:   * I didn't like Lara's voice and found it unfitting the character. I found her voice actor unsuitable for this role, and her pitch and tone didn't match up to Lara Croft in my mind at all. * Lara is dying of hypothermia but is too snobbish to put on a puffy winter coat worn by a myriad of slain enemies. * The E button is used for too many different things. While spamming to pick up ammo, I frequently pulled out a lit torch becuase my ammo for that type was full.  * Some weapon modifications are absurd.  * Lara is squeamish and reluctant to kill anybody, but will find the most extravagant, elaborate ways to execute enemies in needlessly violent ways during her adventure. * An item crafted in the 1830 is not 'ancient'.   If Crystal Dynamics could combine this title with the mentally-rigorous puzzles of its predecessors and eliminate the insulting hand-holding, it could change the industry in profound ways with a new paragon of video gaming excellence.  ATTENTION: PC MASTER RACE! Stock up on RAM now. I've seen the FUTURE, and its name is TressFX!

This game is ridiculously good. And for 2.99 with the Winter Sale going on, there's no game that is a better bargain. Because of this game, I'd probably be prepared to pay full price for the Rise of the Tomb Raider in anticipation for what it will have to offer.   What's good about it:  Rich story with enough variety in gameplay to let you decide whether you want to be stealthy or just go all out guns blazing. There is a feeling of character development and progression and your character is not the same Tomb Raider she was when she first started. The graphics are on point, and the game excels in bringing you into the story, as if it is your story.   What's bad about it:  Because there is a story to follow, I understand why the game is linear. Everyone loves open world, but this is essentially the story of Lara Croft so it's expected that they do some funnelling towards a particular path. I believe multiplayer is probably where the game sort of falls off. I would have much rather had more to the core of the game and story than a PVP mode which just seems completely out of place.  In an industry dominated by male protagonists, I think Lara is badass and very refreshing. No superpowers, just raw skill and a great story. Not only does it fill a void in the industry, but it does it in great taste and quality.

I was expecting this reboot to be horrible considering how other reboot of this time an age are. But surprinsingly Tomb Raider is an amazing game which capture the essence of what made the first Tomb Raiders enjoyable. Solving puzzles and taking down bad guys of all source and variety. All this with great graphics and gameplay to boot. The biggest complaint i have is the wonky camera angle, but that was probably intented as it adds to the atmosphere of the yound laura croft struggling with her first adventure.

If you dont have this game and your thinking about buying it. Then the answer would be yes :) this game has a lot to offer even though the multiplayer aspect is dead and not very entertaining the single player campaign is very thrilling.  I would give it a 9/10 because the single player was very enjoyable and had a really good story and game interaction.

DEFINITELY BEST GAME of 2013. VERY BEST. Really great game (nice restart of the series ... now we must wait for another story to be told),  This game is a RESET of an TOMB RAIDER series. This game reveals how LARA CROFT become a real HARD CORE TOMB RAIDER.  This is FPS or better to say 3rd person shooter. This game adds a BOW that this series really need (big THX for the idea of makers).  First few minutes (maybe 30) is this game 'oriented like XBOX or PS3 style game' ... like 'monkey push the button' style ... but after few 'pushing' sequences ... game turns into hard core 3rd person action adventure mixed up with FPS and RPG essence. FPS 'feature' is best shown in 'let say' battle mode ... or in battle sequences (situations) ... Game is best to play at highest difficulty ... even at that difficulty is ... pretty 'easy'.  ... THERE IS NOTHING TO SAY ... JUST PLAY IT.  worth any money ... best in sale.  + reset of an series + Tomb Raider + an idea (born of Lara Croft a Tomb Raider) + RPG elements + DLCs + graphics + sounds + story + a bow (great add to the series ... this was something this game wants a long time)  - ? Without any exaggeration, this is one the best games I've ever played. I never played any of the Tomb Raider games before, but this one is fantastic.   Gameplay is smooth and fun.  The game has a cover + shoot mechanic in it that works flawlessly. When there are enemies nearby, Lara immediately changes her stance to a combat stance. She will walk more stealthfully and automatically take cover behind walls when you approach them. There is no 'cover' or crouch button you need to worry about. Just walk up to a wall and she will assume a defensive position. She will also lean out of cover to allow you to shoot an enemy while still maintaining cover, all automatically. You don't need to press Q or E for instance. All of this is brilliantly smooth and fits right into the gameplay perfectly.   The graphics are beautiful.  I play the game in the highest settings for everything without any lag / fps drop whatsoever. With these settings, the entire game looks amazing. The outside scenery, the dark caves, and don't get me started on Lara's hair. With TressFX enabled, Lara's hair is the greatest hair I've ever seen in a video game currently at the time of typing this. It has individual strands of hair that flow through the wind, brush from off her back over her shoulder and down to her side. Jumping, turning quickly, any movement and the hair reacts realistcally. FYI, the screenshots Steam provides does not have TressFX enabled. It is a very noticeable difference. I suggest googling it if you don't know what I'm talking about. But even if you can't maintain a smooth framerate with it enabled, the game is still beautiful to look at with it disabled as well.   Upgrades, weapons and collectibles.  The upgrade system for weapons is, simply put, fun. You start off with mediocre, poor quality equipment. You're then able to collect salvage in your adventure and use it to mod your weapons. As further time progresses, you'll be able to completely upgrade the weapons you have into their next tier. The game also includes several bits of collectibles, mostly for completionists sake. Such as relics that give some backround history on ancient Japan culture, or various puzzle related locations that grant rewards. The game also offers a fast travel option to go back to any point of the game you were previously at. So you don't need to worry about missing out on any collectibles. You gain XP for nearly everything you do in the game, and with this XP you game skill points. Using skill points allows you to gain additional abilities whether it be better survival skills, or stronger in combat, you choose the way you want to go about it.  Not only is the gameplay and graphics great, but the story is great too. It keeps you wanting to play more and more and figure out the mystery the island holds.   There are many other reasons I could list as to why I recommend this game, but it isn't necessary to go on.  TL;DR, one of the best games ever played. Flawless combat with fun upgrading / weapon mod system. Amazing graphics and interesting storyline. Lara's hair.

This 2013 reboot re-envisages an ancient franchise as a high drama action-adventure with heavy third-person shooting and light puzzles, rather than a 3D puzzle platformer wherein you must sometimes shoot a tiger. Perhaps you would call that merely a change in emphasis, but it feels very different. Tomb Raider is a good romp and technically impressive, but despite the hype around the new design, the misogyny and normalization of violence in the main character are still present, and there are notable mechanical and racial problems. The delights for me are the collectibles and animations.  The main character is the thing. Lara is now a vulnerable freshman explorer, tagging along with a more experienced crew, who gets into serious trouble. She has been redesigned with humanoid proportions, and a lot to learn. The game shows her getting hurt a lot. Much is made of her vulnerability, but even grievous wounds are quickly shaken off, and after an hour or so she is slaughtering men by the dozen. She soon becomes much the same hardened murderer as so many other game protagonists. Her in-game barks ('Run, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!', 'I'm coming for you!') evoke a bloodthirst at odds with the storyline of an innocent young woman doing her best at a time of crisis.  I found the original series hard to play because Lara was designed and exploited to titillate a certain demographic. The new Lara has an actual human body. She is still normatively pretty, and thin, with very large breasts. Some people look like this, but ultimately, games over-represent these bodies to pander to the male gaze of their perceived audience. I think the most generous thing I can say is that Lara is desexualized relative to her previous incarnation, but still recognizable. And there is another form of misogyny at play here too. A friend of mine put it that the player is encouraged to want to protect this young girl. There are a great many gruesome death animations for Lara, and the danger she is put in is frighteningly sexualized at the beginning of the game. The enemies are all men. In fact, there are only three female NPCs, and one of them has no lines. For me, this is only a partly successful reboot, and largely for these reasons.  Raiding tombs is now an optional side quest. Each tomb is a single room puzzle with a chest at the end. I enjoyed these deviations from the main narrative, but I was disappointed that the chests contain nondescript treasures. When Lara gasps and grabs one, we aren't shown what it is. I think this was a missed opportunity. Elsewhere in the game, there are dozens of 'relics': artifacts from centuries of Japanese history, modern tchotchkes, and mementos from World War 2. They are well-rendered, beautiful objects, and they inspire interest in real archaeology. Finding these relics and hearing Lara's commentary on each one was my favourite part of Tomb Raider. I wish the tombs had been integrated into that mechanic, but I recognize that the mechanics of a project on this scale are developed separately, in parallel. Unfortunately, when turning over relics, Lara serially mispronounces 'Edo': unbelievable for a professional academic working on location in Japan. But the relics help to illustrate what is best about this game: amazing production values. It just looks a treat. There are animations for every little thing. Even the way Lara flicks water from her forearm when drying off is perfect. The textures are lovely, even if they can be a little gamey. Whole buildings and setpieces are lovingly put together, and then only seen once, for a few seconds. In short, you can feel every cent of the one hundred million dollar budget spent on this game.  Platforming feels good. It's forgiving and intuitive. Lara's jump is quite floaty, but it doesn't feel silly. I generally felt like I had 'just made it' through action sequences, and only had to replay a couple of sections.  The gunplay is standard non-technical third person cover shooter fare. I thought it was fine, but I would rather have done less of it. You can upgrade weapons, but the process feels a bit distant and automatic. There are a lot of Quick-Time Events (QTEs; essentially abstractions during which you are prompted to press a button to simulate having Lara react quickly to a dramatic situation), but never for things which really matter. I lost track of the number of times I had to press X to catch a ledge during a cut-scene, just for the ledge to collapse, but I wasn't involved at all when Lara treated her own wounds, upgraded her weapons, cremated her mentor, or put herself in danger to save her best friend.  A lot of white men made this game, and it shows. At the end, we're shown photographs of the Crystal Dynamics crew. 90% of them, including the senior staff, are white and male. They clearly worked hard, and it's great to see people of colour in the main cast, but there's also a lot wrong. The game is set on an island off Japan, but the antagonist and protagonist (Matthias and Lara) are white. The only Japanese character who is actually alive is Japanese-American. Jonah, a Polynesian cook and sailor, is one of the few people Lara can rely on, but he is painted as a kind of 'mystical person of colour', with an unexplained sixth sense about the spiritual forces at work on the island. Reyes, the ship's mechanic, is another likeable ally, and one of the very few named black characters, but has been fleshed out with a predictable subplot about being a hardass single black mom with a missing baby-daddy.  About three quarters of the way through, there's a miniboss battle with a very large black man. The framing of that fight, with tiny, white Lara swearing at him, and brutalising his body, implicitly draws on centuries of racist caricature. There are no other boss encounters except at the very end, so the depiction really stands out.  The single-player campaign is about eleven hours long. Collecting all of the trinkets may take another six or seven hours. The multiplayer mode doesn't really interest me. It consists of fairly standard team-based shooter objectives on small maps.  Tomb Raider (2013) is no feminist reworking, but the criticisms of it as exploitative have been overstated. In this game, Lara is not sexually assaulted, so far as I can tell, although many seem to have drawn that conclusion. I cannot recommend this game to everyone, because not everyone has the time and energy for hours of shooting, and it is very bleak and violent at times. But if you want big action, and you want to see how pretty a game can look, you can do a lot worse. Just understand what it isn't.

'I hate tombs.' - Lara  14hrs of playing later  'I'm not going home.' - Lara  I guess you could say she...  (•_•)   ( •_•)>⌐■-■  ...buried her hatred of tombs (⌐■_■)  AWW YEAAA  11/10 would tomb again.

Before you read this, please note that I didn't finish the game yet. According to the load-page, I am about 30% through, and have been playing for four hours so far. I am not quite sure whether that means that the main story gives you about 12 - 13 hours of playtime, but that's my stat right now.   I have been playing several TR titles, starting with the very first one on the PS1, back in the 90s. It's obvious that things have progressed a lot, but even though the char and series have gone through a lotta changes, and even though this is kind of a rebooted prequel, there definitely IS some 'Lara-ness' to the main character in this game... and it's not only the voice-acting.  That's actually a nice segue, because the voice-acting especially for Lara is outstanding. It is well-acted, and very well brings over the pain, fear, loss, confusion and anger that Lara goes through during the story.  And there is a LOT of that. I don't think I ever have 'worried' so much about Lara, as she suffers a LOT in this game. She is not the smirking, cool and tough Lara we know from some of the other games, she is teenage Lara here, and the situation has her on the verge to plain panic most of the time.  This might annoy some people. In my case, it kinda kept me on the edge of my seat, because... I felt 'pinched'. You kinda feel for Lara and all the suffering, and you want her to survive.  This game is pretty hard-edge, not only because of all the pain she has to endure. There are some scenes which definitely are not fit for children (a certain tunnel in the secluded monastery being the prime example, with body parts everywhere).   The graphics are breathtaking, especially during one of the key-scenes of the game, where you have to climb a high building. That scene has one of the best examples of conveying the feeling of being high up in the air, climbing up carefully... quite fascinating.   Now, I have read several reviews saying that especially at first, there'd be a lot of 'cutscenes' and quicktime events. Now, I am 30% and 4 hours in, and I did not notice a change... there STILL are a lot of those scenes. Lara talking on the walkie talkie, plus sudden quicktime events where you have to follow the commands on the screen or dodge objects.  These can be VERY frustrating at first. A lot of times, good reaction isn't enough. You lose all orientation, and you have maybe a sec or two to find out what you're supposed to do while the floor around you breaks apart. While this might be pretty...realistic, it sometimes feels less than fair. There is one scene in particular, again at that monastery, where it took me several tries to even find out where I am to go and how, and I kept dieing a lot.   Same is true for the 'move at high speed and dodge objects that will instantly kill you' quicktime events. While some of them, I was able to survive on the first attempt, some of them have to be 'learned' (as in, memorize the order of obstacles or directions you have to move in), and that isn't always fun. Especially when a) the lighting is so bad you can only GUESS where the killing object is or b) Lara's body is in the way, obstructing your view, making it harder.  Those events are the least fun part for me, even though I guess they're realistic (if you were in a similar situation, you'd have to think quickly or even have to rely on luck to survive). I guess dieing is just something you need to get used to and accept in order to 'learn' those events.   The FPS part is pretty fun. You can improve and pick your weapons, so if sometimes, you feel like blasting away enemies with a shotgun instead of assassinating them with your bow, you can. However, in some cases, one of these methods is much more recommended. I found myself using all available weapons at a healthy balance, depending on the situation...sometimes being sneaky and acting like a sniper, sometimes going by brute force.   Controls are decent. The dodging-mechanics can be a bit off (hold shift while moving in a certain direction), but otherwise, I found them to be easy to understand and learn.   So, in a nutshell:   Pros: + Very nice graphics and cutscenes + Lara is a VERY likeable character, the character progression throughout the story is nicely done, graphics rock.  + Controls, apart from the dodging (YMMV!) are good + Soundtrack, voice acting + Scary atmosphere, and you might start to really care about Lara and the pain she suffers through + Fun weapon mechanics, and unless the game forces you to use a certain weapon, you can use different tactics  Cons - While the cutscenes sometimes are very dramatic and exiting, they can be frustrating unless you accept you will die several times while learning them - A LOT of cut scenes and quicktime events, to a point where sometimes, it feels like 'play for a minute, watch 2 minutes of cutscenes', or some interactice movie where you do a few things and then watch for a while what happens next  YMMV-category - A bit of gore and tough scenes, not safe for children. Depends on whether you like that or can tolerate it - I haven't tried all the difficulty modes, but ammo is never really a concern. You will find ammo and salvage (to modify weapons) pretty much everywhere. Even with the talents that increase the amount of ammo I can carry, I often had to leave behind stacks of ammo because I simply couldnt carry any more. This might bother some people, as a lot of times, you can just wildly shoot at enemies, not much need to save up on ammo.   Rating: I'd give this a solid 8/10. Sometimes it feels too much like an interactive movie, with too many events where you just watch. However, the game is a ton of fun, it's interesting to watch the story, watch Lara grow, try different tactics.  Less 'free' than some older TRs, but to me, a REALLY good addition to the franchise.

Excellent reboot with beautiful cut scenes and an engaging story. The gameplay is easy to latch onto and the environments are fun to explore. One thing to note is that the tombs in this game, which include a lot of puzzles, are optional. So keep that in mind. Meaning if you don't go out searching for tombs and just continue with the story then that's perfectly alright.  Personally I love having it be optional because I loved the old Tomb Raider games for their stories, the puzzles were fine too and I'm glad they're still included but I like that it doesn't affect your gameplay by a lot. I'd defeinitely recommend this for anyone looking for a game with lots of exploration, shoot 'em up, and treasure hunting.   One thing I loved the most about the game is how much story is hidden just everywhere. Tiny artifacts Lara examines and tells you the backstory of, journal entries read aloud via different voice actors, and idle dialogue between hostile npcs while you sneak up on them. There's just so much to know and explore in this game I definitely want more games like this with Lara and Sam. I get that by the ending Sam may not want to be an adventurer but that doesn't mean she couldn't help Lara in the following games with tech stuff or connections. Maybe aphone call or something? They seem so close I was almost certain they were more than friends. I'd love to see that more in the future games. Even if its just their friendship or a cameo photo or voice mail to Lara.
Nice game, very good graphics, nice story.
Great Game! Had such a blast playing it. Always looking forward to future games!

New Tomb Raider, new Lara.  From the old days of Tomb Raider with the Jolie saga, I was looking forward to a refresh of TR. Camilla Luddington is a good voice actor in this, and plays the new Lara well, as the nervous and unsure character that is unfamiliar to the series' setting. The story is also great, with the Yamantau environment providing a gritty feel to the game, and the shipwrecks are also kinda cool. You can also greatly upgrade your weapons throughout the game, which makes bad weapons like the bow good towards the end.  I only have two criticisms of TR: the collectables, and the multiplayer. I like collecting collectables in games (no matter how many), but the variation in location on TR is kinda annoying, as there is no indication of height of the object from ground level (as many things like shrines are on cliff faces) or any vague location as to where they are on the map. The other more prominent criticism is of multiplayer. I like whoring achievements, of which I have some left on TR to get. Unfortunately, I cannot get these, as TR is one of those games that lots of people play, but only single player. I have never had the opportunity to play MP as a result, which is a shame.  Overall, a great story and character, but wish that I had been a few years earlier with MP, or that it had at least lasted longer.  7/10

Tomb Raider is a reboot of the original classic. I remember when the first Tomb Raider came out, it was one of the first games to actually have a demo you could play before buying it. I enjoyed the original, but I always felt it was too puzzle heavy, not enough action. Back then the technology just wasn't there to create a game worthy of the vision. Now, with the new reboot, Tomb Raider has become what it was meant to be all along.  They've managed to expand on all of the various elements of the original without being too heavy handed in one area. Tomb Raider is all action. FPS is satisfying with plenty of depth. Action is insane with death defying stunts at heights you have to see to believe. Puzzles are frequent and make you think, as they should. Level design is so good that it makes a somewhat linear game feel like it's not. Graphic design elements successfully mask the linear nature of the game. The music immerses you in the action and is so good it sounds like it came from a blockbuster movie; huge props to the music team.  Raiding tombs is probably the weakest element. You find many unique items from different eras, but the sense of finding priceless treasure is lost as soon as you find out what it is and it gets stuffed in your pocket.  If you're afraid of heights, you may find this game hard to get through. Normally, games don't bother me, but Tomb Raider has you so high in the air you're on the edge of your seat when you jump onto a zip line or leap with blind faith that you'll be able to grab the ledge or bury your axe into the sheer rock face. The action will clean out your arteries nicely.  FPS gameplay can be difficult at times, especially in the tougher battles (and there are quite a few), but it's well-balanced and addictive. I especially enjoy the ability to switch hands and shoot around corners and obstacles from the left or the right. You can easily get your stealth fix by silently taking out enemies with arrows or up close and personal. It feels balanced for multiplayer (which I haven't tried), which shows they put a lot of thought into it.  I consider this game to be a masterpiece. So many people went above and beyond to make this game into something excellent. So many areas of the game could've been less than stellar had someone not gone the extra mile to make it the best they could. It really shows that the whole team cared a lot about the franchise.  Also keep in mind that this, the first game in the reboot, was meant to show how Lara came into her own as an adventurer, where it began. There are nods to the original and you get to see where she got the two pistols from, etc. It's done in a subtle way, so as to tie in the original and bring in the new direction at the same time.  Some people might look at this game and compare it to the nostalgia they have for the original and come up wanting in some areas, but this is a new direction for the franchise and I do think it's the right one as it does every element of what we would expect from the franchise so much better. It's an awesome game.  I can't wait to see what they do next with Tomb Raider. At the time of this writing, the second game is out. I'm definitely going to buy it. Shut up and take my money!

Confession: I have never enjoyed the Tomb Raider games. Shoddy gunplay and context-sensitive acrobatics made them feel like a waste of time. But this one? I'm more than a little bit smitten.   Sure, the 'story' is a bit weak and the 'characters' cheap cardboard cutouts, but the environments are astonishing, gunplay is satisfying and the combat is thrilling. Character- och item progression feels significant and makes exploration of this awesome-looking world doubly rewarding.   If you can ignore the misguided but not-too frequent Quick Time Events, this game has very few flaws. The most derivative sections are good, and the unique parts? Inspired. This is Lara's survival story, her growth from naive explorer into a fearless adventurer, and that arc is beautifully captured through gameplay. I can't imagine how you'd follow up on a story like this, but I really hope they try. I want more of this Lara Croft.

My favourite part of past Tomb Raider games was solving epic puzzles, and exploring for hidden treasures. So the series fan in me is a little disappointed that the reboot has shifted the focus more towards a standard third person shooter. There are some puzzles here, but they're much smaller in scale. Fortunately, the gamer in me was pleased with almost everything else. The combat is a drastic improvement on previous games, mainly because the player has to use their own skill to aim, rather than just locking on targets. The 10 hours long story is fantastic, and the voice acting is superb, providing cutscenes with appropriate emotional weight. I found most characters likeable, especially Lara and her more vulnerable personality. The QTEs can be annoying, especially when you sometimes only get about a second to hit the correct key before death. The controls work great with mouse & kb, graphics are stunning and other than the well publicised TressFX and Tesselation bugs, its very stable.

All around a good game. You play as a young Lara Croft, in the adventure that starts her tomb raiding career, fighting your way through an island controlled by a cult worshiping an ancient queen that could control the weather. Though the game does have some wonderful graphics, it can be a bit glitchy at times; such as when you kill a couple enemies and their bodies vanish before your eyes. The only major downside of the game is that the camera loves to fight you. Be it by being on the wrong side when aiming half the time, turning when trying to jump which leaves poor Lara arcing past a ledge and falling to her death, or turning to face Lara when nearing the top of a climb instead of staying behind her to give you a view of the dozen cultists waiting to ram their machette into her throat. You will probably die more often to poor camera work than anything else in this game. I will note that the poor camera work is pretty much par for the course for a 3rd person action-adventure game, and this is not even close to the worst I've seen *cough*DevilMayCry2*cough*, so it can be overcome fairly easily. It seems to be just about the right length for an action-adventure game, not long, but not really short either, and if you are going to 100% completion you can probably expect to spend around 20 hours playing. The world is also one of the more beautiful I've seen in a game so far. The water effects are amazing, the characters are smooth, but they don't look like plastic, the fire effects is where I believe this game shines though, they even produce a heat blur when looking through them. I would rate this game a solid 8/10

Tomb Raider is a true work of art and a must-own for every gamer.

Keep campsites for checkpoints/autosaves, but allow manual saving for people who want to use it.

Kudos to the team that brought us Tomb Raider. They have worked very hard to bring us a cinematic experience, giving us gorgeous and detailed environments, blending cut scenes with urgent platforming, fast-paced action along with a touch of sandbox roaming. It is clearly a labour of love, and I have enjoyed hours hunting down every item, finding every document and completing every challenge. If you have to resort to guides to do any of this, or to solve any of the puzzles, then you are not really trying very hard!  You do have to work at suspending your disbelief, though, when Lara survives the most outrageous falls and explosions without any broken bones, and sticks the most unlikeliest of jumps ...and Lara grunts continuously, even when standing still.  All of this is good clean, violent fun, though. Now, here are my gripes:   Camera ---------------------- I was continually wrestling for control of the camera. I don't need the game telling me where I should be looking, I can manage all by myself, thankyou.  Button-mashing ---------------------- As an adult, I don't want to be button-mashing. Seriously: you can leave that for the kiddies' games. I don't know any adult who wants to be furiously pounding their keyboards.   Quicktime Events ---------------------- And, we've got quick-time events. This wasn't fun with the ancient Dragon's Lair in 1983 (so I am told). It certainly isn't fun now.  Scripted Events ---------------------- The game is linear and it is scripted in parts. It doesn't matter if you have been playing a certain style, because the game is going to make you do these scenes the way it wants you to. This breaks immersion. I would prefer to do it my way. You can see why the devs have done this, though. Mostly these scenes really do work, and give the game the action blockbuster feel the devs were seeking, and when you play these through flawlessly, it really is exhilarating.  Tomb Raider is a good game. I do hope the devs have put in telematics into this game so that they can see what they should do more of and what they should avoid next time, because one thing's for sure: I will be playing the sequel.  8/10 (single player PC)

Oh I remember ye-olde Tomb Raider games. Running around, gunning down velociraptors with a shotgun like a badass.  And oh, how far away those days seem at the start of Tomb Raider (the new one, not the old one, because names and numbers are hard). This new Tomb Tomb Raider no longer has a badass Lara, but rather a whiny, weak and constantly crying Lara, and here is where the downhill starts (big word coming up): ludonarrative dissonance.  Here's an example on than and the reason why I give the story such a low score:  8 hours into the game Lara opens a door. Behind the door are fifteen burly men with floodlights, sandbags, shotguns and submachineguns all pointing at Lara. Lara then proceeds to massacre these would-be ambushers without comment.  12 hours into the game Lara is in a room with a friend of hers and several enemies are approaching. 'Leave me, Lara, you can't take them!' -the friend says, and Lara turns away and just ♥♥♥♥ing LEAVES! Oh and then she cries some more, because women apparently do that a lot. I shouted bloody murder at my monitor.  Other than the broken story, Tomb Tomb Raider is actually a pretty cool game. All but one of the Tombs in Tomb Tomb Raider are optional for some reason, but at least they're there. Gunplay is okay, enemy AI is fine and the overarching story is interesting enough even with the bawling protagonist breaking down immersion every ten minutes. The game is also gorgeous. The splashing waters, the fluttering leaves, the tumbling ragdolls, all of them are well rendered and believable.  Playtime: 19+ hours (single playthrough)  Ratings (1-10) Visual: 9 Audio: 7 Story: 6 Gameplay: 8 Overall: 8

I didn't know what to expect with this game, and to its credit, it took me a few hours to realize which game this is a clone of. Of course that's mostly because the first few hours are a little schizophrenic. There's about a thirty second intro (where Lara introduces her game with the cringe-inducingly generic line 'I went looking for adventure, but adventure found me') before you're immediately thrown into quicktime events. I guess they wanted to dump you into the action quickly to feel as lost and confused as Lara, but it was awkward and off-putting. I felt confused and emotionally uninvested. Then, one you're past the quicktime events it introduces the concept of hunting animals for food to survive, which makes it seem like it might be a survival based game (which actually sounded really cool), but that's really just a tutorial, you never have to shoot another animal again. Finally the gamesettles into thing and reveals that it's actually an Arkham Asylum clone.  I don't have anything against a game being a clone of another game and Tomb Raider is polished enough to be fun and uses cover-based shooter mechanics as its defining element over Arkham's brawling, so it feels like more than a straight rip-off, but it was never good enough for me to forget that I was playing a game that wasn't quite as good as Arkham Asylum. It tries to have stelthy sections interspersed with the action like AA, but your guns are so effective that it's all pointless. In Arkham Asylum the stealth sections put you at a disadvantage and you had to use your superior mobility to outwit the enemies. Sometimes in Timb Raider being stealthy can save you from having more enemies pop out, but there was never a point where I couldn't Rambo through every thing, even with the combat set to hard. It has the same exact pacing as AA where you'll a lternate between more linear areas and those that offer a little exploration, but Tomb Raider's open areas don't really lend themselves to the exploration as well as AA's. They have a more natural and less crafted feel to them, but at the same time it makes it a slog to look around for everything.  There are also too many sections that take control away from the player to try and simulate peril. In one section Lara has to shimmy her way up a crack in a mountain side. All the player has to do is hold up and she does all the work. Yeah, it looks like she's struggling and trying to avoid falling rocks, but there's absolutely no threat. Sometimes moments like that can work in a game, but when they fail, they're glaringly obvious.  Once the story actually begins to develop at a logical pace it'snot terrible. Lara's fellow castaways all fall into archetypes, but charmingly so rather than obnoxiously. It goes for the hollywood action blockbuster approach rather then the slower paced survial thriller it feel like at first. There are silly moments that don't fit in with the gameplay, for example the game makes a big deal of the first guy you kill, as if Lara is traumatized, but fifteen minutes later, you're sneaking up behind enemies and choking them to death like it's no big deal. There's a moment late in the game where you get a grenade launcher and Lara starts busting ♥♥♥ like she's some avenging angel. It's clearly supposed to be a major moment in the storyline, but I was running through so many enemies early on that it just felt like I was doing the same thing I'd been doing all along.  In any case the game's pretty, the gunplays solid, it's neat to discover tombs (even though most of the item collection is just picking up ♥♥♥♥ that's lying around). I'd recommend Arkham Asylum before this game if you haven't played it already, but Tomb Raider a'int too shabby if you can find a good sale price.

Tomb Raider is one of the best, if not the best, games I have played in the past couple of years. You play as Lara Croft, an adventurer, a cute adventurer in a tank top might I add, who persuades the crew of the Endurance, a ship, to go search for an island thought to be home of an ancient civilization. You can probably guess, something very terrible occurs.   It is very much a 3D puzzle platformer (if that is even a thing) and requires you to go around to find your friends while searching for relics along the way. The platforming and gameplay style is very similar to that of the Uncharted series so you can jump and climb on anything marked to do so. I would go as far to say that they are literally the exact same but with a different story and characters. Voice acting is fantastic as is the detail (or as 'Total Biscuit' often says, the 'graphical fidelity.') Anything you see and hear was done very well and you can tell there was plenty of effort put into this. Though linear, the story is easy to follow.   Of the few bad things, only few need mention. The first is realism. Somewhere along the lines, Square Enix believed that Lara Croft is able to keep going on her adventure after sustaining tons of injuries, some being critical. For a girl of that size and stature, there is no way she would be able to keep going after all of that.   Second is the quick time events. There are a few scattered quick time events in this game which can be quite annoying. They're rather easy and quick, but that's not the problem. The frustrating part is *when* they occur; they come at unexpected intervals during the gameplay or during a cutscene. One second you're sitting there watching, the next moment you're being told to press a button within 1-2 seconds. It's way too quick.  Third problem, which is a major flaw is the multiplayer. I cannot even explain how ♥♥♥♥ this multiplayer is. This is genuinely one of the worst MP experiences I have ever had, and with good reason. It's laggy. It automatically starts with voice chat enabled by default and many people don't realize it's on so you can hear them all game. The maps are usually one-sided and just have a bad layout. Think of this as a single player 'play' on a crappy map where enemies are controlled by real people. On top of all of that, multiplayer is dead. You have to wait at least 10 minutes to get into a good game with other players. It's a good thing people don't buy this game for the multiplayer experience because it would be a huge letdown.   Aside from the multiplayer, Tomb Raider is worth every penny.   Controller not supported (even with x360ce), even though it says it is. Mouse and keyboard is actually much better anyways.  TL;DR: Play as Lara Croft, a girl who wears a tank top all game and is immortal to injuries, in an Uncharted clone on the PC. Quick time events happen. Multiplayer is absolute ♥♥♥♥.  Obligatory score: 9/10
Lara can sure take some wood down her throat, I tell you what.

Good graphics, ♥♥♥♥ poor combat, boring and way too easy combat with absolutely no variety (there is a hint of stealth but its not really used for anything other than getting into a spot where you feel like starting the killing spree). They could have given killing some kind of meaning and i think they tried with the ♥♥♥♥? scene in the beginning.   Alot of things in this game makes no sense at all, like killing animals (think its for XP, don't know. Skipped all that). Opening doors with a bow and rope?? even tho its on the same level as your character etc. Blowing up natural gas to push a cage with your friends into safety? I could go on forever with stuff that just don't make any sense, and only serves to smash the little immersion this game offers.   There were some cool climbing etc and i think that focus on archeology, climbing and puzzle solving would have been miles better than this ♥♥♥♥ poor combat trash.  I can go on but i dont even feel like this game even warrants more.

Tomb Raider is an amaizing game a must have. Tomb Raider delivers an intense and gritty story of the origins of Lara Croft and her ascent from frightened young woman to hardened survivor, armed with only raw instincts and the physical ability to push beyond the limits of human endurance. Superb physics-based gameplay is paired with a heart-pounding narrative in Lara's most personal, character-defining adventure to date. The environments are lush and expansive, with at times photo-realistic vistas that stretch out through forests, over cliffs and out into the ocean. Indoor locations are equally impressive, with dimly lit caverns and unexplored bunkers creating plenty of atmosphere.

Absolutely gorgeous visitation to Lara's beginnings. Has all the classic Tomb Raider puzzles, treasure hunting, and physical feats we've grown to love but enchanced with stealthiness, plenty of action and extremely tense moments, and an RPG-like progression of skills and equipment. A wholly satisfying affair I highly recommend picking up.

There are a bunch of things I hate, and among them are games containing QTEs and jumping puzzles. I can't play some of the most popular platform games just because of jumping puzzles. Tomb Raider is a game primarily about QTEs and jumping puzzles, and yet I love it. Why is this? I don't actually know, but I have some guesses.  First: The actual jumping is pretty forgiving. In fact the control mechanics, animations and graphics are so fluid that there's rarely any guesswork involved in deciding, for example, if a particular jump is within reach. Evaluating your surroundings and making your way through them is more spatial puzzle than twitch reaction test. The result is a world that's a pleasure rather than a frustration to move about in. It's hard for me to say with any authority, but it feels like this is rare in a game in this genre.  Second: The QTEs are not great, but they're not terribly frequent and they make a certain amount of sense in context. In short - not a stellar achievement in QTE, but easy enough to overlook even if you're not a fan.  Third: The level design and graphics and just everything else about the game. It looks gorgeous, it's fun to explore and the controls are fantastic. I even went out and found most of the collectibles, not out of any completionist compulsion but because it was fun to get to them.  Fourth: Lara is both human and a superhuman badass, and you're vicariously both of those things through her. You can feel and share her fear, pain, excitement, awe, exhaustion, anger, relief - even as she displays complete disregard for gravity and the limits of human endurance.  The obligatory con(s): The shooty bits are a little meh. I didn't like that enemies popped in to areas only when you were nearby, even if you could have sniped them from further away. I can understand why they did that, but it felt like a regression from other recent shooters that support stealthy sniping even if not outright encouraging it.  2) A minor nitpick: If you're relatively observant and obsessively collecting journal entries, you're going to work out what's happening quite a lot sooner than Lara does. It then gets a bit much listening to her wonder about things that she should already have figured out.  3) Don't ever let her into your house. She will wreck it, then burn it to the ground.

Tomb Raider is the first of the series I've played and by the sounds of it the best in the series I will ever play. It's a very cinematic experience, which could be a slight turn off for some due to the high level of QTE's, but I found them to work well almost all the time. The fighting is brutal and fun and there are a few nice, but not very difficult, puzzles interspersed with the action which helps its pacing. I often find the motivation to do something in games is not very clearly expressed through the story, but with Tomb Raider I never got that feeling. I always knew why or where I was going and it all wrapped in a pleasing manner. It helped that Lara was a believable and likeable character, who got scared, surprised and angry in a way that made you believe the often outrageous scenarios presented to you throughout the game. If there is anything that was a bit off I'd have to say it was the hunting. It's presented initially like it's a big part of the game, but it's clear later on that it's completely unnecessary. Luckily it doesn't detract from the rest of the game, so you can safely ignore it without ruining the rest of the experience. Overall it is a surprisingly fun game and certainly worth your time to play.

It's always difficult for a game that you have high expectations for to live up to those expectations. I'm not a huge Tomb Raider fan, I've played the early games a bit, but never made it through to the end. I just heard the story was really good in this, of how Lara Croft transforms from innocent young girl to psycho killer ♥♥♥♥♥ of death and so was looking forward to an immersive 20 or so hours playing this game. Well, it's okay. The game is beautiful and I did enjoy the puzzles and the shooty bits. However, I didn't really feel a connection with any of the characters and didn't really care what happened to them. Including Lara. Once you've seen someone stabbed through the stomach with a pencil, and then proceed to leap around a forest, you kind of lose the ability to relate to them! Also I found the actual tomb raiding felt out of place. She's running around an island trying to escape, facing death at every turn and then she's like 'Ooh, isn't this Ming vase exquisite!' There are also far too many quick time events. I'm playing this game for fun! Quick time events are not fun! Doesn't everyone know that? And oh my gosh, no more moving left and right to avoid objects sequences please, they are also not fun, and haven't been fun since the 1980s. But if you can forgive the last two points, this game is worth playing. What it does well, it does very well, I'm just not waxing lyrical because I didn't get the story I was hoping for.

Seeing how Lara Croft became THE Lara Croft is a treat. From a terrified young girl, to a hardened warrior brave enough to take on an island of enemies single-handedly. For those who are both fans of the original games and those that are new to them, this game is worth the buy.   Tomb Raider will draw you in and hold you captivated, leaving you unable to tear yourself away from it. I highly recommend this game.

This is the first Tomb Raider I've played and I haven't even finished playing the game and I'm already dissapointed. The graphics and well written plot are ruined with the almost impossible maneuvering skills you're allowed in 'emergencies.' It also fails to register when you 'mash' a button. Falling off a cliff? Press e to save Lara. What's that? I'm sorry, you fall to your death because the game doesn't recognize that you pressed e a million times to save Lara. So you're stuck there dying numerous times because the game does not realize that you are doing what it tells you. You have to 'mash e' for stupid tasks like opening doors and if you don't do it quick enough(which gets tiring after a few times of it not recognizing you're mashing e) the meter it has just drops and you have to start all over. You're also a lot slower than the enemies chasing you so you die a lot from that, as well. Which brings me to another point of how the game likes to show various graphic ways of Lara dying if you don't do something correctly. There is a river scene where you have to shoot at blocks to get rid of them but also avoid piles of rubble which conveniently have sharp sticks in them, which impale Lara if you don't avoid them, which, again, is hard to do because a.) You can't see them. and b.) the reaction time is slow when you try to move Lara out of the way. It'll just frustrate you. I consider myself a very patient person but this game just completely tore that down. I definitely don't recommend this game. I'm glad I only bought it for a few bucks during the summer sale instead of the full price.

This was one of the most enjoyable single player experiences I've played through in a long time.   The story seemed to flow well, albeit in an outlandish setting [but what video game isn't?] , the game mechanics were smooth and easy to adapt to and learn, and the pacing was consistantly good with just enough going on to keep you interested and enough downtime to let you explore a little if you want to.   The single player run through was a sensible length, around 8-10 hours I believe. A fair span for modern games [although I maintain that modern games are too short in general and rely too heavily on making this up in multiplayer, but that's another rant entirely].  It's also an extremely attractive game with some beautiful scenery.   All in all I see no reason not to buy this game, especially since it's been around long enough that it'll no longer make your wallet cry.

I found the game mildly enjoyable. As someone who played Uncharted 2 and 3 it feels somewhat similar to that in terms of gameplay. If you were expecting strong character development in, I don't know, the only important character in the entire game, Lara, then you've come to the wrong place. In the start of the game, Lara breaks down over killing one or two people but in no time she's on her way to massacring literally hundreds of people throughout the rest of the game (unloading an assault rifle into their chest or jamming her ice pick into their skull, you name it). Lara also gets stranded on the island with a bunch of other people who I can't be bothered to remember their names for, only two or so of which are actually significant in the game, and only two of which I actually cared slightly about (other than Lara).   Parts of the game are somewhat open to exploration, but there really isn't much to find. There are occasional 'optional' tombs which require you to solve an easy peasy puzzle to get a handful of xp. Speaking of puzzles, don't expect to find any particularly hard ones in this game because nearly all of them are childs play.   In terms of combat, there are some areas where you need to use stealth but in most cases, it isn't very viable, some areas just force you into combat and you have no option to use stealth. Stealth is slightly important in the beginning of the game but as you progress, Lara can get upgrades that basically make her a tank, so you can (and will need to) go full rambo in some sections of the game.   Finally, there are a few things that really bug me about the game. There are a few bosses which can only be killed by completing quick time events (did I mention there are a LOT of them?), so despite me pumping thousands of assault rifle rounds into their exposed, fleshy head, they can only be killed if I hit them in the face with my pick. Lara's deaths are pretty brutal and this bothered me a lot. I understand what they were trying to go for, but after the first few deaths it really just got more annoying than shocking.   Basically, I don't recommend this game because it really isn't that fun and it also happens to do an extremely poor job of developing Lara's character.

Picked this one up in the collection pack for $20 recently (all of them ever made up to this one) and decided to hop right into this one.  I've gotta say that it's a major league improvement over any of the past titles in the series by leaps and bounds. Lara quite literally gets beat to pieces in this one and you get to actually see and experience each and every bit of that along the way. I've gotta tell you--it gets very brutal in some places if you aren't used to violence in games by now. She wades through muck, mire, and even blood at one point all while gathering bits of it all over her since that would naturally happen to anyone else if placed in those real-life environments. And about those environments: they are pain-stakingly beautiful and rich--even if some were a bit too gruesome for my taste.  The puzzles in this game are interesting but once you get used to solving them they actually get quite predictable since there's only so many ways to present the same thing over and over again. I even found myself locating all of the treasures and relics along the way the first time through the game--instead of backtracking over previously explored territory (was I supposed to do that?). Probably the most frustrating aspect of the game is the quick-action events (or whatever the game called them, ugh) that often end up punishing you with some brutal death-scene rather than allowing you any adequate amount of time to accomplish anything. So, you end up repeating a short section of the game until you get it just right.  All in all this is a much-needed step in the right direction for the Lara Croft/Tomb Raider series and I hope she has many more successful games in this franchise left in her before she sees retirement! ;-p

Somehow Square Enix managed to make a graphical experience where Lara Croft falls down from dangerous and deadly heights at least 6,354,754,554,123,874 times and eventually they shaped it into a playable game...Nah! I'm just joking!  Story wise this game is pretty nice, but predictable.   Uh oh we crashed on a island and now we need to get help. Mysterious storm makes plane crash? Wat is goin o-...oh wait its the sun queen, she is vengeful bleh bleh bleh   It is however a pretty long story and took me about 12 hours on the hardest difficulty to complete it.  Controls are pretty good, but I wish I could change normal and fire arrows/shells without having to use the number keys. I prefer all weapon changing options bounded to the mouse wheel but...you know what I'll shutup since I'm being bias now.  Graphics for the year it released are good, and when maxed out this game can put a hurting on your system. I just leave things like Tesselation and TressFX off though, I prefer 60+ FPS at all times. They did a great job of porting this too, it is very well optimized in a sense that your GPU is tested through thick and thin, while the CPU won't make too much of a difference.  Gameplay isn't very unique, but that doesn't mean it's not fun. The bow and the rope system are pretty cool, along with the use of the things like the rope pulley thingy-that-I-cannot-remember-the-name-of.   Replayability isn't very long, as you can usually find half of the stuff in one area while doing the story. After playing for 24 hours I have a 100% completed save game. There are a few achievements that mostly require you to start a new game so maybe you can get some fun out of doing that.  Multiplayer I won't go over much, I've only done two 1vs1 matches with a friend, and I've never been a fan of third person multiplayer. I was kinda hoping you start the game with a bow and weapons are scattered on the map and such but nope...they added the old and overused loadout system that has been around since 2007 with CoD4 (CoD4 is still a good game by my standards).  So, my overall verdict is that you should probably look into playing/buying this game, even at the $20 pricetag. If you're patience enough, you can wait for a steam sale and save some money but honestly, if I knew this game was as good as it is, I wouldn't have mind pre ordering it.

In one sentence: Best Tomb Raider ever!  Yes, yes I know it lacks the platform puzzles of the first few since this is more of an action-survivor kind of game, which for whatever reason seems to be anathema to some. But this doesn't change the fact that not only is this a great and entertaining game, it is also the first Tomb Raider that made me see Lara as more than a pair of polygonal boobs doing stuff. For the first time I actually felt that she was a full-fledged character, not a mere game-mechanism or worse still a caricature. Fans of the original game's sense of exploration shouldn't be disappointed either. The game may take place in just one island but the areas you will find yourself in are nothing short of stunning.   If there is one thing to complain about, it is the dissonance between the player's actions and Lara's feelings. Lara is portrayed as green, struggling to place her life above those of her assailants and visibly tormented the first time she has to kill a person. At the same time, the player is encouraged to employ increasingly ruthless tactics and kill with abandon. It just doesn't sit right. Also I suppose the multiplayer experience is, I guess, a bit underwhelming. If it matters to you, its another thing to consider. Personally I'm not interested in multiplayer, so for me this doesn't change all that much.  All in all, this is a great game. And it's highly recommended.

Excellent, 10.5/11. Immersive, cinematic and beautiful, full of story and those tiny details that games like Half Life 1 had. It's a survival/action/puzzle/mystery adventure, mostly. Looks incredible on Ultimate settings. Hair! Finally someone makes a game out of all the modern 3D tech. +1 for Canadians :)  Pros: polished and immersive cinematic experience; the game world feels alive with movement and details; beautiful vistas and locations; storytelling and plot rather than back-story; stealth plays a role in combat; no quest log or map following.  Cons: press button to live; not a lot of actual puzzles; items and ammo are pickups instead of scrounged - gameplay is not survival-based even though the plot is; stealth isn't as important as it seems; not an open world; achievements do not fit the story.  It's a shame, but in an effort to make the game have the widest possible appeal, most of the actual gameplay and difficulty have been toned down or replaced with timed button presses. Still, if this kind of game encourages more cinematic immersion and more storytelling in games, it's worth supporting and well worth playing as it stands.  Note: If you revel only in complex game mechanics and view pretty pictures and story as fluff, this game is not for you.

At the end of TR, just as you're about to win, there's a sequence that brought back something iconic from the previous Tomb Raider games and it made me smile…I should have expected it but didn’t and it just made me smile when it happened. These are the moments I always want in games but seldom experience…when Gordon picked up the super gravity gun and went OFF…when Commander Shepard walked the line at the end of ME2…when Shoeless Joe Jackson tells Ray Kinsella “Build it and HE will come” (sorry…not a game). At some point half-way through I really started to care about Lara Croft. I stopped analyzing the game for its merits and started playing it enthusiastically. So much so that when I knew I was on the last quest I stopped and went back to all my previous locations to pick up any remaining things because I wanted to prolong the experience…not “level up”. That should tell you something.  The game really isn’t that hard, the puzzles are not complicated, the side missions and searches for 'stuff' are not totally integral to the story...but I was having so much fun I finished all the core mission’s w/100% of the non-essential stuff I had to find. I spent hours looking for mushrooms, flags, and Buddha’s. It really was that good (far better than mining planets in ME2). I identified with the physical locations in the game (remote island w/lots of Japanese WW2 stuff in it), I identified with the hero in a way I haven't since Portal 2 and Mass Effect 2, and I thought the voice acting was excellent. Even though your compatriots don’t do much but die (in solid QT sequences), they add to the sense that Lara is in way over her head and maybe somewhat out of her head. Tomb Raider was the most enjoyable game I've played in a long time. Although technically a reboot, this is an entirely original game that should appeal to anyone. The level design was original and very vertical, some of the QT sequences are totally implausible but incredibly fun, there’s a LOT of gore early on (and in some of the later missions), and although the story is only slightly above average…it’s told exceptionally well.  In a nutshell…best gaming experience for me since Mass Effect 2 and Portal 2.   Notes: Most if not all the technical issues at start have been corrected with updates and new video drivers. The much vautned TRESSFX hair effect is, more or less, a foo-foo add to get you to run their benchmark...but it is a cool mini-benchmark and you owe it to yourself to try it (if for anything else than to see your gaming rig crawl to 16fps or slower at max settings).

This is a good single player game. It's polished, has a nice story, nice graphics and compelling gameplay. It's an easy game, perhaps because it's balanced for console aiming. With a mouse you can headshot every enemy and it never really challenges you in that respect, but it's still fun. The game has a nice exploration feel to it. The puzzles are nice, particularly the tombs.  My only real complaint is the quick time events. They aren't fun. They are interspersed in the gameplay and in cutscenes, there's no way of knowing when it's gonna happen, and, I don't know what it's like on consoles, but on PC the key that you have to press in order to not die seems to change depending on the event. It doesn't add anything, it just serves to kill you once and make you watch the cut scene again. It's a particular problem at the start of the game in which it forms a major part of the gameplay, because a large part of the narrative is made up of short cutscenes. Stick with it and it does get better.  The multiplayer is pointless. It shouldn't have been added, but it does the game no harm by its presence.

I loved every bit of it. If you like platform jumping, wall climbing, pressing buttons on demand to get out of a sticky situation (Like God of War) then you'll like this game. But the combat is just as good. I loved using my bow to get stealth kills or once I was noticed, switching over to the shotgun for brute force. You can also dish out melee moves once they get real close and perform finishing moves based on the weapon you have out at the time. If your completionist like me, theres a lot of things to seek out and collect for 100% completion. Then there's the story. From the beginning you'll be sucked in by the mysterious actions of the island and will want to know more about what has been happening here. And from there it only becomes better. The graphics are some of the best I've seen to date. The animations of Lara are amazing. I sometimes forget I'm even looking at rendered polygons and think its just a movie. I can't believe how lifelike they were able to make her movements. For example, she'll fling her hands downwards when she is treading in water to get rid of the water off her arms and hands. BUY IT!
this game is awesome i like how they make us feel the rush of surviving in the island. to feel how little woman make a choice. also this game also have a little puzzle too!

This game should be called 'Uncharted: Lara Croft', because it follows so closely in the footsteps of the Uncharted games on the Playstation 3. Even so, it's one of the nicest looking games I've played in a while and it was good fun too. The downsides for me are that it's sometimes a bit gory without the need for it. Do I need to see Lara graphically shot in the face, or fatally impaled, if I don't press the right key in time? That'll be 'No' then. Also there's a bug in the game for me. I have completed all areas to 100% and the 'All Challenges' completed achievement hasn't unlocked. In all, highly recommended, especially if you can pick up the 'Game Of The Year' edition as I did for a fiver on Steam!

For the hardcore Tomb Raider fans, this may not be the usual Lara Croft you have come to know and love but it is definitely the Lara Croft you would come to respect.  The timeline for this installment of Tomb Raider dates back to when Lara was still the little adventurer with not a single drop of bad-♥♥♥ in her. The story was decently written with the ol' usual save-the-world theme, or rather this time is more of 'save my peeps and then myself'. It is an interesting story and it kept me wanting for more, the build-up was great and the direction it steered was indeed intriguing.  The characters was interesting and with enough effort to locate scattered documents in the world, made the characters even more so interesting as you get to learn their backstory.  The gameplay mechanics was quite good. I loved how the controls felt solid! The camera can be a little wonky at times, but forgiven as it does it's job most of the time.  The multiplayer mode is a little of a joke as an extension/game-life-extender. Though I can see the potential of it being interesting, but as like most single-player games made into multiplayer; it does not carry any true value for replayability.  The servers are mostly empty!  Overall, this game is an ace of a flying color and something to not miss out off if you're a fan for adventure or 3rd person action shooter. I am willing to give this game a rating of:  [4.5 / 5]  ::Rating legends:: 0 - Terrible, don't bother getting or even looking for it. 1 - Boring. Played only for the LoL of it. Not recommended to get 2 - Could have done a little better but was a snore to play it. Not recommended to get but may interest a particular party. 3 - Average. Pretty average game/story feel. Could have done better. No comments on acquiring, get if you want. 4 - Good. Had fun with it and would definitely recommend to get. 5 - Best game ever made, buy it and probably make love to it. (A rare rating to get)  Any ratings with a '.5' additional is basically a bonus to set it apart from its default to show how it's slightly better/more enjoyable. This game was immensely fun, and looked beautiful on my system.  Transitions between gameplay and cutscenes are exceptionally smooth, and most likely the best I've seen. You may even occasionally attempt moving around during cutscenes as I did, or neglecting to move thinking you're still in the middle of one. There were only two or three hiccups to this.  Initially, for whatever reason, the TressFX quality setting for the hair was a bit buggy. Cutscenes in particular, as well as some regular gameplay, would see Lara's ponytail develop a mind of its own as it started flailing about without the presence of wind. This eventually went away, and I didn't have issues with it again.  The mechanics of the game are exceptionally easy to get used to and enjoyable. Storyline was greatly interesting, and the inclusion of random historical artifacts ranging anywhere from early A.D. to World War II era added that much more.  Plus, the unexpected deaths you suffer when you make a mistake are almost a source of enjoyment, as well as a bit of an 'Ooh, that had to hurt,' moment.  I'd highly recommend this, and not just to anyone that has played Tomb Raider in the past. I'm looking forward to future titles.

This isn't just a remake of the original Tomb Raider, it is a complete reimagining of the entire series. Fans of the original games may end up disappointed with the new direction. There is definitely more action and quick time events than a traditional platformer.   With that being said, the story focuses on the gritty origin story of Lara. You start off as a young and inexperienced Lara heading out for the first time on a grand adventure. You are quickly shipwrecked, beaten, bruised, stranded alone and traumatized within the first hour of the game. Equipped with a bow and a climbing pick, your goal is to recover the rest of the crew that you arrived with and to escape the island in one piece.  Basic gameplay is that of a traditional third-person shooter. You run around using cover and shooting around edges and corners to progress through fights. There is also the element of stealth that can be employed. If you are good with the bow and sneaking up behind people, you can stealth-kill your way through a vast majority of the game.  Some quick time events are fairly bland. The most common one is to press a single button repeatedly to open certain doors. Others are the typical 'press E at the right time or die' situations. They don't add much or detract too much from the overall experience. If you fail at one of the events, it'll put you right back into the action and give you another chance.  The greatest disappointment with the game is the multiplayer. It is a veritable ghost town and next to impossible to find a game except during peak hours. It is plagued with one-hit-kill mechanics that discourage newer people from giving it a second try after playing with more experienced people. It feels like it was tacked on at the last minute in spite of all the downloadable content and emphasis placed on it by the developers.   The visuals and graphics are absolutely breath-taking at times. So much so that it enhances the journey on the island to feel much more epic that it would have otherwise. This is an amazing game and well worth the price if you are willing to accept the new direction of the series.
