I would first like to say that I'm a bit surprised how overwhelmingly positive the reviews are for this game. Reason is that I've played TR for many years and have played all of them up to this one. TR has a fairly large devoted following of not only diehard fans but purists. I say this as my favorite TR game is Angel of Darkness (AoD). Like this game, AoD was considered a TR reboot, in which the developer tried to add some new features to spice up the franchise and send it in a new direction. AoD was widely panned by both critics and players. The fans did not like the changes one bit, and I have to admit that some of them were a problem - mainly due to design issues and bugs. However, AoD is most definitely a true TR game with some of the best tomb raiding and puzzles in the series. Also, imo AoD is the most epic and challenging TR game with a great story. I think many players did not even finish it after the first, admittedly, somewhat cumbersome first couple of chapters.  With that said, the new Tomb Raider game here is quite good. The main issue is that actual tomb raiding is very very minimalized. Tombs basically consist of a handful of small caves with some fairly easy puzzles. I have yet played the newly released game after this one, but I suspect the lack of tomb raiding was by design. I believe the game was meant to be more of a pre-tomb raiding / origin story of the young Lara, where she gets her first tastes of tomb raiding. Hopefully, this aspect of the game becomes far more important to the series in the new and subsequent games. Ha..I mean the game is called Tomb Raider..and that is what Miss Lara is...  In addition to the Tomb Raiding factor, platforming, another important feature of the series in the past, is also under-utilized here. However, there's still quite a bit of it to be ok.  So, what makes this game good though is that it basically excels at all other aspects of the action-adventure genre. For one, you have a very nice story here. A story that really marries the setting to the plot and action. I'd say it's probably the best story in the TR series to date, especially as story and plot has not always been TR's calling card, so to speak. Combat here is quite fun, moderately challenging, and with decent AI, although not great AI for sure. Sometimes the AI kind of gets stuck in between spawn section running around like chickens with their head cut off. But still, it's pretty cool how the AI will take cover and throw grenades and molotovs at Lara. You can't always just hide behind cover and expect to safely pick off the enemies. And they will charge you too. The weapons are pretty cool, especially the bow. Also, the bow is used quite a bit for PvE stuff as well. Actually, I think it would be quite fun to try to play the game through completely using only the bow for combat as a challenge. Lastly, all technical aspects of the game are excellent from sound to visuals, and I encountered no bugs whatsoever.  So the point here, is that while Tomb Raider is by no means a typical Tomb Raider type game, it certainly classifies as a very good and entertaining action-adventure game. If you like the genre at all, you will like this one. Still, I hope to see more epic tomb raiding in the future of this series. I rate this 8/10.

Definitely the best Tomb Raider in the entire series mostly due to how well the game develops Croft as a character. It starts out as, more or less, a survival game in which the re-imagined Croft, this time nothing more than a grad student, is shipwrecked on an island and has to fend for herself against the elements and a crazed group of cultists hunting her and her friends. Things eventually go off the rails from gritty, survival, game to balls to the wall, over the top, action, but it's a testament to the writers that no matter how absurd things get (and they do get absurd) or how many scores of mercenaries Croft ends up mowing down by the game's end, it's able to maintain an emotional core and vulnerability to the character that makes it not only believable in its own way, but uniquely captivating.  Plus, the developers definitely have good taste in B-Action films, judging from the direct references to 'Rambo 2' and, most effectively, 'The Descent.' Not just a scene involving a 'baptism' in a pool of blood is lifted directly from 'The Descent,' but whole portions of the game's general tone and 3 act structure (from survival, to character hardening, to revenge) are taken from the film. I usually dislike it when games crib too obviously from films, but 'Tomb Raider' handles its filmic influences incredibly well.   It has its flaws (It's a bit too long and probably should have ended sooner after the middle climax, as the game definitely slumps in its more conventional second half. Plus, I think the game pulls its punches one too many times when it comes to Lara's companions, none of whom are as well developed or interesting as she is. Honestly, they would have had more impact if they'd just been killed off in the first act), but at its best, it feels like playing a really awesome, forgotten, Grindhouse action film from the 1970s....which is the highest praise I could ever give to an action game.

Areas are far too closed/linear to enjoy long. Had a very consolized feel to it. Visually capable - it just fell flat in many other areas. I never once felt like I cared for Lara, where she was, or what she was doing. The only items in the world you can interact with are highlighted, and either ammo or used in solving puzzles. Considering all that the game has going for it, it's hard for me to go against the grain with this one. Pros:  - Interesting gameplay ideas,  - Great level design, and art style over all (even though it's nearly always brown)  - Good character development  - Excellent graphics  - Pretty nice combat Cons  - Quick-Time Events: These kill the gameplay more than anything. There is nothing more frustrating and degrading than dying more than several times because the game thrusts button presses at you while there's action on-screen. These events even make their way into banal events like opening doors or kicking open objects, and even some cutscenes. This is what I can't stand in this game, when my skill level is brought down to my ability to press a button to progress through a cutscene that I have no other effect on anyway. This happens CONSTANTLY. All throughout the game, I ragequit simply because I can't press a button fast enough and I die instantly several times in a row. Unbelieveable.  - Mucky movement mechanics: In an effort to make movement more 'realistic', Lara instead moves as if she's guessing where I'm trying to go rather than directly responding to my keyboard. This makes getting into cover painful, simply because I'm hoping her AI can do it for me, rather than simple cover buttons that work better in so many other games.  You can play the game yourself to see whether this will bother you, but honestly, having finished the game, there were gleaming moments of solid design all-around, that ultimately fell victim to stupid Quick-Time Events that will kill you unfairly.

First, I am a guy raised with the first Tomb Raiders on the Playstation. I think I did all of them but I don't really remember everything. If there is a thing that Tomb Raider did well along the franchise it's mixing a great sense of exploration, mystery and wonder, with acrobatic action and fights. So, did they succeed to reboot the franchise without loosing the essence ?  In 2 hours I already saw a lot of flaws, they were so obvious and visible, and then after 3-4 hours I began having fun. Combats are kinda relaxing, but easy and dumb (man, the AI...). Exploring some beautiful environment is great. But I had a mixed feeling about the game all along.  Here is the thing, it could have been a lot better and the beautiful work that has been done in all department felt wasted. I just wanted to finish it, quite quickly actually. Play the ending, and then pass onto another game. I can like a game of the same style, an action adventure Hollywood-like. Let's take Dead Space 3: I had a good time playing it, it's a rich game, the gameplay is constantly switching and evolving, every sequences are great and you feel like you had enough when you finish it.  When I do Scripted 'on a rail' sequences in Tomb Raider (Lara falling, escaping, that kind of thing), it's not challenging, it feels long, no choices, easy and slow QTEs (QTEs alone are already not so good...). When I do climbing it doesn't need dexterity, accuracy or timing in your inputs. When I do stealth, I just pick up my bow, silent arrow, aim for the head, if I miss it and don't hit the body ? Well the worst thing that could happen is just distracting the target, he doesn't suspect a thing. When I do combat I don't need to be smart, pick up the right weapon or having a tactic (for at least 90% of the opponents). When I'm exploring, I just push the 'survivor sense' button, see what's glowing, go there, tap it again, for what ? Boxes that gives just a little XP or scraps. No inventory or item managing, no perk trade-off. You collect stuff, upgrade your gear throughout the progression, that's it. There is nothing really smart about any of the game mechanics.  Face's animations could have been better for a AAA title, on the technical side you can see that they were so limited by the old gen of consoles. Still it's beautiful on PC, but some stuff like the characters are not detailed enough, every cinematic (in engine) feels really poor. Lara is weirdly animated, it's too nervous and jumpy, even if there is details and contextual animation (Lara approaching her hand next to a rock while holding the torch, those kind of thing). From time to time it even feels like fps went down, but no, the animation is just jerky, and sometime it's the camera too.  The scenario is classic adventure stuff, nothing new, the character of Lara is not explored. Oh yeah, she get dark, look at how killing hundreds of bad guys is destroying her... For a surviving explorer, she have a biggest killing history that most war heroes. The other characters have nothing that set them apart from what we've already seen in other games or movies and are predictable. So I don't listen to the characters notes hidden everywhere. Frankly, it's boring to spend time reading or listening to it when all that I want is progress. For me the biggest let down of the adventure is that it would have been a powerful experience if it was more believable. Everything is PG13, exaggerated, flat. Big explosions, frenetic action, Lara yelling and getting wrecked every 5 minutes are not what moves a player. And it's short, 10 hours ! Why so many AAA action games always aim for a short adventure ? Of course we would want 4-5 hours more, they don't have any excuses for that.  So yeah, not a great experience. But I remind you, i didn't have a bad time either. Some stuff are good, 'hidden' tombs are interesting, there is not a lot of them but it's a nice little puzzle. Still too easy though.  Environments are impressive, maps are big and have a lot of vertical progression to them. I love the FOV they choose, mainly because I played it on 21/9 monitor I suppose but still, you see so much. I have quite the setup for gaming, big rig (GTX 980...), awesome monitor, headphone amp, subpac... So of course I enjoyed the ambiance, environments, music etc... The adventure, even though it's déjà vu and not deep, is well orchestrated and have a nice pace to it.  So, 'Did they succeed to reboot the franchise without loosing the essence ?' No, at least not as well as it could have been. It's not a bad game though, but 'not bad' is not what you expect for a reboot of such an iconic franchise. I talked in this review about how this reboot of Tomb Raider is failing at being a great game. There is a bit more stuff in it, this doesn't cover the whole game, but it's basely what I will remember from those 10 hours. Still, this makes me wonder if the next one is gonna be really better. After all, those kind of games are made so that you buy the sequel coming in the next few years.

This is not a review for all the fans who ever played a Tomb Raider game before. I'm pretty sure for all the true Tomb Raider fans it's a must. I myself actually never really played a Tomb Raider before. It's not a bad game but not the best in my opinion.   Graphics are good - even if it's already 2015, nearly 2016. As in most games, the hair isn't really good. Only Lara somehow has moving hair, all the others have static hair :/  What really made me decide to give a negative review is the story. Again it's not the worst story ever, but I always knew that if I'm really close to escaping the island, something new happens so I would have to do something again. For me it was like a really short story but the devs thought of some dumb things to make the story longer. Example: Oh we found a boat, but we need the tools that are like 10 miles away. Okay I got the tools but now all of a sudden the enemys are attacking again. 5 minutes before I'm there they take someone with them. Too bad you now have to go away 5 miles again to rescue said person. The game isn't that hard aswell. You have like 2-3 seconds to press the right key.   The multiplayer isn't really a thing and you have to get like lvl 60 to get some cool stuff: not really easy, the game is already 2 years old. I only played multiplayer once or twice.  I like that the game saves often.  Achievements and Collectibles: I'm absolutely not a fan of them so I finished the game with 65% completion. They're just not really a big thing in the game. Hunting is like once in a kind of tutorial involved but I never ever did hunting again. The upgrading system is cool, you want to get some salvage to get your weapons better but I don't think they have a really big impact on the gameplay.  Conclusion: The game isn't bad but I would appreciate some improvements to the story and some aspects of the gameplay. The graphics are really good - except the hair.

If you're a fan of linear games that tells an epic story, this is the game for you. The weapons and their mechanics are really cool and a lot of fun in this game. The Bow&Arrow must be the best part. This game's combat-mechanics is -so much more- than simply Aim&Shoot, which makes it very enjoyable and great fun. The movement-mechanics are so controlled, and you really feel agile and easily movable as you climb obstacles and jump around freely. Although this game is very obviously linear, it still feels very open and manouverable because of the immersive environments. It's difficult to explain it, you've just got to experience it. The fact that you travel so far in the game, makes it feel like it takes a lot longer to complete than it actually does, so you get a lot of playtime for the money. To top it off, you get to look at that sweet piece of meatpie as Lara's clothes get more and more torn the further you progress in the game. This is one of the best games I've played, and Lara is now one of my favorite game-characters. All in all, I give this game a 9.5/10, absolutely mindblowing.

Welcome to Tomb Raider QTE the motion picture... 'we see that you like QTE so we made a QTE in the QTE so you can QTW while QTE'ing'  Holy ♥♥♥♥ this game is full of QTE. I have never seen a game so full of it as this. There is more or less no skill events in this game, all QTE scripts.  Hold F or smash E to interact. Why the heck do I have to smash my keyboard 50 times to open a chests or a door? And there is a ton of them. Did I mention that you HAVE to do the collectable to have any understanding of what the heck is going on on the iceland?   And there is a TON of 'video clips'. Holy moly the amount of them makes this game more of a QTE interaction motion video.  And the main character you control is a wimp. Who the heck is this person? A random chick grabbed from the street then thrown into chaos? She is so weak and have an non interesting personality that it is on the border of boring. She cries, she whines, she whimper, she has no self esteem.... This is the person who is going to be Lara Craft the adventurer, and we have this drama queen? People in the reality show 'Big Brother' have more interestring personallity than the characters in the game.  The mobs in this game is boring and uninteresting. Not 1 bossfight was interesting or challanging. There where no gimmick or techniques. Dodge, F, QTE, I win. That is every fight with the few 'bosses' there is in the game. I have never ever played a game with so badly created bosses than this game. This game take the lead with a lightyear.  Then there is the movement, holy ♥♥♥♥ this is bad. Melee combat really suffers because of relly sluggy and bad movement.   And the 'puzzles' in this game is laughable. The DLC's are just stupidly expenceive compared to what it gives. Each catacomb is like 5 minuts. The puzzles are so easy that I wounder if they even tried to make it challenging or just put them in the game to have some 'content'. I think the longest I used to solve a puzzle in this game is about 2 minutes.  Do I recomand the game for full price? HELL NO!!!  If you get the game on 70% or better sale, buy it and play it. But don't expect some strong personality evolvement from the main character or any other you see in the game and don't expect any wow moments or experience from the game. It is a good looking half good action adventure game and nothing more.   Will I play the game again? Never.

totalbiscuit's description was fairly accurate, but I didn't enjoy this game. first of all the plot is so predictable and cliché that is was more annoying than enjoyable, because come on, it's the same basic maja-ish ritual magic story in which nothing makes sense, also stupid plot devices, and don't move the story forward in any way. I won't spoil it too much, but you make a disstress call, and the help you've asked gets destroyed, and in that part which took like 2 hours was completely useless and didn't progress the story in any way. Also notable was that it could have been directed by Michael Bay, almost everything explodes or gets destroyed, also some actions made by lara are not really survivable, like falling from real high, to getting wounds (because the plot says she has to have one) and are forgotten after 10 minutes of gameplay. Pretty awesome gameplay mechanics used a single time, there are also no surviving mechanics accept hunting which you do once and don't have to do the rest of the game, enemies on weird unreachable places like on high pillars, which then move and then magically disappear. the transaction between scared girl and mass murderer happens in one cutscene in which some bad guy gets killed, cries for 2 minutes about it and then starts killing everyone. It pretends that the game isn't linear, but it actually is because in most cases you don't have to get back, and is kind of weird because pretty often the path is destroyed or inacessable. And one last thing I straight up hated: a lot of quicktime events.

Tomb Raider is the reboot of the classic adventure games, but with a dark and gritty feel. Will you want to play this or go back to the originals ?  Tomb Raider follows on Lara Croft as she is on an expedition to find an Island called Yamatai which was once ruled by queen Himiko. The ship crashes on the island which is populated by crazy survivors who want the entire crew dead. So it's up to you to find a way of the island.   To begin this review I want to express something about this game. When it was first announced, I wasn't a major fan of the gritty and violent tone of the game. I felt that taking it too far would take away the charm the original game had. But after I had the chance to sit down and play it, I feel mixed on the game.  Now I'm not calling the game bad, I quite enjoyed it and found myself on the edge of my seat in some moments. But this game suffers from major problems which I hope will be fixed in the upcoming title Rise of the Tomb Raider.   The story is this games weakest point. You're supposed to root for the characters to get of the island and you want them all to stay alive. But apart from Lara i didn't care for anyone. All characters felt one dimensional and it was really hard to actually like any of them. You have stereotypical characters like the nerd, the tough old guy, the mentor and stuff like that. Not to mention the entire plot is incredibly predictable and you can see who dies from a mile away.  The gameplay is fun, but it feels more like a cover shooter than a mixture of both Adventure and Shooter game which the original game was. I felt the game focused way too much on the combat and not so much on puzzles. The game does have optional tombs that have puzzles in them so you can get the treasure, but it's incredibly easy to miss these tombs.   The game is also riddled with bugs and glitches. One time the game crashed because of an explosion I caused. Enemies phase through walls and you can glitch through walls too.   Graphics and the environments look absolutely beautiful and it's one of the best looking games I have ever played. Maxed out it's one pretty looking game.  The optional tombs are probably the best thing about this game. I loved the puzzles and the whole figuring out stuff even though it was incredibly easy.   Boss fights are another problem with this game. Most boss fights consist on how many shotgun shells can you blast in the shotgun face. Apart from one cool boss which took place up on a lift that's falling apart there's not much variety.  The entire game took me 10 hours to finish everything expect find all the collectibles. The game is overall pretty easy so you shouldn't have much trouble finishing it.   In the end this game tries too hard to be Uncharted with it's over the top action sequences. The game is still a really fun game and I would say it's worth buying just to play through it once. But expect more of an third person shooter and not a Puzzle driven adventure game with shooting involved.   Final Rating: 7/10 - Worth Checking out   If you liked this review, please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments what you disliked about the review.

It's a nice game, but has not a lot in common with the old games. Which was to be expected, but the changes go far beyond of what i was hoping for.  First, it's a modern game with loads of bad modern habits. The first hour it tries to hold your hand very, very firmly to explain the mechanics. And yet, it doesn't make a good job with that. I died 3 times in the introduction mission without seeing any enemy. Just annoyng.  Second, loads of moments that take you out of gameplay: Cutscenes, forced slow movement scenes without any gameplay or even story relevance (beside that dubios 'showing the weak side of Lara'-idea), useless 'press Y repeately to open hatch'-kinda moments and oh yea, and quicktime events! Why can't we just run around and encounter things in a gameplay kinda fashion?  Third: Jumpscares! Yes, creatures were attacking you surprisingly in earlier games, but here they go overboard to the point of making this game a borderline horrorgame. I see the point in the characterisation of a young Lara being afraid of the world, but they could have gone a far subtler way.  All in all it's not a bad game. But i'm just sick of a lot of those modern game design elements, that try to extend gameplay time artificially to cover up for weaker gameplay mechanics.

The only reason I would not recommend this game is simply because I am psychically unable to actually launch it -.- I've tried everything conceivable, and every tip the net has to offer and yet I am still 100% unable to even launch the game, I don't even get a black screen, nothing at all shows up. It apparently can have something to do with nvidia GPU's so for that reason alone the game devs can go ♥♥♥♥ themselves if they weren't able to pick up such a glaring bug in the game.

Uncharted (Girl Version) is an action-adventure third-person shooter platform video game series developed by Naughty Dog and published by Sony Computer Entertainment for PlayStation consoles. The series follows modern-day treasure hunter Lara 'Tomb Raider' Croft, senior treasure hunter and mentor Victor Sullivan, journalist Elena Fisher, and numerous secondary companions whom they will come to meet and recruit as they travel around the world to uncover various historical mysteries

An endless parade of quicktime events, linear action sequences and cutscenes with not one interesting or challenging moment. It attempts to build a character by having it's protagonist fall off dozens of cliffs, swim through blood and walk through catacombs made of skulls and is just trying way too hard to bring Lara's hardship across, so much even that it more starts to resemble an episode of Happy Tree Friends. Consequently, I took the game equally serious. Furthermore, ten hours is too short, all characters are simplified stereotypes with maybe two traits each and Lara herself has no personality whatsoever and is constantly bound by her environment, that only leaves her one option. She merely reacts to the environment and if that's all that I wanted to see I could also watch a dog walk around the island for ten hours and get the same result as playing this miserable reboot with no right to exist.

I'd consider this game a must have, for anyone even remotely into gaming in any fashion. It's worth it just for the sightseeing in this beautifully created world. If you have a computer that can run this with all settings maxed, it's pretty easy to argue this is the best looking game ever created.  Game play/mechanics: 8/10 Only marred by some of the quick time events, and as much as I usually hate QTEs, at least half of them are really good in this game, the ones that aren't give it a pretty major hit though. When they suit and advance the story, they are really really good, but there are a few of them that feel pretty tacked on, and one in particular that's the major concern. (No spoilers, you'll figure it out).  Graphics/visuals: 11/10 Best looking game I've ever played, the art direction, detail, atmosphere, everything is AAA+, amazing job.  Story: 10/10 Highly subjective, I really enjoyed it. It's a great concept, and really well pulled off in my opinion. Well above typical 'gaming' story and voice acting. Better than 99% of the movies released in the last 5 years.  If I had to use one word to sum this game up, it would be 'professional'. Everything about the production of this game is first rate. If it wasn't for the annoyance of a few QTEs, this game would rate as perfect for me. An outstanding game, and one that every gamer should own. Worth whatever price they feel like charging you.

Call of Duty: Laura Croft with a Bow and Arrow Edition  This game is a great game if you are looking for a terrible old arcade shooter. Because to make Lauracroft badass they need to give her an assault rifle and have her mow down countless enemies with it. Because killing people with assault rifles and improvised grenade launchers is how we know lauracroft is badass.  The cover based shooter mechanics are pretty terrible. There are some really good moments to be had within the game when you arent constantly shooting through hordes of enemies just because. I enjoyed the challenge rooms more than the actual game because the challenge rooms were nice short environmental puzzles, but sadly most of the game was not that. Most of the game was in fact Hid behind a rock and shoot every enemy you see until you run out of ammo and then switch to a different weapon.  The story started off great and successfully told the story of a girl willing to do anything to survive on a remote island, and managed to not suck all the way through. Sadly the game feels two-faced. You have the part that cares about whether Laura croft survives or not, and then you have the part of the game that wants lauracroft to be a elite bloodthirsty commando that has no regard for human life.

Don't get me wrong, I actually like this game. However, this really falls short of being a proper, classic Tomb Raider installment. I'm sad to say that I was dissapointed with how the game's story and length plays out.  It is remarkebly short, probably lasting 8 hours to my estimations. The story on the other hand can be quite dull, and feels kind of generic like you see it in lots of games.   Moreover, I'd like to commend the combat system - it's well made and really fun but it just doesn't suit a Tomb Raider game! While I praise the fantastic graphics and it's very good optimisation, it feels rushed and it's horribly overrated. I hate to say it but please do not pay attention to the 'Overwhelmingly Positive' review score this has.   GRINDING - A LOT OF IT. Salvage is one of the key ingredients to upgrading your weaponry, and you will find yourself grinding for it a lot. Killing absolutley tons of waves of enemies in the process and it just feels so repetitive. It is extremely boring as you carry on throughout the game.   MULTIPLAYER - 'Footage not found', pretty much.   My advice would be to avoid this game and play the proper, classic Tomb Raider games from good old times - they are much more worth your time.   6/10 - such a dissapointment.

Tomb Raider game allows the player to discover how the main character of the famous game series Lara Croft changed from a student dreaming of discoveries and adventures to an actual badass tomb raider. At the beginning of the game, the boat in which Lara and her team/friends are travelling capsizes and Lara ends up on a mysterious, hostile island, where the survivors are hunted down by the island inhabitants. In the game, Lara will attempt to find and rescue her team and to discover the terrible secrets of the island.   As Lara goes forward in her quest to make it out alive with her friends, she will get new weapons and new skills. She can also collect materials in order to upgrade her weapons (which are pretty powerful in the end). I really liked the fighting in this game, it can be pretty intense sometimes. As it's a Tomb Raider game, the player will also need to use their brains a little to be able to reach the next area from time to time.  +/-  + well-written story + beautiful game (not amazing by today's standards, but it looks good) + good gameplay + love how the game shows the progression of Lara  + a lot of action, stunts, and fighting  - even in the hardest game mode, the game is not that challenging in my opinion  - I had a few bugs, like my character getting stucked for 30 seconds before magically getting unstucked. It didn't happen often, it didn't bother me.  - the game is short to complete. I'd say you can easily finish it in 10 hours if you don't really take your time to look around each zone.  I would like to add that the game also has a multiplayer mode that I haven't tried and I'm not interested in it. If it's good and if there are still active servers and players, it might add a lot of fun to the game.  Also, I read in some of the reviews that didn't recommend the game that it's because it's too linear compared to games such as Far Cry or Just Cause. Tomb Raider is definitely a linear game, so if you're looking for open world games you shouldn't buy it.   In the end, I would give this game 8.5/10. Tomb Raider is a must-have for any fan of the series or just a fan of action-adventure games.

The 'gritty reboot' is a total success. Strong female protagonist, great story, tons to do, challenging while still being accessible, great graphics.  They've somehow managed to maintain the spirit of the original Tomb Raider games and it makes this game rather unique, feeling distinctly different to other similar games. Definitely not an easy game, or for the squeamish, and it can be quite exhausting, as very intense sections appear regularly and can be utterly unforgiving. Be prepared to die, and die often ,,, and usually horribly.   Very strong game and holds up well throughout. There are small puzzles but they're nothing strenuous, they can be figured out fairly easily. They've added hunting which is interesting but doesn't really serve much purpose - if they'd gone the Far Cry route where you actually use the skins of the animals you kill, it would've made more sense.   The controls can make Lara look a bit jerky but it's a minor flaw. The climbing and jumping feels like pure Tomb Raider and work very well. It's easily the most fun part of the game. Combine with a bit of treasure hunting, history and collections.  The one serious problem with the game is that most achievements don't get recorded - I finished the entire game and ended up with 8 achievements of 50. From the forums, there are many, many people complaining about this. Extremely annoying.  All in all, very solid game and a pleasure to see a beloved franchise given a modern overhaul. If the quality is maintained, we've got a very successful new series on our hands.

First, I have played very little but this game is a significant disappointment. QTEs litter the play, of course it wouldn't be bad unless they were the worst version of a QTE (Quick Time Event). They use different buttons at different times, don't track to buttons that perform similar or the same actions during game play.  This is the worst kind of sloppy game design, driving by marketing dweebs and fools that cannot allow a player to make a choice. You are forced to play the exact path that the game designers want because regardless of what you try to do ... guesss what? You wind up in the exact same virtural cut scene with yet the next sequence of QTE to waste your time in. I stopped playing because I got to shoot a guy in his crotch and he still came at me as if I did nothing at all. Pathetic game designers relax, because your future is safe if this is the future of game design.

>Walk into a room all stealth-like >A group of enemies is in front of me; they don't see me >a gas pipe is conveniently throwing gas into all of their faces >I conveniently got my fire arrows back 3 minutes ago >I groan incredibly hard and let out a huge sigh  Man, I don't mean to sound like one of 'those' people but I just got done playing Doom and to go into a game whereby the ENTIRE experience can basically be summarized as one long cinematic is so awful. There are scenes in this game where woah holy sh*t everything is BEING DESTROYED AROUND ME LOOK AT ALL THE CHAOS all I gotta do is press forward on the control! Yeah it looks awesome and I loved it at first but after the fifth time I just rolled my eyes so hard. At a point I wondered what the difference would be between what I'm doing and just watching a Let's Play of the game. Because this thing might as well play itself at this point.   Just as the aforementioned room of explosive gas and enemies most areas you enter have everything set in a way that it might as well have been ANOTHER QTE. You are in a tunnel and crawl through it, and an enemy will always walk in front of you but not see you. The logical progression here is silently take him out, then take out his friend next to him on this small walkway where you have no option but to confront him, and then take cover behind this conveniently placed piece of cover on this small walkway and take out the enemies that are clearly in your line of sight whilst covering, proceed once they're dead to this QTE event where you press forward and ocassionally press the jump button as everything blows up around you. This isn't a game it's an ''interactive experience'' where even the shooting segments where you're actually playing the game feel like a QTE. That's amazing.  There was a point in the game where it started getting REAL good. This was somewhere around the mid point, where I find one of Lara's allies and am in a relatively large area with the task of getting to a waypoint. I felt like I was actually given a challenge and had to find a way to accomplish it. ''Ah, I can go here and then proceed this way''. Granted the solution was still just one, but giving me the space to FIND the solution rather than being given it makes a world of difference: you're still being linear in design but not in results and what the gamer is actually going through mentally. Allow me to fail; give me the space and vagueness to make me THINK and CONSIDER options. The solution can be one but give me the space to think of what it might be before you tell it to me cause having me stop and think is somehow an evil. Worry not cause the game defaults on QTE once again after that incredibly short section.  It's a shame; the game had a few glimmers of what could have been. Beyond the ''walk through small crevices really really really slowly'' sections, you had a few 'optional tombs'. Lara would monologue any pertinent information, and continue to do so as you explored it further. You walk in and find a way to get the treasure chest; simple but this is about as much puzzling this game will ever get. Too bad these tombs were short as hell and literally consisted of one puzzle each. One simple puzzle.  Then there was the Rambo feel I got at times: Lara making her way through the jungle alone with enemies looking for her. In the beginning you have to kill a deer for food; Lara is pensive but does what needs to be done. I was prepared for Rambo part 5. Nope; here's Lara's friends and people who's names you don't actually remember other than Sam and Roth (you know I'm right). We can't go down the internalized grief and silent suffering of a protagonist, gotta interrupt it with her friends coming on-screen every few seconds. Not caring for the storyline, which is typically VERY important in super linear games like these, is a HUGE detriment. I just didn't care about Bob or whatever the hell that dude who showed up for three minutes was. And it's not until now that I remembered there was that other explorer dude who was PRETTY IMPORTANT for 50 minutes. They're just not very interesting or, other than Sam, that vital to the storyline. Yet a lot of time is spent on them. It's really weird.  Anyway if you like Asura's Wrath but without an interesting plot or like QTE's in general and shaky cams that make your damn hurt (I'm not the only one) then this incredible game is up your alley. Otherwise stay clear; it's the WORST of modern gaming design. Which means an automatic overwhelmingly positive on the steam store.

I'm not sure how to sum this up, but this game makes me appreciate just how good Naughty Dog really is at making games. After playing the Uncharted series this game just feels really poor. The animations aren't as good, the dialog is terrible, and Laura's character is so poorly designed. She was fearless and badass as a kid, but somehow became super squeemish? Her reactions to everything are always the same, 'OMG NO! Okay I'll do it.' Over and over and over and over. It's really obnoxious. Then as soon as you find a tomb she's like 'YES, PARTY TIME!' Where did her apprehension go? Oh that's right... it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.  Don't even get me started on the bugs. I can't finish the first tomb because the animations freak out and Laura goes into this death tumble in the part of the plane fuselage you're supposed to climb. She just rolls and rolls and eventually goes back to that ledge I was hanging from. Over and over and over. It's awful.  The thing I find the most horrible? The quicktime events. Every time there is some fight, it's basically quick time events over and over. It's really terrible.  Graphically the game is nice, but if you're going to make a big fuss about this 'Tress FX' hair ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, then at least make sure the hair responds to gravity. In the FIRST SCENE, she's upside down and her pony tail is the right direction. The rest of that hair? Defying gravity like a boss. She must have some killer hair products.  Overall the game feels like it had lots of cool ideas, but then it was chopped up by publisher requirements and rushed out before it was ready. It's typical 'AAA gaming' these days. Only a few studios are really knocking solid releases out, and sadly this isn't one of them.  Overall I'd give this a 5/10. The gameplay is too repetitive, the story is awful, the character development is laughably bad, and overall the only thing I liked was some of the jungle designs. Those also felt very formulaic and very much a tunnel based level design.

Tomb Raider. When I think of a 'Tomb Raider' game, I think 1 thing over everything else. Puzzles.  When I play the new 'Tomb Raider,' I think 'Shooter.' There is not much else to the game other than that, it is mainly a duck-and-cover shooter with some puzzle elements to it. Don't get me wrong, I loved the new game, but it didn't really, to me, feel like a 'Tomb Raider' game.   The game looks absolutaly beautiful, especially when being used with a high-end graphics card. The story line is pretty alright, but can be a bit overdramatic when it comes to Lara and her 'survival instincts.' What's up with that anyway? she can somehow turn her wierd little sub-machine gun/assault rifle that she picks up from one of the islanders and then somehow turns it into an AK-47? and then from that into a 'Commando Rifle'? It doesn't make sense. And Lara must be some sort of wizard to be able to fall from the heights that she does, lands barely winded, and walks off fine. She must have all of her ribs cracked by now. I had a friend of mine only fall a metre and crack a rib!   But anyway, enough of the rant.   tl;dr: Overall, it's an amazing game, doesn't really feel like a 'Tomb Raider' though, looks good, and has some wierd magical powers of turning a homemade bow into a compound bow.  8.5/10

Tomb Raider is a fantastic reboot of the series. After the last few dissapointing games Lara is back and how! The game is nothing like the older games in the franchise the reboot is more like Uncharted so a bit of platforming, shooting, lots of cutscenes, awesome setpieces with lots of explosions and a terrific soundtrack. I personally enjoyed this game more then the older games because you don't get stuck on puzzles hours but don't get me wrong there are some puzzles in the game which are rather easy to figure out and that's fine by me since it keeps the pacing just right. With terrific graphics, great music, over the top set pieces and a story which tells us how a survivor, aka Lara Croft, is born this game is a must play for every action fan out there! I dare even go as far as to say Uncharted holds no candle to the Tomb Raider reboot. Highly reccomended! 8.5/10

Now, not to say I didn't enjoy this game to it's full extent, but this game frustrates me because it had the ability to be so good.  The first 1/2 of this game was probably the best game I've ever played. Puzzles were fun and not monotonous, combat was adrenaline rushing and upgrades meant something.  I feel as though the developers either rushed to get a finished product or just got lazy past the half-way mark. After about the Natural Gas Caves, the game got confusing, hard to follow- traversing the terrain became difficult, because enviroments were just mashed together and forced. Game mechanics such as the Grenade Launcher were put in without any need.   I feel as if the developers took their time and continued doing the game the way they started, this game would've been god-tier.   Also, the finale was just boring and weak. Not very grand.  The characters are easily hated and the majority of those you don't like meet a less-than-satifying end  I'm dissapointed.

Let's start with what's good about the game: -Lara is a better character than ever. She's pretty but she's not a bimbo, she actually has some clothes on, which is sadly rare in videogames nowadays. She's smart, but she's not the nerdy scientist cliché. She's courageous but she's not some kind of dumb female rambo. She's vulnerable without being the usual annoying damsel in distress. Overall she's a very likable character. - The environnements and overall graphics are pretty nice. - The writing is interesting, even though the storyline isn't anything special.  That being said, here's what I don't like about the game: - The gameplay is just downright terrible, Lara's control feels very clunky, there's QTE's all over the place, the combat mechanics are just horrible, the game allows you to take the stealth option only when it's not important to do so, otherwise it throws waves of dumb enemies at you.  - The camera does a lot of forcing its pre-determined angles on you. - The animations are among the worst i've seen, and for some reason, the other animations in this 'worst' category are also from Square Enix games. - A lot of Hitman Absolution assets have clearly been re-used in this game. And Absolution itself was already terrible.  Overall, it's enjoyable at times, but it would have been better off as a movie than as an actual game. And that's actually how the game feels, an interactive movie you actually have very little control over.

Tomb Raider unfortunately doesn't live up to the hype or praise.  It's extremely linear, the mouse and keyboard controls frequently fail to recognize what you want to do, while standing behind cover Lara will often outright refuse to shoot to one side or the other and I've noticed numerous bugs and glitches.  Some of the bugs include being shot (while being unable to shoot through) various solid objects; from the floor to the ceiling and even various chest-high-walls - you can never know when the game engine will mess up and you'll be hit by a random bullet from a guy you can't even see.  Another big issue that I want to get off the list quickly is enemies spawning and de-spawning in plain sight. There's literally no excuse for an enemy to appear from thin air within melee distance from me in this day and age. It's unforgivable. As for enemies despawning within clear vision - well, it would've at least been nice if the game allowed me to loot them for salvage first.  Beyond that, it's a cover-based shooter with four guns, each with some additional fire modes, but those do nothing to alleviate the fact that you're using just four standard weapons for the entire game (and in numerous sequences, only one of those weapons - usually the starting one which is the bow. Bow, pistol, assault rifle (which doubles as a granade launcher) and shotgun. Nothing special or exciting.  Functional would have been the best way to describe it, but due to the aforementioned bug where Lara refuses to shoot to the particular side of certain cover objects I can't even say that.  There's 'exploration elements', which means there's a bunch of collectibles for you to find if you're intereseted. But there's no reason given for them. Old GPS caches, understandable. Old things (coins, toys, etc) - okay, Lara is supposed to be an archiologist, so that makes some kind of sense. But desacrating cairns? Shooting tribal symbols? Gathering redcap mushrooms? It doesn't make any sense, and it doesn't offer any special rewards (just more useless exp points).  The game includes stealth elements - both the bow and the pistol (once upgraded) can be used to silently kill enemies. But there's no reason to when you have regenerating health and ludicrous amounts of ammo. Also, as soon as a single enemy spots you, or a target you took out, the alarm will be raised and every single enemy will know your exact position immediately, regardless of distance or number of walls (and floors) between you.  There's parkour elements, but those are terrible due to being awfuly slow for the majority of the game and are further hindred by the fact that Lara sometimes decides to simply not obey your commands. And, to top all that off, they are laden with QTEs.  Speaking of QTEs, they're all over the game. Chase sequences, combat takedowns etc - you can't play for ten minutes without having to perform a bunch of the buggers.  As for the story... Well, it's linear, boring and stupid, and every single character you meet has a digital clock over their heads just to make it a part of Lara's supposed character arc.  The problem with that is that she doesn't have any; from the moment you start the game you're scoring headshots and setting fire or exploding enemies with impunity. Whenever Lara whimpers (which is pretty much all the time), cries or is unpset it just comes across as fake.  It doesn't help that almost every member of the crew she travels with is extremely unlikeable.  Lara is supposedly heroic, but in truth she's just declared as chew toy of the day. Every single person, animal and stationary object she sees (other than the aforementioned crew) is out for her blood and they'll stop at nothing - including suicide or self-destruction - to get a taste.  I know lots of people were impressed by the graphics, but to me they aren't anything special; neither the level design, nor the quality of the assets. I realize a good while has passed since the game's release, but that doesn't excuse textures as low as can be found in this game nor models as crude as are often used. This is at it's most obvious whenever you 'raid' a tomb (which, in this particular game, means solving a single puzzle with no combat or traps) at which you find a treasure chest at the end. When you open it, Lara will always gasp at the poorly textured and low-poly, ugly items within and marvel at oversized coins with a texture so pixelated that it's almost impossible not to join her.  Overall, it's just another soulless AAA title to add to the pile - just as I initially suspected (which is why I bought it this late). Couldn't recommend even if I wanted to. 4/10.

The most-requested issue to patch, the excessive camera bob/shake which makes many players --unable to play-- due to headache/nausea, was never addressed. Tomb Raider begs the question - how many times must Laura Croft nearly fall off a ledge before you press 'e'?  I've never played or bought a Tomb Raider game before - so I have no nostalgic memories to soften the rusty nails in this game (and there are many). Tomb Raider is a mediocre game ruined by Quicktime Events (QTE). Over and over again, after finishing a level you find yourself sitting back to watch a cutscene only to be killed because you must have your hands on the keyboard ready to press a button at any given moment. I suppose this tactic of distracting the player with pointless button-mashing tries to compensate for a cliche and boring story with cringe worthy dialogue even the above average voice actors can't pull off. 'You killed my BROTHER! NOW I'LL KILL YOU!!'...Yeah.   The story begins with you trapped on an island overcome by a hack director's shakey cam - where 1 by 1 Laura's friends must find themselves in situations that require their sacrifice to save her. Wah wah wah. Poor Laura, how hard it must be to lose flat uninspired characters we have no bond with. Laura herself of course is equally shallow, simply needing to be kept from falling off ledges. The whole narrative 'adventure' of this game is monotonous and repeatitive without intrique or humor. A 24page comic book could have more depth and imagination.  Unquestionably the standout pieces of the game are the environmental and level design - both second to none - which might make the game worthy of buying on sale for some who are curious. Unfortunately the tombs (puzzles) are rather few in number as they are one of the more engaging parts of the game. You'll notice at this point the controls neeed work as they still feel very controller based. The weapon system and upgrading is also another minor bright point in an otherwise unremarkable offering.   Ultimately Tomb Raider might be worthwhile if you find it on sale and are curious but you're not missing much if you decide to pass. A grand adventure game this is not.

This was my first real introduction to the Tomb Raider universe. I did, however, briefly play a playstation iteration of the series. I purchased the game as part of the Eidos Anthology pack, so I played with all DLC installed. I give this game a 4 or 5 stars:  Pros:  Good story:  Flows well.  Controls are smooth:  Saw no real clunkiness with climbing or jumping.   Moderately difficult collectables:  Easy to find if you look, doesn't feel like grinding.   Cons:  No real replayablity:  100% completed on first run, nothing new to entice a revisit.   I played through on Hard from the beginning. Large groups presented a challenge but the difficulty was still pretty casual. Gameplay drew me in for several hours at a time. At no point did it feel like a chore or grind. The only thing holding it back from a 5 of 5 star was the story. While I think the story was very good, it presented no significant plot twists or deep intrigue.

I bought this game during a very cheap sale. After playing through story mode, and looking back, I would have certainly paid more for this game. The gameplay really pulled me into the game. I got shivers when Lara was dangling by one hand to prevent a 1000ft drop to her death. I exclaimed during some the more gruesome kills. I gasped as Lara cleared a a ridiculously long jump over an endless chasm.  The game had great graphics, and fortunately I was able to keep on Ultra the whole time so the setting was beautiful (except for the piles of mutilated bodies, delapidated buildings, and various wreckage strew about the island). Although actual weapon variety is very limited, I never felt restricted, and always found myself coming back to the bow anyway, so I hardly missed having a full arsenal of weapons.   The story was gripping and like a good production should, wasn't afraid to let main characters die! This just pulled you even further into the game and brought a feeling of despair like you were actually there rather than just wathcing it from afar. Obviously much of what Lara does is impossible, but that's clearly beside the point.This game is fantastic and all of the absurb stunts it forces you to complete make it quite exciting. The puzzles and challenges in the game were thought inducing, but didn't make you struggle for 30 minutes to find the solution. They had the perfect amount of creativity and difficulty, making for a fun break from the raging violence!  Overall this game was very good, I have very few complaints, if any.

I have never played a Tomb Raider game (my only experience with this series is some gameplay on youtube and a couple demos) so my opinion is not based on how it compared to the originals. That said, this reboot of the classic series is great.   Tomb Raider is a very gritty and violent retelling of how Lara Croft became the treasure-hunting survivor we all know. Rather than being eye-candy or Nathan Drake with boobs they actually make Lara likeable and her character development was fantastic. Unfortunately I thought the rest of the characters were forgettable and by the end I couldn't even remember most of their names. The story is great and kept me interested but it wasn't anything to brag about.   The combat and platforming are both really fun and I liked the upgrading system. The puzzles on the other hand leave a lot to be desired. While there are some fun puzzles I wish they had been a bit more challenging. There are also hidden tombs you can explore to get extra supplies and plenty of other collectibles like artifacts and journals.   Despite some minor issues I enjoyed Tomb Raider and I definitely recommend it. I'm really looking forward to the sequel.

Probably one of the best storytelling-games available on the market. There are SO many things that other game makers can learn from the implementation of this game. From the first moment you start the game you can feel the physical pain that she's going through. You immediately have to run around in the wilderness, being chased by wolves and madmen. This is combined with having almost no skills or weapons apart from a bow with a few arrows. The sense of urgency is CONSTANTLY upon you and you always feel unsafe and uneasy. As the game progresses with gaining new weapons, skills and tools - so does the surroundings but more importantly, Lara's voice acting. Even the way she interacts with others and the way she talks to the enemies changes from 'Please! Don't hurt me!' in the beginning to 'BRING IT YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S!' by the end. Brilliant implementation and coming together of voice acting, interactivity (you can keep walking around even if there's an incoming radio call from your mates), cut scenes, voice acting, storytelling, level design, camera angles that show off the level design, did I say voice acting? Pure brilliance. 11/10 would pay to watch someone else play the game.

Tomb Raider is the kind of adventure story that makes me want to stay home and NEVER GO ON AN ADVENTURE EVER. That may sound negative, and it kind of is, but i don't mean that I didn't like it, I just mean that it's not a 'fun' adventure. ... That didn't sound good either...  This game is fun as a user experience, but for the characters in the story who don't get to pause mid-combat and make themselves a sandwich, it's completely miserable.  It's a dark story is what I'm saying.  I find that the gameplay is... mixed. I'm not the biggest fan of quick time events (but who is?) and there are quite a few of those. The y are by far the worst thing in this game, I don't think I've raged harder at a game than during the QTE in the wolf cave. (I HIT THE BLOODY BUTTON! HOW DID I STILL FAIL?) The combat, on the other hand, is a lot of fun. It gets repetitive in places, but for the most part I had a blast. Another high point is the puzzles, which struck that perfect balance between not too easy and not too hard. I appreciate a game that makes me feel smart. Then there's the traversal... I'm down the middle on this one. On the one hand shooting a rope arrow into a cliff side and sliding down it is exhilarating. On the other hand I feel like the environment being littered with obvious 'THIS IS A PLACE YOU CAN DO A THING' markers breaks my immersion slightly, but not as much as the auto-run.  Speaking of auto-run, Lara runs when she wants to and walks when she wants to. This isn't a problem usually, but there were a couple of times where I wished i could move more slowly, especially in the shantytown area.  Also, why is the melee attack a second tier skill you have to unlock? If I were Lara the second i got the climbing ax my first thought would be 'I can use this to hit people.' but no, you have to unlock enough other skills to get to the second tier before it even becomes an option. I feel like I'm being too critical at this point, let's move on to the story. I like it. Mostly.  The story goes that you (Lara Croft) are going on an expedition to find the lost civilization of Yamati, said to be located within the dragon's triangle. which is kinda like the Bermuda triangle, but Japanese. A storm causes your ship to crash on an island populated by a cult of other shipwreck survivors who believe that the storms are caused by the spirit of the sun queen Himiko, and that the only way to stop the storms is to sacrifice Your conveniently Asian friend Sam to the sun queen. So they capture her and most of your other friends, and it is up to you, the most bad-♥♥♥ innocent shipwreck victim in history to save them, find a way to stop the storms, and get home. I like this setup, and for the most part The execution is also well done. I only have two gripes about it. First: Lara kills a guy and is devastated. That's good, but then after that she suddenly becomes a remorseless killing machine. but everyone else has already harped on this point enough, so I'll move on. Second there are three cutscenes where Lara is in close proximity to The game's main antagonist Father Mathias, when he doesn't know she's there. SHOOT HIM! Just snipe him now and this will all be over much more quickly! Oh, you're not gonna do that? alrighty then... this would be excusable once but she has the opportunity three. different. times. if you need her not to kill him at least give a reason why she can't, like maybe she tries but her gun is out of ammo and by the time she reloads it's too late. I dunno. Something. All in all, I would compare this game to Disney's Hunchback of NotreDame, It's really good, but it has a few gargoyles you have to put up with. I give it a 7/10.

Awesome game! It'd be nice if it had more dungeons and puzzles like the early Tomb Raiders. Hopefully there will be more in the future. I like this iteration of Lara and it works to breakdown the back story about the Crofts.  I enjoyed this game.

This reboot of a classic series is my first experience with the franchise, so I came in with no bias, in addition to knowing little about how the game would be like. I will now proceed to give my thoughts on the various aspects of this game, rate them, and then combine the totals to give my overall score.   The Story  Lara Croft is part of an expedition to rediscover the lost Japanese kingdom of Yamatai, the Queen of which is apparently the ancestor of Lara's best friend. Upon nearing the suspected location of the island, an immense storm shreds the sea vessel, leaving the crew stranded on the island. It is quickly found that there are denizens on the island who shared a similar fate years ago, and they are hostile to Lara and company. It's up to Lara to save her friends, survive the wilderness, and uncover an ancient mystery and curse.  The story is easily this game's weakest aspect. Cliche and predicatble the whole way through, you'll solve the big mysteries early on and know exactly how a cutscene will play out a few seconds after it starts. Heck, you probably know what's going down just from the paragraph above. Not even one unexpected curveball to be found. As for the characters, Lara herself is very likable and acts realistically to what happens around her. I began to look forward to the next cutscene just to hear her piece out a mystery I already knew the solution to, or to speak to her friends. When she felt sad, I felt a bit sad as well, even though I didn't really care about what happened. The supporting cast have one-note personalities, but I did find two of them to be likable on a similar level to Lara, despite their comparative simplicity. The game's main villain has one single line of dialogue. Yeah. The game's secondary villain has quite a few more, and his backstory is relatable, but he seems evil for the sake of being evil, for no good/realistic reason.  Overall, I rate The Story 7.5/10. Not horrible, not great, but servicable.   The Gameplay  Picture Naughty Dog's  Uncharted , but with a good selection of qualities from the Metroidvania genre. I certainly didn't expect to find  that  element in this game! As the story progresses, you'll be trickle fed a bevy of upgrades that makes movement faster and easier, and allows you to access new nooks and crannies in old places. When you aren't monkeying around the semi-openworld levels in search of upgrade materials and backstory-rich books, you'll be gunning down enemies in smartly designed battlefields that keep each encounter fresh.  Stealth is certainly an option in a handful of parts in the game, using silent melee backstabs and the handy bow, but it's not a valid method of play for the majority of the game. You're forced into standard gunfights. The gun-wielding human enemies are far from bullet sponges (a common problem in the genre), going down after a reasonable amount of body shots, and dying outright from a single bullet to an unprotected head. The first half of the game, combat can feel somewhat unfulfilling. Enemies die just a little to fast to let you flex your impressive array of available moves and weapons, and you'll be wanting for more. Thankfully, the second half of the game delivers, when enemies start wearing armor that blocks bullets (It's a great, punchy feeling to shred off their armor with bullets!) and come at you in greater numbers. Unfortunately, just as the combat gets truly in its stride and you're lovin' the fast action, the game is already over. The obligatory 'final mook rush' before the final boss is the best fight in the game, and I would have loved to see more encounters like it.  The pacing is kept fresh by balancing a mix of exploration platforming, tense gunplay, and puzzle solving. No puzzle in the game is a true brain teaser stumper, but they do offer a repreive from the overwhelming action and they employ a satisfying physics element to them.  Almost everything you do and collect will give progress towards the next weapon upgrade and skill unlock. By the end of the game, Lara's a flippin' Terminator who wields guns that pretty much melt faces. Of course, you can opt out of the upgrades if you want a good challenge.  It should be noted that this game is somewhat quick-time-event heavy. The majority of scripted cutscenes have them, and they sometimes happen during platforming as well (usually only during high-action time-limit platforming). If you find them insufferable, it can be a problem.  Overall, I rate The Gameplay 9.5/10. I wish there was more of its best, and it left me eagerly looking forward to a sequel that can potentially refine and improve upon what's here.   Length and Replayability  On my blind playthrough, I endeavored to collect as many items as I could. I ended up completing the game with a 94% total, and it took me 10-12 hours. Not the best for the genre... The levels are quite open in appearance, but when you're solely progressing the story, you'll blitz through it all quite quickly. I imagine my time could be halved if I did so. Due to the linearity of the game and lack of ways to approach various situations, the replayability is very weak here. This isn't the sort of game where you'll be eager to have another go right after finishing. Instead, you'll be coming back a few months down the line when nothing else in your library seems attractive.  Overall, I rate The Length and Replayability 5/10. The slow-paced early hours aren't a big help, either.   Graphics, Quality, Glitches  I played this game on medium settings in order to maintain a high framerate on my computer. Even on medium, I found this game drop-dead-gorgeous! Every area has a heaping helping of eye candy, and they are all visually distinct from each other. One of the most beautiful 'realistic' games I have ever played. I'm sure my eyes would just flat out melt if I played on Ultra! As for quality, the game was consistantly 60FPS, even during the most hectic scenes involving particles, explosions, and large environments. It overall ran like a dream. An excellent PC port, it offers a very satisfying amount of options for graphics and keybindings, including gamepad support. I am exceedingly satisfied by the quality here.  As for glitches, I encountered two. The first was a game crash that forced me to restart my entire computer, but only made me lose 10 seconds of progress. The second was a progress-halting glitch in a PAID DLC AREA that prevented me from completing it. A google search determined that Square knows of this glitch, and offered no advice other than restarting the entire game and doing the area in a specific method. Let me make this clear... They haven't patched out a common, progress-destroying glitch in a TEN MINUTE LONG, THREE DOLLAR DLC AREA, in a whole year! That is scummy beyond belief. I encountered this glitch shortly before my game crash, and these two things happened early on, and the experience left me exceedingly mad, and almost made me quit playing.  Overall, I rate The Graphics, Quality, and Glitches 9.5/10. The two glitches I encountered where revolting and severe, but other than that, the game ran like a dream the whole way through. I can't disregard the quality of the whole crop because of two bad apples.   Overall Rating and Verdict  Story: 7.5/10 Gameplay: 9.5/10 Length and Replayability: 5/10 Graphics, Quality, Glitches: 9.5/10 Final Rating:  8  (7.8)  I would highly recommend this game if you're looking for an entertaining and cinematic action romp. It can scatch that Metroidvania itch, but not every well. Don't play for the story. Instead, savor the great gameplay, and look forward to the somewhat recently announced sequel!

I've pretty much just done the story (which took me about 9 hours) so far but there's tonnes of value to be had in addition to it. Puzzle tombs and collectibles and a multiplayer mode.  Since this game is on sale so often I see no exuse not to own this game as long as your computer can run it. One of the definite must play titles of recent years.

This game was a hard sell. It had a lot to prove to me and it carried with it the weight of a franchise. When I started it up, I was not impressed. Characters I couldn't care about, over use of cinematics, predictable sequences, and quick-time events everywhere. However... after the first 2 hours, they seem to disapear. Cover based shooting I never enjoy mainly to finiky positioning mechanics. But it works rather well here with a good control scheme and fluid movement animations. If I had any problems with it, it would have to be that many characters are still forgetable even till the end. And the game dosen't seam to flow well with it's tone and style, it looks like a survival game most of the time, then quickly moving into zones that look like they got pulled from 'The Evil WIthin'. But over all a fun game that is worth a 3 hour look.

The story is filled with thriller, suspense, and great characters. Graphics cannot get any better than they currently are at. It feels like your watching a movie some times. If you are a person who enjoys gaming and have the hardware to support it then i recommend Tomb Raider

Simply put, the exploration, combat, climbing, and all those super-scripted Uncharted style set pieces are a bunch of fun, but the story is sort of lacking. None of the characters have much personality aside from Lara, and the supposed emotional journey of Lara is sort of ignored by gameplay. The key moment to think of is this (spoilers ahead): Lara is nearly ♥♥♥♥♥ by a man, and after a struggle she kills him with his pistol and has a moment where she cries and looks at her hands in a sort of 'what sort of monster have I become' way. Then you return to normal gameplay, and you swiftly find that you get bonus points for headshots.

What can I say? I've just completed 'Tomb Raider' and I am compelled to share my thoughts!  Graphically the Game is gorgeous, beautiful Vista's, great character designs and fluid animation. I personally found the setting evocotive, with the very Island you find yourself stuck on taking an ominous charachter of its own, feeling almost overwhelmingly oppressive and creepy at times. The sinister presence almost put me in a mind of the omiprecent antagonist from 'Alan Wake', but perhaps thats an odd comparison.   Mechanically the same high praise can be applied, combat feels great, platforming and puzzles are challenging without being impossible and the progression system feels almost beleiveable given the context of Lara becoming 'The Tomb Raider' through rising to tremendous challenges.   The only thing mechanically I can complain about is all the Quick time Events (QTE), of which I feel there where a few to many. QTE's have a bad habbit of getting really old, really quickly if failed. nothing ruins the sense of urgency in an adreneline pumping action scene more than dying repeatedly to a failed QTE, I find it jarring and immersion breaking, but thats just me.   Lara's new, strong & beleivable incarnation makes for an engaging relatable charachter, a far cry from the juvenile, over-sexualised 1997-2008 incarnations that have put me off previous Tomb Raider Titles. Although its true that Lara does go from 'Innocent young Lady' to 'Mass Murderer' in the space of 15 minutes, we are talking about an action adventure game here, so I found it easy to suspend my disbelief.  Will I go back and 100% complete Tomb Raider? Probably not, but thats not necessarily a bad thing. At the end of the day I've gotten 9+ quality hours of escapism and and enjoyment out of this game, and It ended on a high note!   Would I would recomend? Wholeheartedly Yes.
Decent game with fine story. Excelent graphics. Recomended.

Halfway through the game, it's absolutely excellent, an example for what every AAA game should strive for. Haven't had this much fun since Warcraft 3 and Warhammer 40k: Space Marine.   After watching Yahtzee's review from Zero Punctuation it sounded like this was just another quicktime event extravaganza with mechanics that were one time use, but that review is dead, dead wrong in Yahtzee standards.  This game mixes excellent quicktime events with exploration AND tomb raiding (there's 6 or 7 major tombs, all with unique puzzles and art), as well as decent stealth mechanics and crisp, responsive combat.   The environments are varied and will make you go on a screenshot extravaganza, the story isn't some corny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it has hints and nods to past games and it's not cringeworthy or anything.   For every theme park driven zone you get a fully explorable at your own pace zone afterwards, this game just kicks major league ♥♥♥.  This is the best Tomb Raider I've played since the 90s, did not expect it to be nearly this good.  10/10, without a hint of doubt. It just keeps getting better and better.  Edit: finished the game, excellent reboot. I haven't played a game this good since Mass Effect 2.

Lara Croft...  I played the first Tomb Raider games back on the PSX as a young kid. Tomb Raider Chronicles was one of my favorites, Lara Croft running around in all her polygonal glory shooting two pistols at foes in exotic locations (and, of course, trying to look up pictures of the Nude Mod [that didn't actually exist].) I couldn't get enough of the series. When the movie came out with Angelina Jolie, as a young teenager, I fell in love with it, watched it far too many times and developed a celebrity crush on Ms Jolie.  And then the games slowly faded away into memory and I transitioned over more to the Devil May Cry series.  It was completely forgotten about, for all I knew.  Then, a year after the actual release of Tomb Raider (2013), I heard about it. I had no idea it was continued! I saw it on steam and my nostalgic feelings for the old series came back.  So I bought it.  And I played it. And played it.  Lara was young! Hot! Ambitious! And a hell of a character. The production value of this game is absolutely wonderful. The cut scenes that turn into gameplay are so well done they took me by surprise every time. The characters are interesting and well played out each with their own personalities and histories, and they keep it all the way through.  There are enough twists in the plot to make Twizzlers blush and to keep you hoooooked. Oh my god, so hooked.   I have heard there's a sequel in the works, but I have mixed feelings about it since this one is so good. Can they make it equally as good, or will they completely ♥♥♥♥ it up? This was so unexpectedly good, I'm not sure another one can compare.  But I'm going to hope. I'm going to hope to the end of the earth that there's another one and it'll be as good.   But until then, I'm going to keep playing this one.

This was actually the first game in my entire life to give me a headache and I seriously considered stop playing mid campaign. If you are a developer and have no idea how a steady cam works, please at least give us the option to turn the damn thing off.

8/10  Solid game, but not perfect. There are a few things that I find troublesome, but I will start with the pros. The mechanics are good, and combat is fun. The platforming is, as always in the Tomb Raider series, incredibly well made. You will feel like an adventurer of sorts playing this game. The story, although cliche, is fun and absorbing. However, there are a few problems.   The movement range and contralibility of Lara is rather low. There is no walking, or crouching, or going prone, or sneaking. Yes, you can 'sneak' kill an enemy, but it is easy to get spotted. It becomes frustrating. Also, the guns aren't too customizable. Enemies aren't too random, and there are no regular civilians on the island, so free travel can be a tad bland. However, if you play through the story and don't worry too much about the rest, you'll have a pretty good time.   One more thing; graphics. The graphics are very good in this game. I have an R9 280x (AMD, I know), and can run it on High-Ultra pretty well. Make sure your computer is prepared so it can experience the game in all its entirety.  Very good game, and would reccomend.

I got this on sale for $5. So I feel like I got a good deal. But lets be honest. The game is one long, continuous quick time event. Ratings for number geeks:  Story: 7/10 Graphics: 9/10 Gameplay: 6.5/10 Overall: 7.5/10  The story is interesting, but shallow. Same with the characters. I literally don't care whether they die or not. And you can't do anything to save them anyways. The gameplay is basically following prompts, basic platforming, and FPS. Sometimes it isn't clear where you are supposed to make your next platforming move, but most times the thing you want to get to glows like the sun(using MAGICALPERCEPTIONVISION). An unfortunate side effect of this is seeing areas, and 'interactables' that you cannot access without the correct weapon upgrade. Even if is doesn't make any physical sense. This should have been planned better. But I guess it's just another form of hand-holding.  Lara Croft Is fatally wounded at the beginning of the game, and continues on will-power alone so save the world, and her friends. She literally never eats, sleeps, or defacates. The seemingly fatal hole in her abdomen hinders her movement for all of thirty seconds. The rest of the time she holds onto it like an old sports injury, but only at idle. A sense of reality, or physics, is a hinderance when playing this game. Especially when crafting.  Most of the time, the game is good at hand-holding, but challenge/side quest items are intentionally placed in the most annoying places imaginable. Or are nearly invisible unless you intentionally scan dark corners using the zoom-in button.   My complants aside, the game is pretty fun if you can stop ignoring the minor issues. Nothing is really broken(How many games can you say that about these days?). It looks great, attention to ghaphical detail was incredibly high, and the perks and weapons are fun to play with. And you honestly want to progress through the story to see what happens next. If it's on sale, pick it up.
