Tomb Raider - Overall 6.5 out 10. A play through movie with a bit of camping  The graphics , music and realism of character's in this movie game are great. On one hand this is one of the best 3rd person adventure games, and the other hand; a really bad button mashing game between cut scene's.   WARNING : There is a scene early in game where you will be forsed to watch Lara being forsefully felt up, you can not skip, gives you 2 seconds to try to work out what to do, 4 or 5 times, if you get one button wrong, repeat again and again. Honestly the frustration of stupid button mashing with such a sensitive scene, ruined the whole mood of the game for me personally.  Once you get passed that you can camp up, kill animals, level up, go treasure hunting, some interesting and historic artifacts, and more. Lap it up plenty more cut scene's to go.  The main aim of the game (apart from trying to make it a shoot em up, survival game) Is to set up Lara Croft's origins as a young woman turning into the great treasure hunter. Which in one sense they do a great job if you see the game for what it is ... A play through movie with a bit of camping. Was very impressed with the detail of character's, lighting voice acting and smooth game play.  True fans of Tomb Raider may not like the new direction they were going with this game, but if your new or not really a fan of Tomb raider, It may surprise you.  PRO's = Graphic's , gameplay, music, lighting, charaters = 8.5 MID GROUND = Storyline = 5.5 (It's there but something feels like it's missing) CON's = Too much button mashing between cut scene's.

Very enjoyable, cinematic game. The game itself is violent and mature, with a reasonable story that is well told.  I would not say it is very difficult - hard was not a particular challenge, but I am pleased with the experience overall. It also relies on the same mechanics a bit much - you spend a lot of time travelling by rope in this game, for instance.  Overall, this game is an easy recommendation - the production quality is excellent, the game is fun and engaging, and it's a pretty good value.

I've read a few negative reviews about this game and I really can't agree. I grew up playing Tomb Raider, but I haven't played in a while and this game certainly got me into it again. The storyline isn't too deep, but it's not bad either and it was good enough to get me invested. The characters are well portrayed and believable. The gameplay was was a little rocky at first and to me, the sensitivity was a little off at times. It took me longer than usual to get used to it, but after a while the game ran smoothly and I could really immerse into the story. Once that happened, I was hooked. I loved the design of the landscape and the environment and even though there may have been a lack of details, it didn't do anything to hurt the overall impression. aonly negative point I have to make is the very directive gameplay. Tomb Raider used to be tricky, clever and hard to to crack. This one makes it nearly impossible to go wrong. They're no more trying and failing and trying again because the path is too obvious and the options basically non-existant.  But still, I can whole heartedly recommend this game!

A damn good game that is worth the play through.   Initially I thought this would be a simple Uncharted rip-off that purely sell off of the greatness that once was the tomb raider series but within the first 10 minutes of playing....I knew I was wrong! The game is so much more than a cheap copy and seems to combine so many effective game mechanics together in wjat can only be considered a near perfect game.  Also worth mentioning is that the graphics are, to put it simply, incredible. They really set the bar high for what games can and should look like today. Combined with the excellent animation effects, the visuals stand out as a massive positive for the game.  One negative however is that the game is riddled with quicktime events. I hope their usage will be toned down for the sequel as they get annoying fast, seeming out of place in such an fresh game.  Another is the multiplayer mode. It's not worth your time or effort playing feeling completly unnecessary and tacked on. If you are considering getting this game for the multiplayer you are wasting your time, it's the single player experience where this game truly stands above the rest.  Overall, definitly worth playing through. A very well made game that truly has revived the Lara Croft series for the better.

And though it encourages you to go back and revisit areas, I think you could do just fine whatever way you decide to play it.  If you like an action game with a touch of RPG then I think you'll enjoy this game. And at the sale price, you can't go wrong. The value of action/excitement and hours of gameplay at that price really make a garanteed winner.

But the graphics and the puzzle factor kept my enthusiam otherwise I might not have given it a chance. However! After the initial 'tutorial' I was surprised! I loved the whole crafting/hunting after coming from a Skyrim, the system gave into my OCD of having to find and collect everything, and I had to retry many 'cutscenes' because I failed to press the buttons in sequence and time which actually kept me on the edge of my seat instead of an old couchpotato button bash..   Lookin back on my experience, the fears I had of linear progression were somehow distracted giving me a sence of openworld and being able to choose my battles, however once a battles complete it seems thats it for the area apart from the occasional wild boar that randomly stumbles into u (not fast travelled back yet so lets hope the developers will surprised me with some bandit camps). One thing I missed from the old game was the dual wielding guns (no pun intended?!) and the T-Rex, that shock of OMFG what was that. But I'm looking forward to the sequel/prequel of this nonetheless. The gameplay (minus the useless QTE's which means ignore a couple boss fights outright) is decent and the overall idea of surviving on a island of trapped psychotics while trying to solve an ancient mystery in time to escape and save friends is generally solid. The major issue I have is storyline, plot holes (to me it was a plothole) and how they whittle away at the survival tone from the first five minutes.  It all boils down to the sharp bone/stick that forms the largest and most ghastly plot hole. If you are in a jungle and have an open wound, infection is practically assured. And yet Lara manages to shrug off this potentially mortal wound (scant inches from her kidney and the vascular system that feeds it) wading through blood filled cave water and yes even an open latrine for an improptu cliff city of psychotics. Still no infection or even the slightest concern for the wound that should be killing her. After getting medical supplies to help a friend with a broken leg, Lara places no priority on cleaning the wound even.  Round Up Time: can't get into the games other enjoyable features because I have basic first aid training and can't get over how a game using the phrase 'a survivor is born' can get away with ignoring basic survival priorities. Food yes, parts to fix gun yes, but basic common sense and medical intelligence NONE.

Tomb Raider's never particularly been a series that I enjoyed. From my youth, I can recall people fawning over Eidos/Crystal Dynamic's creation as she swam through tombs, punched sharks in the face, and I presumably interacted with pre-rendered backgrounds.   Regardless of any connection to the former games, the 2013 remake of Tomb Raider is an incredible adventure in its own right. Setting the stage for Lara Croft, it acts very much as the birth of the character. Throughout the game, you will feel yourself pushed by nature until finally, Lara starts pushing back.  The environments are lush and relatively varied, especially considering that the entirety of the game is one geographic location. What becomes a game of hunting a few deer and defending yourself from feral wolves seems to effortlessly turn towards the Indiana Jones-style of blurred lines between myth and history.  The game has a high degree of reliance on two systems: its combat and climbing/navigation systems. I'll begin with the combat.   Like many adventure/action games these days, TR opts for a minimal HUD presentation, and players have access to (eventually) four weapons. Each of these weapons has its own alternate fire modes. Throughout the game, you are either granted or given additional tools or weapon upgrades; 'parts' for weapons are obtained in the numberous boxes hidden all over the island, so there's always something to upgrade. Combat feels relatively tight but not TOO tight: upon playing the game I was a bit confused by the lack of the standard lock-on function at least at the mid to close range to aid with dodging and counters. However, upon reflection, this is appropriate: Lara may have training, but she's no Kratos. The game feels much more interested in asking the players to use Lara's wits to survive rather than her brawn for many situations, and although I favored the bow in my playthrough, I found myself changing my ammo types and pulling out my other weapons with great regularity to match the challenge ahead of me.   There are some issues in combat, however. While the majority of the game is easily on the 'average gamer' difficulty, occasional situations can feel overwhelming, as enemy spawns appear linked to your movement. If you opt to mow down enemies while advancing forward, you can quickly find a pack of armored soldiers behind you. At least one encounter I died to, only to realize what was going on and upon slowing down it became much easier. This did somewhat bother me, as I felt like the game was dictating my pace, but it's not unforgivable. Additionally, at random times the heavy machine gunners will lock on you like they're 360noscopemlg420 and you'll find yourself eating dirt in less than 2 seconds from full health.  In addition, the Pistol feels like it's superfluous. Perhaps it's because mine lacked upgrades, but I pretty well threw it out the window. That being said, the moments where Lara finally realizes that she IS a badass and vocally lets it known are very appropriate in their timing in the combat and story.   The second system that it hinges on is its climbing and navigation. You have a small number of tools with a few uses. Long short short, you can climb rocks, grapple ropes on certain surfaces, etc. Lara's climbing got a solid 'A' from me solely because it avoids slowing down the pace of the game unlike the grunt-laden climbing in games like Assassin's Creed where it becomes a chore. Occasionally the game actually will integrate the navigation and combat elements and it's a delight.  While I feel like the story has a couple gaps; namely that it takes Lara far longer to understand the plot than it takes the player, they really don't detract from the overall enjoyment of the game itself. The game is also relatively short; you should be able to finish the entire game in a full day, 6-9 hours depending on how many of the ample side quests and collectibles you want to grab.   The biggest 'miss' I saw while playing is that the game really doesn't balance the hunting aspect very well. This is really stressed early on as you have to make a fire, find food, and so forth. However, and maybe this is to the benefit of the game, it's structured in such a way that you can ignore it once necessary.  All in all, Tomb Raider is a very solid entry into a saturated action-adventure field. It very successfully evokes feelings of desperation, sorrow, and downright sympathy from the player for the protagonist. You know the whole time that Lara will come out on top (especially if you're aware of the upcoming sequel), so there is no doubt that Ms. Croft will 'live', but the game piles so much misery and brutality from an unhospitable location that you begin to wonder if she can ever 'live well.'  8/10

Phenomenal game. Lara's development is handled with gravitas, though as always it's difficult to reconcile a story depicting the emotional development of a neophyte while not leaving the gameplay angst-filled, incompetent, and non-fun for the first stages of the game. In this task, they decided to opt for a disconnect between her emotional state during cutscenes and her gameplay, which can be jarring. But she is a capable protagonist, and while she receives help from time to time she rarely needs saving. The other characters are there to support her.  If you possibly can, ignore the hullabaloo surrounding the pre-release scandal and all the comments made by various producers regarding the game in general and certain controversial scenes. Most fears I had going into the game - that Lara would be infantalized, gratuitously sexualized, or demoted to a supporting role in her own game - were unfounded. On its own - the game is everything one should want in this regard.  Gameplay itself isn't perfect. Some quick-time events are annoying to deal with. One at the end of the game is completely mis-calibrated - I had to switch to a gamepad during that sequence to even have a hope of finishing it properly. Lots of the game's content amounts to near-meaningless achievement-hunting. Ammo is tight in a few early segments, but eventually becomes a complete non-issue.  There's lots of Tomb Raider platforming, but very little in terms of Tomb Raider puzzles. The only real puzzles are contained in the optional tombs that you can raid along the way, and each tomb only has one environmental puzzle - solve it and you get a perk or two and a zipline back to the start of the tomb. There was so much more potential there, wasted.  Since Tomb Raider came out the same year as Bioshock Infinite, and the two are both adventure shooters, it's natural to compare the two. Bioshock is better. It's not much better - Tomb Raider is very well done, but Bioshock has a bit more depth and a bit more of an immersive factor.  7/10

after 7 hours i found out i didn't like this game and that its a good game here is a looong list why 1) things i liked which you might not: - the game made me feel bad for a fictional character. maybe im a perv but the first time Lara had to ,slowly and painfully remove a metal rod from her pancreas i thought it was kind of hot, 7 hours later however i just want to give her a blanket and send her to a psychologist. this character gets traumatized, shot, hit, stabbed, beaten, etc (not including the various death cut-scenes) so many times it feels like the writers really hated her for some reason, i like that in works of fiction - the 'tomb raiding' was mostly optional and separate from the main story, so if climbing puzzles aren't your thing, well you don't have to go looking for treasures as much  2) things i didn't like which you might like: - 'cinematic experience'. the game is cut-scenesand QTE heavy. they are done well for the most part, but this is basically why tomb raider is not my type of game.  - the cinematic experience means the game is very linear. most of the levels don't just start at A and end in B letting you do what you want, they are roads you are put in. even tho there are some optional quests and hunting and crafting, almost everything is done in what are basically corridors ( kind of like fable1). it is cinematic but a bit boring for me and i stopped playing after 7 hours.  - too much shooting/bullet spongy and numerous enemies. most gamers probably like this but personally if i have to shoot something multiple times in the head or have to kill hundreds of people as an individual i feel cheated - too many (nitpicky) problems with the story. i wont say anything spoilery but one that isn't and really grinds my gears is the simple logistics of running an island of murderers cut off from the world loosing HUNDREDS of them in firefights with a terrified girl with ptsd and then still having the man power for more, how do they feed themselves how do they get enough ammo where do they get cloth from just wtf!. that said for most people will be too immersed to care or notice - upgrade and customization is not done well and the game would have been better without it  3) things probably everyone will like: - they really did a good job with the player model. sure she is made attractive for obvious reasons but it goes deeper then that. over the course of the game youll see the effects of wear and tear on Lara's equipment and her body. at the start of the game she looks like a normal happy person would, give it a couple of hours of story and she will be bloodied, dirty, brutally scarred and have a very determined but sad look on her face as she runs (or limps) around. in other words they did her physical transformation to an action heroine very well - i think the animations are (while not ground breaking) done very will - the voice acting is ( for the most part) great - the graphical fidelity and effects are AAA, not the best but still very good (2013) - the ai while not very innovative, was (for the most part) competant

My two cents on this installment of 'Tomb Raider'  They obviously tried to go for realism, which from the very beginning was undermined by the implausibility of damage Lara was taking in the narrative, as no one could survive that. There was also gigantic disconnect between cut scene actions and what the gameplay presented, that is never good way to present a GAME. Jumping bits were very much automated without any requirement of timing on the jump and the 'nearly made it' scripted QTE events reeked modernity, in the bad way.  Basically same issues as with nearly all new reboots and games. Gameplay sacrificed on the altar that worships cinema. Simplification with nothing added. Gameplay elements that are unecessary but create 'replayability' while the game actually provides none.  Meh game from start to end. I only hope the future installments take their gameplay cues from earliel games of the serie rather than what it was now.

Pros -The 3D models and the animations are amazing, the developer team really put effort into it -The story is deep and complex and if you don't skip the cutscenes you get to understand the history of the Island and how Lara manages to scape with her crew -The controls are incredible simple and easy to use, you don't need to change any key as all of the default controls are good -Plenty of content to find in the game and Steam achievements to unlock -The developer team thanks you for finishing the game in the credits... nice touch  Cons There is not really anything i can complain about the game, maybe it being too short, around 6 hours if you just go for main objectives and leave a second gameplay for side quest, tombs, relics, challenges, etc, but that's about it. Excellent game, much better than the previous games in the series due to much better, refined, controls, gameplay and visuals.  Praise has to be given to Rhianna Pratchett (Heavenly Sword, Overlord, Mirror's Edge, Viking) who's writing skills have been put to good use in helping to create a fantastic storyline.  I highly recommend this game, especially when there's a sale on as it's  OUTSTANDING  value for money.

nothing short of superb. Started playing tomb raider when it first came out many many years ago and always enjoyed them but this is a lesson in how to update a game franchise. loved the story, found it held my interest until the end. Loved the game, classic tomb raider gameplay but updated for next gen with all the graphical thrills you'd expect and demand. Forget ps4/x1, I played this at 1920 x 1200 @ 60fps with settings at ultra and it never dropped a frame. Loved the graphics, great set pieces. OK, some of it is a bit 'on rails' but just the right side of control - I always felt I was in control as opposed to just tapping buttons to avoid obstacles. Loved the combat too, good variety of weapons and liked the collection of loot in order to upgrade weapons.   and to top it all, I only paid about £6 for it !  (let's just hope Rise of the Tomb Raider is not an X1 exclusive)

I woke up. I am a woman. A pretty famous woman. I go on a nice boat trip to look for atrifacts. I get some back story. There is a storm, my boat goes down, I find the water rushing in and I am fighting for survival. I end up injured on land and fall. Racks are everywhere as I roll and push and try to survive. I move forward but someone is behind me. I run, panic, flee, and struggle to get their hands off of me. With a kick they get pushed back and a rock crushes them. I find a pcikaxe, a bow, and a shotgun. I no longer have time for their games, but I do have a lot of time to walk around searching bushes for items that end up weighing hundreds of pounds and casually go on my way.   10/10 I had a surprising good time.

Incredible game, very fun to play, the graphics look good, the atmosphere is perfect and it is very easy to get into it. I had some minor problems regarding the play with a controller but it did not affect my overall experience with the game itself. The story seemed very interesting and well developed, just maybe not too in depth, but that is just my preference, I feel like the ending could have been wrapped up better, seems a bit rushed. It does appear slightly linear, and on games like this it is a feature that actually works pretty well, I could still feel like i have a lot of space to play around while not loosing myself to the vasness of the terrain, in times where a lot of games make you decide what to do, I find it refreshing that this game reflects on Lara's choices alone. The development of the character throughout the game is done with such a nice realistic feeling and getting to do more things as the game progresses helps it from becoming repetitive. Maybe my only flaw in this game would be the puzzles which were too easy and too predictable for me, it seemed too casual even on the hardest difficulty and I feel it is an element that could definetly spice up, not only the feel of the game but also the way you feel acomplished after completing such a difficult task. The combat system was well thought out and it was a lot of fun to figure out different weapons and use them to the fullest, the enemies gave me quite a bit of trouble, especially at the end but that is just the way I like it. I felt it was challenging enough, just maybe too predictable.  All in all a very enjoyable game, with an improved puzzle difficulty and a bit more of that element of surprise i feel it could go a long way.

First of all, i m not a Tomb Raider fan. I haven' t played any other games of the series and I got this one from the complete Square Enix - Eidos bundle, which I bought for the Thief, Hitman and Deus Ex series. Anyway since I already had it, I thought to give it a try. And I m very glad I did.   I mean this game has everything! Great graphics that run smoothly in my average laptop. Excellent voice acting, music and sound.Very good story and characters (despite the supernatural core). Clever level design and easy to understand puzzles that actual make sense. Character development and weapon customization. Some stealth elements, and finally, a in game hint system disguised as a ability that doesn't break immersion and saves a lot of dead time searching this or that hidden collectible. Absolutely spectacular.   I really wasn't all that into the old Tomb Raider games, but this game really blew me away. Reasons I liked it:  1. It has a great sense of pacing. You are getting new tools and upgrading existing stuff all the time. 2. It has the perfect difficulty curve. Never feels unfair but isnt way too easy either. 3. Fantastic sense of presentation all around. 4. (On ultra settings) Is the most gorgeous game I have ever played. Seriously. It is ridiculous.  - Gameplay-wise think Uncharted except instead of a combat/platforming ratio of 70/30 this game is more 40/60 and never gets ridiculous (amounts of enemies) like Uncharted. - Runs about 9-11 hours. No game+, but you can continue to collect stuff to 100% after it is over. Multiplayer is mostly throw away.

The game is a third person shooter with puzzle sections and all is very well mixed together. The climbing sections are fun and at some occasions pretty intense. You have four weapons in total with a lot of upgrades for each of them and I never felt like I needed more weapons than this (Well that's not entirely true, there were times I wished I had a bazooka but that was only beacuse you receive the underbarrel grenade launcher and the explosive arrows a bit later in the game.). Fighting your way out using CQC is also possible although when there are more than two enemies around you would be better off using a ranged weapon. The story wasn't something special, but Lara's character is really well written. The main theme of the game is surviving and it backs it up with a lot of sections where Lara's life is hanging by a thread and relying on your reflexes. When not in battle or climbing the game encourages scavenging for parts, hunting for XP and then building better weapons and improving your skills. It's a really good game.

This game is fantastic.  The graphics: Even though I 'only' played on high, the graphics of the game were fantastic. It blew my mind looking at the island and seeing lara.    the story: the story is really cool, and really weird. I did take some breaks, because I felt I needed a break of about a day, but after that, I pulled through.  Controls: Although the controls felt a little weird sometimes, I was generally able to get done what I wanted to get done. The game is a great mix between AC (of which I am a giant fan), Uncharted (from which I rushed through the 3rd part) all combined with an amazing main charcter.  To lara: she is such an amazing character, she is smart, courageous and not afraid to do what has to be done. (what i did find ironic was that she complained about having to kill people after massacreing loads of them, but that barely bothered me)  Most importantly: This game is a finished game. It is done. This is it, ok, there might be some additional features, but the game felt like it was done, like there was nothing that needed to be fixed or added *cough* the crew *cough* ubisoft *cough*.

Just a fantastic action/adventure game. It's definitely not like the old school Tomb Raider games but it never really tries to be and it's great at what it does. This game is intense and brutal. The storyline is very fun, but might lack replay value (unless you're trying to get all the achievements). Tomb Raider will literally keep your hands on the keyboard and mouse. After the first couple MINUTES of playing the game, I would expect something sudden to happen in a QTE (Quick Time Event) or something to pop out and try to kill me. THAT is how intense and suspenseful this game can be. However, the QTEs can be hard to see through all that's happening in game, so take a second or two to see what button you have to press. And the deaths that can happen to you are terrible. I saw some of them in a review, and I happened to do a lot of deaths that were brutal and painful to watch. I got crushed by rocks, impaled in the neck by a wooden spike, impaled in the belly from a tree branch, fell into water only to hit a spike and float off in a bloody mess, and get filled with bullets and/or arrows. The combat is enjoyable, and the stealth feels great when done right.   I personally did not enjoy the multiplayer that much. I didn't find very many things to enjoy about it. All that happened was spawn camping and trying to push out only to be killed by someone who is a higher level. If not getting shot with bullets or arrows, it's being blown up by a constant spam of grenades.  Singleplayer: 9/10 It's a great story with fun puzzles, combat, and exploration. But lacks the replay value to continue. Multiplayer: 4/10 It's alright, I personally didn't like it that much. But it keeps the fun combat I guess.

Excellent game, even better than the older Tomb Raiders in my opinion, and for me that's really saying something! Great graphics (although for me that's not necessarily the most important thing) solid, intuitive game play mechanics, and most important (for me at least) it has a great story. I really feel like the developers did a great job of staying true to the essence of what Tomb Raider is, there are no shortage of puzzles to solve or tombs to explore in this game. There are also plenty of artifacts/relics to find, and Laura always has something to say about each one, which I thought was a nice touch. This is yet another survival game that has you using a bow (which is arguably Laura's most important weapon) and hunting for food-- although the hunting aspect isn't a huge part of the game. In a sense though, Tomb Raider has always been somewhat of a survival game, even before it was the trendy/cool thing to do to give the players a bow and arrows and add a hunting mechanic to every game the old Tomb Raider games still made you conserve your ammo and gear such as flares for example, and you still had to fend off/watch out for dangerous animals. For the next game I'd like to see the iconic dual pistols make a comeback, there was a moment at the end of this game that made it seem like that will be the case, but it could go either way. I also hope that the 'exclusive to X-Box' release is only temporary with a timed release for PC and PS4-- that is the way 'exclusive releases' usually go these days, so let's all hope that is the case here.

Tomb Raider is an excellent game and a successful reboot to the franchise. The combat is smooth, exploring is fun and as soon as you see the credits, you will instantlywant to press 'New Save'. The OSX port for Tomb Raider is basically identical to the Windows version, with the controls feeling fluid. The options are also identical, so if you have a really powerful Mac (don't know why you have one if you play on Steam), you can tweak everything to the max.  Tomb Raider is a masterpiece of a game. The experience is very captivating. Deserves a 10/10.

I was never into the Tomb Raider franchise. I think in large part it was because, growing up, my mother frowned upon the big-breasted, ♥♥♥-kicking, protagonist, Lara Croft. 'Too crass and sexual.' Being an adult now, and finding this game at discount price at the Steam store, I decided to buy this game.  And I am so glad that I did.  This was my first high graphics game with my new computer, and it made me so excited to have my new toy with the spectacular looking enviornments and characters.  I could not help myself but think of the Uncharted franchise, which I also think is above par, but I would argue that Tomb Raider is better primarily for one reason: maneuverability. The movement feels less scripted, while remaining cinematic. Being able to jump like Lara, high and in whatever direction neccessary versus Nate's short, forward jump, makes a big difference for me.  Overall I would recommend this game to anyone and give it a 9/10 overall. One of my favorites ever.

I know this is an old game, but in case you're buying it to gear up for Rise of the Tomb Raider, here's a helpful review. Yes, this is the obligatory, gritty reboot of a classic franchise. But it's actually a good adventure game. Lara's on her first expedition and her lack of experience forms the emotional focal point of the story. She's forced to do a lot to survive, and mowing down waves of armed assailants to keep her friends from dying turns out to be a real drag. The storytelling and voice acting are on point, along with a soundtrack that lives up to the Square Enix name. The environments are what we might call “lush” (a word that never gets used outside of reviews), with plenty of action-packed set pieces to keep players interested. Several obstacles turn out to be cinematic sequences that involve things like escaping the path of a crashing airplane and scaling a treacherous mountainside. They’re a lot of fun, even if they do feel terribly “Triple-A”. A lot of detail went into creating Lara’s character. The ways she interacts with her environment and changes over the course of the game add to the immersion. Combat is important here, and it’s pretty solid. Lara controls well and enemies feel more human than the average NPC. My complaints are few, but significant. Firstly, Tomb Raider has always been about visiting exotic locales. While this installment definitely tries to incorporate the fantasy elements the series is known for, Lara’s expedition only covers one island in the Sea of Japan. There isn’t much to see in the way of landmarks (e.g. the pyramids, Area 51, Atlantis, etc.). Everything feels authentically Japanese, but not very awe-inspiring. As far as actual tombs go (Tomb Raider should be about tombs, right?) there aren’t very many. Most are little caves tucked into the environment that require players to solve a single puzzle. What does Lara get when she excavates a tomb? A pile of scrap materials she can use to upgrade her guns. It’s underwhelming. Exploration and platforming have been replaced by shooting and action sequences. It’s still a great game, but fans of Lara Croft might wonder how they stumbled into the Uncharted franchise while expecting something different. 8/10.

This is easily one of the best single player gaming experiences I've had in the past couple years. It's so nice to see a development team that seems to care about the final product they are producing. This game was crafted with love and it shows. The gameplay was never boring. Lara's movement is so fluid and the action was always the right amount of challenge. The puzzles were never frustrating to the point of wanting to give up. Still one of the best looking PC games out there and it runs well on modest rigs. Never had a single crash and only encountered a single noticeable bug the entire game. I can't recommend this game highly enough and I am sorry that I waited as long as I did to play it.

I absolutely love this game.  There. If you're looking for anything but gushing praise, you know to look elsewhere. Anyway - onward to glory.  Also, let me get this out of the way: the graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is solid, the crafting is fun, the environments are almost unilaterally epic, the story is fantastic, the supernatural element is downright rad, and the story is GREAT. Also, DAT HAIR. Now - onto why I really like the game.  I never liked the old Tomb Raider games. All my friends used to play them when we were kids, though honestly I think that was for the same reason anybody played Tomb Raider: the bewwwwbs. Hooray for fapping to early 3D pixels. And before we go on, a little about me: I like women. A lot. I like them better than men because, I'll be honest, I'm not much of a guy. I'm not macho. I only ever played soccer and ran track, and that was only for a little bit in my early scholastic career. I'm a skinny little romantic who writes fantasy novels and spends a lot of time daydreaming about being...well, basically anywhere else. Hmm. Think I got sidetracked.  Women. I love women. Specifically, strong women. I'm no social justice warrior, crusading around the internet to right the wrongs perpetrated against the feminine species; rather, I like my women to be smart, I like them to be strong, and I like them to be take-charge individuals. Bonus points if they're physically strong.  The new Lara Croft now shares the pedestal of My All-Time Favorite Video Game Protagonist with the late, great Commander Shepard. Why? Because she's the only female protagonist I've ever played who I've felt was more than bewbs and an a*s with dialogue. I'm sure I've played another one somewhere along the way, but for the life of me I can't think of any right now. So: what did they do to Lara?  First, they made her a newbie. You get to experience Lara's growth into the eponymous Tomb Raider right alongside her, and that's awesome. She goes from being a naive archaeologist, to a traumatized survivor, to a hardened hero.   Second, they gave her breast reduction surgery. I know, I know. WHAT?! That's horrible! They ruined the character and blerbedy blerbedy bler. This might seem strange, but I personally prefer women to look...well...real. Lara is still inhumanly beautiful, that is for damned sure. But the focus this time around is not on her sex appeal - that's a secondary character aspect. The focus now is on Lara the person, not Lara the body. I love it.  Third, the took away her sl*tty wardrobe. She still wears the tanktop, and toward the end of the game her pants start to show hints of the shorts she wore in most of her past games, but that's it. And honestly, the tanktop is completely reasonable. I know tons of girls who wear tanktops. It's a thing. Lots of them show their bewbs. Lara spends this game shipwrecked, with the tanktop being the last thing she was wearing before being stranded. It makes sense. It isn't there because HAI GUISE BEWBZ. And, let's be honest, if they'd done away with the tanktop in the first game in the reboot series, guys everywhere would have flipped their sh*t, because most of us think with our d*cks.   Fourth, they gave her an INCREDIBLE voice actress. I've never seen Camilla Luddington in anything else before, which is a tragedy. All of the VA work in this game is top-notch, but Luddington's especially stands out. Talk about breathing life into a character. I hope she gets more work outside of the TR games, because she deserves it.  And fifth, they made her capable. Lara spends the entire game just surviving in the face of ever-increasing odds. She starts off with almost nothing in the way of useful gear, and ends the game with a mishmash of homemade, MacGyvered tools and weapons that wouldn't be out of place four or five years into a zombie apocalypse. Not to mention - the girl takes a beating in this game. Honestly, I sometimes felt like I was watching a UFC fight where one person just continually got the sh*t kicked out of her but kept getting back up. Some (a lot) of the stuff that happens to her strains credibility (I don't think I'd be able to even function, much less climb cliffs and bare-knuckle fight bad guys after falling fifteen feet straight onto a rusty, old piece of rebar) but I think the message here is greater than the delivery: this Lara might not be a superheroine, but she's a tough scrapper whose determination against all odds is her defining character trait.  I don't think enough games have strong female leads, or honestly even secondary characters. They just don't. Bayonetta doesn't count, and neither does Quiet. And why not? In the now-immortal words of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, it's 2015. Why is this still not a thing? I don't want to play games, read books, or watch movies where men are the only real characters. It isn't realistic, it leaves me wanting more, and if I wanted to read about how awesome dudes are all the time I'd get a subscription to Maxim or Just For Men. Lara has scratched that itch for me like no other female character ever. She's on-par with the likes of Naomi Nagata and Sonmi-451, and I am immeasurably sad that Xbone fgts are playing Rise of the Tomb Raider while I'm not. I absolutely cannot wait for the sequel to this game. Infinity/10

Tomb Raider is my first Lara Croft Adventure since the old EIDOS days back in the 1990s and I really like it. The idea to rework the concept and character of Lara Croft has been overdue for a long time. The guys at Crystal Dynamics did a very good job in reinventing the female character of Lara Croft as a fragile but tough and definitely not lady-like young woman. It is nice to notice a development of her character throughout the game, from a fragile and frightened little girl into a strong and confident woman. I also like the new weaponing and skilling system, it makes the game more realistic. The story itself is good and made from the stuff that action-adventures a la Tomb Raider are made of. The fights are the best part of the game in my eyes because they come close to reality, especially the in-fights. The level design is a bit too colorless and monotonous, I get the idea of a dark and morbid world and the situation the characters are stuck in. But especially the Japanese/Buddhist ruins are colorful and shiny in reality and therefore should have been depicted as such. The only colors you get are those from blood and explosions and this is simply not enough. What I absolutely don't like is the concept of mindless button mashing and randomly pressing buttons in slow motion sequences. Simply because it is outdated since the 1980s and has never been fun and adequate. If you want to emphasize the struggling of the protagonist you could have come up with combo moves or in case of the PC version include the mouse for once. What I also miss from the old games is that you play at different places all over the world. The story they came up with may only work for a single location but I hope that the guys at Crystal Dynamics come up with a multi-location setting in future games.  I finished the game in 11.5 hours with a total completion rate of 70% at a normal difficulty. In my eyes that's a little too short. You are more driven by the story and your missions, rather than Lara's actual natural behavior: relic and treasure hunting. Don't get me wrong there is absolutely nothing to complain about following the storyline, but here the act of 'tomb raiding' only looks like a nice mini-game for in between when you accidently stumble across a tomb entrance. And that's the kind of sad part, because once you have finished the game you got no intention to complete the remaining xx % or even the motiavation to play it again soon. It was fun while it lasted, but now this chapter is over. Tomb Raider is a fine piece of game: thoughtfully concepted (but not as thoughtfully created) with a love for details and fun. But nothing more.

This game is pretty cool actually. I've only played for a few hours but I will certainly complete this game. Now, I chose to get it on PC rather than ps3 because of the Christmas sale. This game will run on some fairly decent gaming PC's as well. There are many tweaks you can do to make the game run smoothly. All in all, I would give this game an 8/10

Game: Tomb Raider Genre: Adventure, Action, Epic  I bought this game during the exploration sale last year. It was a game of a series I would like to play and it was able to run on my non-gaming laptop in good graphics quality so I thought: Why don´t you just buy this game? And so I did.  After beginning several other games I haven´t played yet I was fascinated by detail, story and the amount of adventure in it and decided to concentrate on this game. As a passionated Assassins Creed player I found many similarities to the game in terms of character movement, which I accepted with pleasure. The thing that I found the most indicating for a good game ist the difficulty of the game itself. That means you are not being killed by a couple of shot nor are able to run into bullets with almost no damage. You have to take a look at your surroundings plan alternate escape routes and find cover and ammunition, which is scatteres across the area quite generously (but that is ok since there are no ammo shops). I never had the feeling to be bored of walking around or shooting my way through tons of enemies. The upgrade system of your weapon arsenal is huge and matches everyones wishes (e.g. silencer, flammable bullets).  I think this game deserves its respect due to the balance of gameplay and attraction of continuing exploring the whole island even after the end of the game. 10/10 would play again and again

Tomb Raider (2013) is like Star Trek (2009). It is a reboot. Unlike Star Trek, they didn't do some convoluted time warp to change history and cause Lara Croft's life to play out differently than before. They simply gave the character and series 'universe' a complete restart.  If you haven't played any of the previous Tomb Raider titles, this is a good one to get into the franchise with. You'll be on par with Lara: experiencing it for the first time.  I described the game to my daughter as a 3D platformer. Not a platformer like Mario Brothers but rather 360 movement with obstacles requring jumping, climbing and even zip lining. Its not a true open world or sandbox game. But the story will stay on hold if you want to run around and complete any of the side challenges or look for the 'hidden' objects. You can even go back to previous zones using a fast travel system at each base camp.  Puzzles required to progress through an area can be challenging. But once you know what you need to do, its just a matter of getting the timing down.  There are some bosses which enter the area to fight with a short cutscene that can't be taken down with just any old weapon. These require you to pay attention to what hurts them and get them knocked down into a weakend state (denoted by a red exclaimation mark that appears), then run in to do a series of finishing moves which require you to press the displayed key at the exact moment.  Those are really my only gripes about the game. Difficult puzzles and difficult bosses. But if that is all I have to complain about, it just means that I need more practice.  If you haven't played it, get it and give it try. Especially if you can get it on sale.

Every steam sale, it's cheaper than a fast food meal so there's really no excuse.  Also if you're reading this when Rise off the Tomb Raider is out on PC and aren't sure if you need to play this one first. Just play this first, it's so often heavily discounted that you can get a good feel of whar RotTR has to offer for a tiny price.

This is a very straightforward, very linear, very, very fun adventure / action game. You start right in the middle of an action cut scene, and it goes straight into the game world from there.   The graphics are quite nice, the sound is quality. There are a large number of collectibles, some of which require coming back to an area after acquiring appropriate equipment. The controls are not complicated, and in fact are quite intuitive. The puzzles and tombs are... puzzling, I guess is the obvious word, but not exactly complex.   I very much appreciate that the time from clicking the icon on my desktop to being in-game, as Lara Croft, ready to play, is less than 20 or 25 seconds. I don't have a stellar rig by any means, and this loads up fast. And only one splash screen before the 'Continue from last save' screen, which is unusual.  Also, I tend to have to grab gameplay in short bites, 15 minutes to a half-hour at times, and this game suits that very well. I can boot it up (quickly, as stated), and actually push forward in the story in that limited time.  This was a great follow-up for me from Fallout 4 - I wanted an escapist, non-heavy game, and this delivered well.

What a return to form this game was! Once I'd realised that the default refresh rate was for some reason set to 24hz it ran very nicely at 60fps and on highest graphics settings so looked tremendous. I had purchased some of the DLC only to realise that the extra guns are for multiplayer. I feel a bit cheesed off that this wasn't very obvious but oh well.. The weapons in the game are pretty great. They don't level up very equally... I ended up getting the exploding grenade arrows very near the end, at which point they were pretty redundant. Stealth fighting isn't supported all that well, the game forces you to fight from cover against numbers so the bow soon becomes more of a useful tool than a weapon of much worth, considering the time spent upgrading it! They could possibly learn a thing or two about different combat styles by playing 'Thief' and 'Dishonoured'.  The 'mash button like an idiot' or 'dodge things you can't see' sequences are thankfully few and far between, there are a few times where you just feel they might have swapped them for some puzzles as in the original games rather than having to time reactions to things without adequate warning. Those are my only issues with it... I wish the game was significantly longer, and that's how you know a game is good. After 33 hours in game to be begging for more (such as perhaps an extended mission getting all your loot back to Croft manor fighting against modern pirates and other treasure hunters on the island a month later perhaps) shows that this is truly a Tomb Raider game worth getting. I wish her boobs were bigger. What? Come on, she's famously got large glands! I'm not suggesting DOA style breast jiggle... Although... Ok Ok.

Angelina Jolie made me dislike Lara Croft. I had no desire to learn more about the character because I saw her as hollywood portrayed her, a sex object. And as a young girl at the time I didn't like the idea of what should have been a strong female character being dressed in skimpy clothing (I still don't). However this game has changed my opinion on Lara. They've revamped her wardrobe. Made her dress more appropriate (for the most part -who doesn't wear a jacket on a boat?) This is who Lara Croft should always have been. And now in my mind always will be.  This is the first ever Tomb Raider game I've played. And I have to say I'm absolutely impressed. The graphics are great and the story holds up.   Game play isn't clunky at all and the controls make sense. Although I wish I could have been able to remap some of the controls for my controller however I got used to it.  What really impressed me was with regards to the subtitles. I know, who cares about the subtitles? I play most of my video games in the middle of the night, and I can't play my games too loud or else I will disturb the people I live with. So I rely on subtitles to fill in the blanks of the things I can't otherwise hear. Most games focus only on what is said, this game gave full on subtitles that included ambient noise as well.   Lara Croft, the female Indiana Jones.  Buy it now.

It was good game for what it is but it in the end it was underwhelming... although I would recommend people try it for themselves. It doesn't retain much about the franchise apart from Lara who I liked. It could be called anything else. It’s not a TR game.  Ludonarrative dissonance is a fancy term that's often thrown around but I found it particularly apt for describing the reboot. I couldn't help the longer I played it the more absurd I found it and I think it's because it wanted to come across as realistic that it's more farfetched 'gamey' elements stood out in a negative way where perhaps I would have glossed over them otherwise. Here are some of my gripes that stopped me loving the game, although again I'd say I did enjoy it overall:  - Lara is supposed to be fresh faced and her first kill is supposed to have impact which it does, for 10 seconds. She is obviously so harrowed by the experience that she can murder about 10 other people 2 minutes later without batting an eyelid and the game is about her downward spiral from innocence to full on psychopath. - There isn't any progress in Lara's skill, in real terms that is. Her weapon accuracy doesn't improve. She becomes better at melee kills at least but the game doesn't start you off completely ineffective, she's pretty much competent from the word go. I'd have preferred her struggle more and with each encounter slowly build her skill but this doesn't happen really. - Mastercraftswoman. The modifications to your weapons become increasingly farfetched for a supposedly grounded game. It's supposed to be an isolated island but the fact you can construct all these modifications from found / scrap metal is a little OTT. - Gun play and traversal is a little janky but at least the animations are well done and the game does look visually great. - Uncharted set pieces but with no pacing. This started off as a few great spectacles but eventually they just feel like they are being chucked at you for the sake of it. They don't have any build up and I did wonder on a few occasions why on earth everything Lara was near was just collapsing at this exact moment. It just felt more ridiculous than awesome. - It didn't have the courage to go toe to toe with the Uncharted series and I couldn't help be disappointed by that. Have some guts! It takes a lot of influence but doesn't want to be compared directly to it so I feel like a lot of the radical changes were put in place purely to prevent this comparison rather than for a real purpose. I feel like it created some strange hybrid. This is not an action adventure game like you'd assume TR to be. It's 1/3 Survival, 1/3 soft horror, and 1/3 shooter. Some sections felt more resident evil than TR. - the characters are boring; I couldn't care if they died or not. It wants you to care, have some emotional grounding but they could literally not even be there and it wouldn't affect my enjoyment of the game. - The ultra-violent deaths for Lara are notorious already and they were just off-putting personally. Not necessarily because they were violent but because they were just unnecessary. The lead developer must have a fetish for this stuff because I didn't feel like they added anything to the story. Remove them and it wouldn't have made the game worse. The npcs don't die in horrific ways but Lara does and the only real blood and guts are in the scenery rather than the game. It didn't go all out with the brutality to make it believable and knowing the franchise so well it felt strangely jarring and after a while I couldn't take it seriously at all like it trying too hard.  Uncharted is bowing out. I'd have loved TR to take the mantle back but it's not the direction this franchise seems to be taking. I'm not sure if I'm going to love RISE of the TR, I hope I do, but it's strikes me that it wants to be more of a shooter now than the rebooted TR / adventure game that I would have preferred.

This is by far the best of all the Tomb Raider games I have ever played. And even though its not perfect (but very close to), its fantastic. Its one of those games where you just keep playing no matter how many hours you have already played. You just have to try one more thing...  It has it all: A good story, Superb graphics, good sound effects and music and Laura look better and more sexy than ever (this is important). There is a lot of puzzel solving, FPS gameplay and a lot of jumping and crawling as we know Laura. This time much of the jumping is in the heights and so scary that it makes you jump in your chair many times.  What can be improved: Even though you can move Laura freely around in the world, its still a linear game. On each map Laura can move freely, but each map still has an entry and an exit you have to follow. This is not necessarily a bad thing bacause that also ensures that you have done everything needed to move on to the next map. No going back is needed (only if you want to do your 100% achivements, and for that they have made camps you freely can teleport between). Also some of the action (maybe 1 out of 10 times) are made as movie sequeces where your action is reduced to move left/right and jumping/shooting at the right moment. If you fail a sequence, the game has always been saved just before, so you have no worries. You can do them again and again untill you get them right. These sequences are often used to end some chapter with a nice cinematically presentation to move you further on in the story. Although simplistic in gameplay they are often very beautifully made and with tense action. You often discover that you were holding your breath during the sequence. There are also sidequests in the game, and although they are often just one single puzzle to solve, and not important for the game at all, you still feel a lot of joy and excitement just to have found the entrance to the sidequest.  Conclusion: The game has tons of hours of story, gathering plants, shooting and skinning animals, upgrading your weapons, finding GPS and boxes, bossfighting, shooting amulets and mines and so on. You really feel the enormous developing team behind this game. The game is huge, and have a very high quality. I don't think I ever encounted even a single error in this game. Buy it if you loved the previous Tomb Raider games, or if you like this type of game. Its among the best in its genre.

9/10 This game kept me interested, enthralled, excited, annoyed, and beyond stressed during the whole 10 hours-ish it took to complete (thought don't expect much of the achievements unless you have friends willing to help you out...)  The benefits include a fantastic new story line which aims at giving this reboot (1 of the 2) a new, more personalized, character while providing the standard 'tomb raiding' benefits. In similar regard, the graphics are quite fantastic and not excessively demanding on ones computer. My first run through of this game had the graphics all on low and it all worked, and looked, quite well. Since then, however, seeking those pesky achievements has never looked better. And in that regard, the negatives... Getting 100% achievement rate is next to impossible. You will need help to find some of the challenges, for one. Even then, some will take forever... The biggest downside, however, with this game is the multiplayer which is essentially non-existent. I feel the developers should have added a 'bot based' multiplayer option which would allow for 1 or 2 humans to have a good multiplayer game to get those other achievements. Or something, who knows...  Nevertheless! If you're a fan of story (it's somewhat half-life-esque in terms of 'do this, then this, oh then you need to do this! All while looking for these...'), shooting (the shooting system isn't 'ideal' in terms of responsiveness, but it definitely works), and seeing some totally unbelievable albeit really cool things. Then go no further...  For the price (5-10), it's basically playing a good novel.

Crystal Dynamics have done something that many people figured a developer could never accomplish, and that's make an legitimately compelling game out of the 'Rambo' movie license. John Rambo is one of America's most beloved action heroes, and it warms my heart that the creators of this video game, along with accomplished author Rhianna Pratchet, were finally able to give gamers the Rambo experience they, and the license, so richly deserves.   Of course, since publisher Square Enix was unable to finalize a deal with Lionsgate Films for the rights to the property, they instead decided to release the game under the title 'Tomb Raider' and replaced the character of John Rambo with a 21 year British woman named 'Laura Cruz'. Despite these alterations, this is still the Rambo you know and love!   So go ahead and buy a copy of RAMBO: Tomb Raider today! Or else.....HE'S COMIN' TO GET YOU!

Easily one of the best games in my library. Great combat, awesome level design and story. Lara's movement is fluid and natural. Was left wanting more when I've completed the story. In short: a nice game. Nothing groundbreaking, but it has its merits.  Immersive visuals, compelling (for the genre) story, and a trigger-happy bunch of enemies on an island that you can't really leave. Now where have we seen this before? Not that boring and lackluster TV series that just refuses to end season after season...  It is a pleasant challenge when most of your opponents can easily overpower you, at least, initially. Compared to Deus Ex, where you stay hidden because things are easier that way (but you can still take on a military bot and a few bad guys all by yourself if you choose), here stealth is the only way to survive. Unfortunately, this game does pretty much the same evil thing Assasin's Creed did - it introduces collector's trophies, which are not exactly relevant to the completion of the game.  Also, not sure about the rest of language packs, but the english one sounds... strange at best, when that dude is trying to either kill you or ♥♥♥♥ you... whatever. If you, authors, meant him to be russian or something, at least hire a decent actor that knows the bloody language next time! I know, 90% of games, let alone Hollywood movies, are made by people who think they can make do with someone who knows a guy that knows a language specialist, but the results are always miserable. A game of this 'class' ought to do better.  Anyway, that's about it for now, more might come later as I actually finish this game. It's still worth playing, after all.

This is a fantastic prequel to all of the previous Tomb Raider games. The entire game takes place on an island, and there are no levels, so you continue to explore new parts of the island as you unlock better gear and weapons. The exploration is rewarding, with lots of additional tombs, challenges, and collectibles to find. The plot gets a little silly towards the end, but it's not too different (in terms of ridiculousness) from any other installment in the series. Overall, it's an excellent AAA game, with many tense and exciting moments, solid combat, and it's a great new direction to see the Tomb Raider series evolve towards.

Anyways i digress... this game takes gameplay to the max managing to balance enough of the 3 core sectors. This game has only one flaw: You can't find anything wrong with it, no matter how hard you try. The graphics are stunning, even for an one-year-old game. The soundtrack is so immersive, rich and tense. Those two elements combined are responsible for putting the player right into Lara's shoes, feeling her anguish, fear and adrenaline, as she shifts from gulible and fragile archeologist to a brave survivor. You are garanteed some skipped heartbeats and hours of fun. The collectibles not only make sense but they also add depth to the main story, complementing it. None of the characters are shallow or without purpose, every little things adds to the other. The game physics and mechanics are interesting and not boring at all, they work pretty well and are quite complex actually, making the game neither hard nor easy, but very challenging, compeling and fulfilling. I always feel bad for paying lots of money on a game I don't fully enjoy. This time I feel bad as I bought this game on a sale and now see that it was surely underpayed. Made into my personal 2013 Top 3.

This was the biggest gaming surprise I’ve had in a while. I expected a lame rehash from a stale franchise. Instead, I’m happy to announce thatthat Tomb Raider is an incredibly fun and intense experience that has resurrected Lara Croft.  I played the original years ago and while it was fun at the time the formula got old quickly and I could not get interested in the sequels. It was roughly 90% intricate, drawn-out puzzles & platforming with 10% miserable combat sprinkled in. What they’ve done is rebalance the game mechanics so it focuses much more on combat (which is oh-so-fluid) and the puzzles & platforming are more of a side dish. I think this works because it keeps the game moving along.  For example, there are optional tombs you can raid, but they are very small areas with only one puzzle that won’t take you more than 10 minutes to solve. This is a little disappointing, I’ll admit. I would like to have a little more meat to the puzzles, but I will take the short ones over getting bogged down in a 45-minute labyrinth.  RPG elements have been introduced, as well. There is a lot of optional stuff you can do in this game which will yield experience to make Lara stronger through special skills as well as finding “salvage” which is used to improve your weapons in certain ways (more damage, less recoil, etc). Special journals can be found, too, which help to unravel the mystery of the island you’re on.  Another brilliant touch is how they’ve tweaked exploration. Each area has several sets of secrets to uncover but you don’t have to find them all before you move on (some will require items you don’t have yet, anyway). You discover campsites as you play and can fast travel between them. This lets you focus on having fun instead of feeling obligated to gut an area’s secrets right away to avoid a lengthy backtrack to an earlier area. It makes things so nice.  The game is gorgeous, too. Environments are beautiful & smartly designed so they feel very open with lots of nooks & crannies to peek in and usually multiple paths to traverse around obstacles.  As I mentioned earlier, combat is fluid and thrilling, the exact opposite of how it was in the original game. Head shots with fire arrows never get old, and the AI is smart. Ranged opponents will throw fire bombs to flush you out of cover or shoot guns at you while melee opponents will zip line in to close on you. And there are so many gratifying ways to kill them. Stick an arrow shaft through their neck with your hand at close range, dig your climbing axe into their back for a stealth kill, hit a guy right as he’s about to throw dynamite resulting in a friendly fire explosion, etc.  The story is very good, too. Games rarely make me want to play to find out what happens next anymore. Usually the story is something bland & serviceable to keep me level grinding. I really like the narrative in TR, though. Quite unrealistic, of course, but still enjoyable.  And if you’re concerned, keyboard & mouse controls work just fine. This is not one of those sloppy console ports that is unplayable w/out a gamepad.  The only knock I have against this game is the use of quick time events. QTEs are something I want to see go away and never come back. I am tired of the “press E to awesome” gameplay mechanic. However, Tomb Raider doesn’t rely too heavily on them and they are at least presented in a very dramatic way, so don’t listen to any commenters saying the game is nothing but cutscenes & QTEs. The beginning is admittedly slow and has a lot of them, but that’s because you haven’t gotten your weapons yet. Once you get armed, you encounter them a lot less. The QTEs don’t ruin the game and only end up being a very minor annoyance.  There is also the obligatory multiplayer mode that all video games are apparently required by law now to include. I don’t know anything about it and I will probably never play it. It’s an extra thing if you want it, but know that the single player campaign is not lacking at all.  If you like action games, you should definitely pick this one up. Tomb Raider had lost several steps over the years but is now running like a more polished version of Playstation’s Uncharted series, with better combat & storytelling. A very nice surprise that is worth your attention.

The finest Tomb Raider game since... well... ever.  The game does nothing new, nothing that has not been done before. It is clearly cribbing heavily from the Uncharted series of games to understand how to do the Tomb Raider format better than Tomb Raider has ever managed before, adding in an open world sandbox aspect, and replacing Nathan Drake with the person he originally replaced. The genius of the game design is not in being new or original though, but rather in taking those old mechanics and refining them to perfection.   However, more importantly than them getting the mechanics right, they got the story right. It draws you in, and drags you along. The quality of the writing is everything that you could hope for, and it pulls off the trick of feeling extremely cinematic, but doing so in a way that would never actually work in a movie. Rhianna Pratchett shows the deft touch of the consumate artist who is at the top of her game and understands the strengths of the medium she is working in, even as she plays with the tropes and clichés that would have sunk a lesser writer. To her credit, those very same tropes and clichés not only do not feel tired and over-used, but the fact that they would be so tired and over-used elsewhere actually plays in to setting the right tone and mood for this game. Like a true master, she takes what is death to other lesser artists, and makes beauty from what others would discard.

Reboot to the Tomb Raider series gives Lara Croft a graphical overhaul and a more action-orientated experience.  Firstly, the graphics, and Tomb Raider certainly does not disapoint. From the moment you are given control of Lara, staring out over the shipwrecked coast of the island of Yamatai, the lanscapes are completely stunning. This continues throughout the game, with a good variety of environments, from lush forests to the stone interior of a world war two bunker.  The controls are great and make navigating lara through the semi-open world environment a joy, from scaling large radio towers, to zip-lining down mountainsides. Furthermore the combat, always the weakest part of the series, has been completely changed, with the auto aim replaced by third person shooter mechanics, fun melee finishing moves and stealth sections which are fun, although this approach can not be chosen and is instead forced upon you in certain moments.   The story is solid, though not the strong point of the game. Although the characters all feel different enough from each other, they are all fairly one dimensional other than Lara herself, who develops well throughout the game from frightened victim, to hardy survivor, and is voice acted solidly and convincingly.   The puzzles are interesting and serve to break up the combat well, but unfortunately this is exactly their purpose: to break up the combat sections. For a game series which has traditionally been about puzzling, it was sad to see the emphasis lifted so heavily from this element of the game and this is my biggest criticism. For fans of the action/adventure genre, who occasionally like a break from the combat, I highly recommend this game, however long-time fans of the series may be disapointed by the lack of lengthy and difficult puzzles.   Overall, I would recommend this game for its great graphics, good combat system and most of all the sheer fun of controlling lara. Although the story is not the strongest and the puzzle elements feel like they could have been fleshed out, it is overall a fun experience and it's good to see Lara back.

Tomb Raider is a terrific addition to the series that has a fun story, but also fantastic graphics. I've played it on both windows and mac, and it runs fine on both. However, a word of warning - if you have a unsupported graphics card on the mac edtion (I don't know about the windows edition), there will most likely be graphics issues. I tried it on the unsupported NVIDEA GeForce 8800 GS, and nothing rendered but Lara's hair, water, and fire along with trees etc. No actuall textures rendered such as the walls of the cave you start off in, and the ground.   All in all though, Tomb Raider is a fantastic return to the series that I thouroughly enjoyed, and the graphics will astound you - if your rig can handle it of course ;)

A truly excellent game. I've been a fan of the Tomb Raider series since the beginning and to date its characteristic puzzle meets shooter meets adventure vibe has been unmatched - and now the creators have managed to incorporate elements from the current MMO shooter trend to outstanding effect.  I can't help but feel that this latest incarnation of Tomb Raider is inspired by Borderlands 2, not just in gameplay mechanics such as levelling up and upgrades - but also by going writer-first and starting with a solid story, and then following it up with solid execution across the board from directorship to art and lighting. The net result is an epic. An interactive novel. A story you be a part of.  My one and only criticism is that it's a bit short and I completed it in 2 days. But loved every minute of it, and will almost certainly play it again (and maybe again).

The latest Tomb Raider stands in a way as the second reboot by Crystal Dynamics as the haggerd franchise attempts to catch up with games such as Uncharted. Honestly, even Tomb Raider: Legend seem to be two steps behind the rest of the world. This new entry, however takes a larger leap to get to the head of the pack.  In many ways it's merely catching up with the compitition, but with a surprisingly deep combat system, and the fact that it's TombRaider it seems to be able to edge just an inch ahead of the rest. In the end you get a extremly polished AAA action explorer game, with a fun and rewarding combat system.  The only problem to be had is in respect to whether it's in fact Tomb Raider, and how simular it is to the Uncharted franchise. Really the new game layout bares more in common with an Uncharted game with a girl then the next Lara. The latest Tomb Raider has little to non of the series past actual Tomb Raiding, non of the alternate costumes and general fan service of the past entries. This, much like the removal of the sex appeal of past entries is a matter of opinion of the player. Note however, that though the sex appeal has been toned down/removed, the violence is fairly extreme. Though it attempts to give you the idea that Lara is young and vulnerable, almost immediatly she is executing people with shotgun blasts to the face, and stabbing people in the throat. So if big boobs offend you more then gang style executions, you'll be right at home.  In conclussion Tomb Raider is an amazing comeback for this aging franchise bringing fresh life into it's whithered bones. As a franchise Crystal Dynamics has a chance to lead the pack, if they can out pace the likes of Uncharted and Assassins Creed.

Pretty decent experience. The opening minutes are harrowing and there are multiple occassions throughout the game where that feeling comes back in full force.  I do have to say, the game was at its best when all I had was a flimsy bow and I crapped myself whenever enemies were nearby because well, it wasn't exactly easy to fight them off. That only really held true at the beginning, however. Once you start getting weapons and upgrades, you become pretty damned unstoppable, and that feeling of utter menace you got from the environment simply vanishes. The only things that can really kill you, after a point, are the awesome set pieces where you have to scramble lest the ground beneath your feet crumbles and you die.  The weapon variety and upgrades were nice, but I mostly stuck to the bow and arrow, and wish that really would've been the only thing available to us. Maybe the handgun too. That combined with a greater emphasis on not being seen and getting Lara through situations by using more creative level design so that the whole game isn't one big freakin' shootout could have elevated it from being a good game to being a great one.  [spoilers] I mean, the disbelief increases steadily and exponentially as the game progresses, and nice little details like the journals of soldiers getting decimated by Oni and the stormguard etc could have made the whole experience that much more frightening and harrowing if those spooky bits of lore were substantiated by actual danger. I loved Lara's impetuous screams of 'see if you can stop me you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!' but come on... a bunch of well trained soldiers got decimated by these things but one little girl on her first adventure mowed them all down with a vengeance?  There's a degree of believability at the beginning that I found really enthralling and got me hooked, but the game dispelled it completely by the end. That's not to say it wasn't fun.  What kept me going was the exploration, and how creative you could get using environments to your advantage in a fight. It was really easy to just find a nice fox hole and kill everything in sight, but damn was it fun to just run out there and tear it up.  All in all, a good game, and a good start on the revival of the series. Looking forward to seeing where they take it.

This series has been close to my heart since the release of the very first game when I was a child. I've played at least a little of every title along the way, but I'd begun to wonder if any development team could ever come close to the magic of the original. Something about this one finally achieved what was missing for me, and is the game I've been hoping to play for years. I can only hope that future titles can carry on what this team of people brought to the series and find ways to improve on what they built here. I daresay I would love to see this team do a proper full-fledged remake of the original title to really do it the justice that the Anniversary remake failed to achieve, but I know that will never happen. This game makes me excited to see the untold stories of the indomitable Lara Croft.

It took me a long time to get around to playing this game and I wish now that I had started earlier. I've rarely had more fun with a game than I did with this one. To me, this is a game of exploration. The physical puzzles and combat are secondary to the discovery of new places, documents and relics. We all know Lara Croft, sometimes we forget that she is an archaeologist. This game describes how she became the Tomb Raider of legend and I loved the ride. The game is defined by the tiny details that help make the experience immersive. Lara will, when jogging through a forest or through a narrow tunnel, reach out a hand as she passes a tree or to fend off a wall. Her clothing deteriorates as the game progresses, rents and mud and blood from her very physical activities having their deleterious effect. As she gets wounded her vision blurs and she moves a little more slowly; no health bars on screen. If she detects bad guys she ducks into a crouch, a position in which she stays until the threat is ended. I would call the combat cover-based but you don't need to press buttons to enter/exit cover. If she enters her combat crouch and nears appropriate cover she uses it. Later in the game enemy fire will destroy cover, as will your own, so combat becomes much more dynamic. If you want to stay alive you have to learn to stay mobile. While the story is linear there are fast travel points scattered liberally over the map that you can move between at will once discovered, allowing you to search for those things you may have missed. Using them, I was able to achieve 100% completion on my playthrough. I could go on and on about the things I loved about this game but I'll try to sum up my experience. I came to care about Lara and her journey of survival and sacrifice and I felt privileged to be allowed to help her on her way. If that's not an immersive game experience I don't know what is.
