Pretty impressive, overall. To get right to the point, while it has its glaring flaws, it's a pretty fun action-platforming experience. The story is entertaining, the movement feels fluid, it looks and sounds nice, and they made a decent attempt to make the main character actually feel like a person rather than a nameless badass slaughtering endless enemies... Well, mostly.  You start off feeling entirely helpless, but the game eases you into things well enough, even if that means several mechanics that might seem important are touched on once or twice later, and then never again. The characters are about 'what you see is what you get', but even though there is a twist or two that you'll see coming a mile away, they might surprise you a bit with how decently written they are. Lara herself feels like an actual, ordinary person accomplishing extraordinary feats, which is enjoyable until later on, when you begin killing dozens of enemies as if they were nothing, breaking down any 'challenge' or 'ethics' that might've stressed you earlier. What I'm trying to say is that, as the game goes on, there is a slowly increasing dissonance between what you're doing in-game and what the game says is happening. But that's okay, it's not a huge deal.  If there is anything I could rag on, it's the sheer amount of firepower you get later on. You have access to more than four ways of brutally murdering people, and ammo is seeming always there when you need it most; a stark contrast to the first couple of levels where you're struggling to get enough arrows to consistently deal with threats. Any sort of scavenging you might do is eventually reduced to searching the fifty bodies you just killed to fill your ammo back up.  But enough of the negatives. It's a good game, and one I would certainly recommend if you have an aching for a new platformer.

Tomb Raider is a prequal to the other installments which tells the origin story of Lara Croft. Lara and several others set out on an expedition to find the ancient island of Yamatai. After a brutal storm. Lara finds herself washed up on that very island. It soon becomes clear she is not the only one there. A violent and well armed cult inhabits the island and takes her fellow explorers prisoner. Lara has to fight to survive and save her friends, all while uncovering the secrets of an ancient kingdom. A very detailed game. The scenery is amazing, the combat is well developed, and the story is powerful as it shows Lara changing from a green explorer to the hardened adventurer that we've come to know and love from the other games. Normally, I don't care much for prequals but this one stands out! This game leaves you in awe and doesn't have a dull moment. I highly recommend this game. If you are new to the Tomb Raider series, this is a good place to begin!

Looking forward to more enteries into the Lara Croft franchise after this golden reboot.

Usually, 'reboot' is synonymous with cash-grabs and low-key imitations of the original material. I'm glad that Tomb Raider 2013 didn't fall for that. Instead Crystal Dynamics have opted for a more modern, Uncharted-esque stance on what made Lara Croft special. The result is reasonably impressive but it won't please the fans of the old formula for many reasons : the title notwithstanding 'Tombs' are actually....optional.  Yeah you read that right a Tomb Raider game which isn't about raiding tombs, secondly the tone of the game has radically changed. In TR2013 we are talking about a grittier approach which dovetails nicely with the modern videogame audience which doesn't reward truthfulness to the source material. Dare I say the majority have only heard of Tomb Raider. Admittedly I was a little bit put off by the sheer amount of violence on display, the narrative didn't give me the impression that all this gore was warranted. It didn't really fit. Gameplay wise this is a rather standard third-action game featuring a agile cover system, gunfights and puzzles resolving. If there is one complain that many have made about the game is that the XP system is tacked on and doesn't really bring anything meaningful to the game, and it's weird to see boxes waiting to be salvaged in such an environnement. The XP system is put in place to stay in the loop so to speak, to mirror what Far Cry 3 or other games have implemented.   If you have played and liked Uncharted there is a good chance you might be thrilled by this reboot of the franchise. I can't say it's quite as impressive as Uncharted 1/2/3 in terms of pacing and writing but it's definitely a game worth playing and not a mere Uncharted knock off. Lara is definitely not the same but she remains a likeable character, some might not like her somewhat american accent but newcomers won't be bothered in the least.  7/10. Recommended.
i loved this game 10/10, nothing else to say really

Gone is the buxom, one dimensional Lara of old as we are introduced to a more realistic and interesting Lara in this reboot of the Tomb Raider story. The game starts off in what appears to be a linear QTE adventure but as Lara makes her way across an island it grows into an almost open world where you can fast travel from one region to another. Now this isn't GTA but somehwhere inbetween Uncharted and the old Tomb Raiders but on a single island. The Lara we're introduced to is unsure and vulnerable but as the story progresses the writing shines as we see her grow into a pretty strong heroine. This is made better by really good voice acting (for the most part) so it's hard not to be engrossed for the entire length of the story. With great gameplay, story, characters, music and a gaggle of PC tweaking options this game is nothing short of great.

Tomb Raider has a very extravagant level design. Comparable to the Uncharted series but maybe a little bit more because of the semi-free roaming feature. It has similarities with Dark Souls and Witcher games because of the camp system where you can save and also upgrade Lara. The story is very good also, if you like mysteries. The artifacts and documents you collect also adds a little more to the story and every artifact you collect from modern to ancient times broadens your imagination and has a voiced-description of Lara. This game really makes you think of how thrilling it is to be an archaeologist. If this was a movie, this would have been a blockbuster hit in the theaters. Though the multiplayer is a ghost town but if you have friends you can have a private match or coop. The script could also be a little bit improved since it's not as well polished as the Uncharter series. 9.5/10

Hunting was a one time thing, then I never seemed to get food from the animals anymore, just my arrows back.   Can't say that I would recommend this game, or would play it again.

Before this the only other Tomb Raider game I had played was Underworld. (which I only played about half of because it was borrowed) It was good I suppose other than the fact that I had to use a guide every so often for the puzzles and I felt pretty terrible about the way I had to perversely stare at Lara's tightly exposed ♥♥♥♥ the entire time as she backflips over endangered species whilst promptly shooting them in the face. Kinda makes you have to turn the screen off everytime someone enters the room.  Anywho, I did not have to turn off the screen or use puzzle guides in Tomb Raider 2013 because this game takes itself a lot more seriously and I had less of a hard time with the puzzles.  The new, rebooted Lara can be taken a lot more seriously because she seems to have much more of a human personality now and dresses a lot more realistically too. Her personality and character are complimented by the situations she has to go through and the strong story and setting around her. The majority of the game's puzzles are entirely optional as 'Tombs' which can subsequently be 'Raided' mostly for weapon upgrades of various kinds. I'm not sure if the puzzles are now easier or if I'm simply smarter than I was back when I played Underworld.  Let's be honest, it's probably the former. Nonetheless, I felt great when I accomplished a puzzle tomb and the snazzy weapon upgrade was nice always nice too. The action in the game is pretty awesome, the game becomes less and less scripted as you go along but even so, you'll never complain about a scripted moment later on because they're so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ kick-♥♥♥ in your face. The gameplay is split between the platforming (which will become more and more advanced as Lara acquires new tools and equipment to help her)  ...and the combat (most of which you can choose to handle stealthily with melee, silenced guns and your bow OR you can go crazy with your machinegun and upgraded fire-breathing shotgun) All is handled awesomely and feels incredibly fluid and smooth using an adaptive cover system where Lara will crouch, stand and lean exactly when she needs to without the player having to do anything but move her there. The open world is pretty interesting. If you've played a game like Dark Souls then you'll be familiar. Large, open areas liniarly connected. Also containg bonfires from which you can upgrade, level up and fast travel. The whole world looks freakin' amazing too, you'll get a lot of situations where you can see somewhere in the distance that you can get to, if you can't then you can return to the area later on with new equipment and try again. A lot of the time you'll find explorable, puzzle filled tombs this way. Incase you can't tell by the essay of a review I have here: I love this game. The only complaint I have is that there isn't all that much to do after completing the main story other than find the remaining tombs which feels pointless because I have little use for upgrading weaponry after the main story where the wide majority of the enemies are fought. So if you get this game I'd also reccomend any DLC available provided that it's good and substantial. I'm not sure how good the game is on other difficulties but I'd reccomend highest difficulty on your first playthrough because with the stealth approach I died pretty rarely.  Too long, didn't read?  It's a good game.

Playing through family sharing as my father owns TR 2013, they are on a solid path, making improvements where they are most needed, while still making you feel like they are the Tomb Raider Development teamwhen you get frustrated. These titles are among one of the best survival action series' I have had the chance to play, and as a Developer myself There is a lot to learn from, studying how they changed from one game to the next with the change in technologies as well. If you like Adventure games and don't mind a third person shooter aspect with a reticule for the combat, as well as an ending in 2013 that makes you question why they were so realiztic up to that part, you will love these games. They don't start you back too far from the last time you died, and that is one of the most pleasant aspects of the game. it is called TOMB RAIDER, so to not have to do entire tombs and levels over again just because you died is a really nice touch. for $70.00 USD you get 10 games. thats right, 10. where else you see that good a deal?  HumbleBundle.org?  from time to time, yes, but would you EVER see this type of deal if you went to say Walmart, Target, Micro Center, Best Buy, or any others? Unlikely. BUY THIS.

I haven't played a Tomb Raider game in almost 15 years, but I'm glad I came back to the series with this one. The visuals on this game are nothing short of jaw-dropping, and had me compulsively snapping screenshots throughout. The mix feels like a summer blockbuster, deep and bright and always loud. And the sound design is A-grade, with the Foley being especially good, lending a lot of human weight to all of Lara's grapples and climbs.  The plot's generic, but the environments are so well-designed and arted that you don't mind hopping around them to get to whatever the next goal is. Exploration is a blast and I naturally fell into searching out collectables. Could've used a few more tombs, though.  Worth picking up on any kind of sale.

Forget everything you know about Tomb Raider.  This is a masterfully epic game. It has stunning graphics, compelling story with an intense pace, likeable characters & character development, meaningful weapon & skill upgrades, fun and well balanced combat with a seamless cover system, a healthy dose of exploration, parkour & physics puzzles, and some of the best motion capturing I've ever seen.  Everything about this game is well designed and executed . They really nailed it. I could not put it down.

One of the best games, if not the best, that I have ever played in my entire life. The graphics. Gameplay. Enemies. Objectives. Storyline. Collectibles. Items. Epicness. All of these, and probably many more are absolutely fantastic. I would recommend to anyone who likes third person shooters will not be sad. I didn't like them myself, however this proved to me the best. Even the loading screen is in the absolute detail. Thrashing water onto the dark island, and simply everything else including the epic storyline as well as the characters are fantastic. There is one problem, though. I have experienced the game crash at least 5 times, and two events, Windows had to restart after a terrifying blue screen. Although I simply cannot stop playing this game, because my computer is still working fine. In fact, other games crash. This means that Tomb Raider is nearly perfect, and is this game has the most epic singleplayer. With awards being won, this game has been so good.

I really enjoying this game and can't wait for the next update. The missions, challenges and puzzles are good. I'm enjoying the 'damn hot' Lara, she looks so hot on this game.  The only downside is the combat difficulty level, even with Hardest mode the combat level somewhat too easy to beaten.  Worth of purchase!
It's like a waterfall of hair if you have a supercomputer
Great visuals, great gameplay mechanics, a bunch of quick time events but not bothersome!

An adventure worth of the franchise, the new Lara worth of the heritage, a story worth of a daring reboot, gameplay worth the heroine's grandeur and an immersion worth being called an interactive movie.

I would not recommend Tomb Raider. I would, in fact, do the exact opposite. I have never played a game so proud of itself, and so unworthy of that pride. It looks nice, it occassionaly plays nice, but the cut-scenes are distracting, and yet uninformative, the quick-time-events are obnoxious and repeatative, the combat is just silly, and when Lara falls 80 feet, on her spine, and feels nothing but a slight twinge, bye bye tension. I was just watching someone else's story, not interacting with it on any level. I liked Roth....I guess. But his arc was stupid and pointless too. Nothing happens in this game. Hell, even the older Tomb Raider games held some weight to their story...actually, scrap that. They didn't, and neither does this. This is the perfect Tomb Raider game as it continues a long line of poorly made, boring games and next time any game thanks me for playing it, I will kill a small puppy.
Absolutely awesome game. Gameplay is smooth and well designed. And not to mention it is one of the best looking games I have played in my life!

Surprisingly fun for a third-person shooter. I'm a first-person FPS guy but this game is fun. Reminds me of Far Cry 3 although a little more linear. Combat is challenging in its own way. Worth a moderate price. I recommend.
One of the most entertaining Tomb Raider games in existence. If you've played this franchise in the past, this game is a must.

It has been a very long time since I've played a Tomb Raider game and for the first time I've felt like I completed a truly astounding game. Every bit of the lore, I loved. Every ounce of her character I believed in. This game made me feel connected to the story and I wish it wasn't over.  This hands down beats any Uncharted game and is truly what all other types of this game should draw from and learn from. I'm a Japanese cultureholic so naturally all of the myths and such within this game I already knew based upon actual stories.  I am anxiously awaiting the second one!

So far, this game is THE Game 2012/2013 for me. Nothing comparable was produced in those 2 years (except Skyrim-DLC's, but they don't count as game ;)). It's brutally and shocking real, one will find themself in deep empathy with Lara very soon in the game, hoping she'll escape from the jungle alive, fighting those crazy lunatics and her own fears, stretching her physical limits to new hights. Square Enix + Crystal Dynamics just produced not just a masterpiece within the Tomb Raider-Genre, but also generally. Hats off.

I have no feeling on this series. It is not that good as the metascore suggests. There are several secret achievements that is highly missable. since I dun wanna spend too much time on this, I would better stop helfway.

I've played all Tomb Raider games and I have to admit that this one is my favorite one. Very mature gameplay combined with great graphic, good balance between fights, climbing, and geometrical puzzles brings one of the coolest experiences you can find in the modern games. I got this game on sale and it is my favorite game from 2013. At it's heart it is an easy third-person shooter on normal difficulty. Superficially it's a plot-based survivor game aiming for graphical realism (but not tedium). It's extremely simplified RPG elements (need to find next major equipment upgrade to progress) but no inventory to worry about (beyond ammo). The plot is a little corny/obvious but good enough that I never once felt like 'oh, so that the next plot device to delay my progress for another level'. Laura did not earn a single complaint from my girlfriend for being too fake, so that's a plus. Her early-game whining made me shout at the screen a few times though. Level design is fantastic and always fresh; it can be easy to get lost. Jumping is easy and there are simple climbing/ledge mechanics. There very few timing puzzles aren't bad enough to make you want to rage-quit, in fact the puzzles are pretty basic. There are only four guns in the game (always available once earned), plus a mid-game mellee addition, but they easily made the bow my favorite. They can be incrementally (lightly) upgraded as you go. Falling damage will kill you if you fall far enough (or 'out of bounds').  For the completionist: It gave me 31 hours of completionist enjoyment for the single player alone (only getting the optional dungeon as DLC). Spam that 'survival instinct' skill (Q) like it's your job. You may have to save at the campsite and reload to finish that DLC tomb because jumping onto the plane got buggy (reload fixed it). Chatterbox is an easy-to-miss achievement, but almost everything else can be 'gone back for' after the game's ending. The only thing you can't repeat (and don't need to) are cut-scene levels like swimming down some river rapids, dodging tree branches, for example (which is the closest I came to wanting a rage quit). Recommend upgrading survivor skills first if you're a completionist... but you'll end up getting all skills and upgrades by the end if you make a bit of effort.  I would have been fine paying $30 for this game, but for most folks I'd put it at a $15 (or less) value (including the optional tomb DLC).

Personally I was not much of a tomb raider fan and I bought this game because it was in the Christmas steam sales and had good reviews. However upon completing the game I can now say I am a fan of the game series, with beautiful graphics and a good story line combined with a good combat system, this game has left a lasting impression on me and I will keep my eyes pealed for future tomb raider releases.
great game!

This game scored 2 / 5 in my opinion. If your interested in why, read the review below, or just read the conclusion if you want the main points. Keep in mind this is my first tomb raider game, and the review is based solely on the campaign of this game, of the original edition.  Graphics:   The opening cut scene was stunning to watch, I thought it was real for a moment at a few parts. However after that, the graphics switch to the game play graphics which was still great to look at, although not the same, and they translated fine from the cut scene.    In a few of the high elevation areas in the game, If you just take a second or two and look at the island laid out before you, it is very beautiful to look at. Same could be said for a few of the low elevation areas, where you can get a good view of the mountains and the temples on them.   Game play:   Switching to game play graphics the whole game, saved loading time for cut scenes and allowed for upgrades you did to weapons to be seen in the cut scenes. Doing this also allowed for QTE (quick time event) to be used, however, almost every cut scene was a QTE, this rubbed me the wrong way. To many QTEs don't allow you to show off the games graphics, but rather make a player focus on pressing a button. Which brings me to the point, several of the QTEs state to “Mash” a certain button, where in truth you are to lightly press the button at a steady internals. Don't get me wrong these can be fun in certain games, but I like to watch my cut scene, especially in games I viewed as more causal. Although I know not many people may share this opinion of Tomb raider being a casual game.    Continuing on with other aspects, the gun play, so as aiming and upgrading your arsenal, was very well thought out. When you kill an enemy with a certain kind of weapon, they were more likely to have that ammo on them to pick up. Also gathering certain parts to upgrade certain weapons, mixed with the random scrap you pick up through out the game felt real. As well as certain weapons working best in certain situations. The shotgun worked best for “tank” units, rifle for fighting a group of targets, your pistol for dark areas that required a torch to be carried in one hand. Finally a bow to silently dispatch enemies and attach ropes to far places.   The game was very action orientated, this sadden me. After all for a game series I always heard was puzzled based with relativity hard puzzles, this game was no where near it. As a new player to the franchises I was very disappointed about this, as most of the tombs were optional, and these were the main parts that had the puzzles. The game was more of a run and gun through areas then climbing, more ducking and weaving behind cover to kill a group of enemies, then more climbing or crawling in tight spaces. The puzzles that did exist where extremely simple and lacking any type of challenge.   The Survivor Vision mechanic was useful when you had no idea were you where going, and it also let you know what you could interact with. The bad thing about this was that at certain parts, such as dark areas, were you are meant to have no real idea of where you were going. You could “cheat” and use the vision and have a clear layout of the room and where to go, as it would light up the darkness.  Audio:   The small sounds of this game were very good, such as bumping into a metal drum that could be moved around, it actually sound like you had run into a hollow metal drum. The voice acting was also very good, the voicing over was good to. You could follow the lips of characters in cut scenes and “see” the words they spoke.  Characters/Story/plot:   The fresh take on Lara Croft was well done in my opinion, keeping to the roots of a bad-♥♥♥, sexy, yet human character that felt real to the player (MOST OF THE TIME). The character design of the other character is good, and the ability to find the “notes” from certain characters was a good thing for people that like to dig into a games back story.   The Story itself is original, but it falls short of what most people expect in games today that are story driven. The main reason it falls short is because of the completely unrealistic series of unfortunate events that befalls Lara and the gang. I am not talking about the supernatural factor, that part is well done. However the unrealistic amount of ♥♥♥♥ that falls on them is to far out, where is the hope? The moments of build up of tension, then release of horrible events. Where is the actually plot twist and turns, that no one sees. They tried a story of high tension and survival, with the idea that your always on your toes, but they fail.    At one point they even take Lara Croft and place her out of character, to fall for an event that not only from a player perceptive, but from an in-game Lara Croft perceptive you can see it going to happen in the game. You could argue that because this is Lara “first” adventure (since its a reboot) that she is naïve of the world. Which in some cases the game designers do well to show this off in the game, when she goes through all this horrible events that befall her. However, this does not mean that she cannot see the actions of the person in front of her that will lead to a certain event that will transpire. I cannot buy that someone who when through college, that is in their mid twenties, had a well studied father, and is well studied themselves, can fall for such an event that is right before their eyes, regardless of the situation.   This brings me to my next point, they even start to destroy the image/character of Lara Croft by setting up a relationship between her and another main female character that has heavy undertones of possible lesbian relationship. I understand that this is a reboot of Lara Croft for a modern world, and that the designer have a character that Lara and her have a close relationship, so that Lara has a reason to care about trying to save her. Whether the lesbian undertones is intentional or not, I feel this takes away from Lara Crofts original character core. Then again this is a fresh face, and they are the designers, so maybe they will run with this and it will turn out to be something great instead of just poor story telling.  Conclusion and other notes:    The graphics were amazing to watch, I didn't like how almost all the cut scenes were QTEs. I especially hated the wording of how you were meant to interact in the QTEs. The gun play of the game was well done, however for a game title I personally would view as a causal game to play there was a lot of Action, and a little bit of adventuring. The puzzles I did expect to play, were few and far between, those that did exist were poorly constructed and were not challenging puzzles.   The Audio of the game was well made for a game that had no music in the background. The characters were well done, until you come to the point where Lara Croft is ripped out of character to fall for an event that in game she should be able to see. The story premise was good, but the execution of it was poor with the constant horrible events happening to the characters, with out any build up, real reason, or pause for a moment of breath for the story to sink in. For a game that is driven by story it falls flat on its face.   All in all, it adds up to be a 2 / 5 game in my opinion.  I played the normal edition on max settings, hard difficulty. I didn't try multiply player, as I had no interest in it.

First off, it's a Square Enix game. That being said, I'm very biased towards Square Enix, cause they make so many games I love. But honestly, Tomb Raider really was an amazing game. I've never played any Tomb Raider games in the past, so this was my first impression of the series and the character Lara Croft. Lara was beautifuly portrayed, and she was just all in all an awesome main character. The think fast mechanics were especially favorable. There were some interesting plot twists too. In the end, it's a game I'd definatley reccommend. Only flaws... I'm not a huge fan of a ton of side quests so, I completed the game with a hearty 66%. If you really wanna pour your hours into it to find everything, you're gonna be here a LONG time. 9/10

If you could accualy play the game I think it could be good. I have a decent computer only 2 years old quad core proceeser I have with 256 gigs of ram for the graphis card.
