Fun game for the most part. Sort of like a FMV game but with updated game mechanics. Although, if you have any issues with motion sickness in games. And I mean ANY AT ALL, don't buy this game. I don't have problems with 99% of all games and this game can give me a major headache with all the shaking.  Otherwise a fun game, I just wish they hadn't rendered the whole thing in the Blair Witch Engine with no option to turn it off.

I was never a fan of the old games but on a recommendation from several friends, I gave this a shot. WOW!!! I am so glad I did, this is one of the best games I have played in years! The story is absolutely terrific, the animations are excellent and the combat is fluid with a huge interesting world to explore! This is an amazing adventure game and I highly recommend Tomb Raider.
Amazing graphics, Lara is incredibly beautiful in this game. Honestly one of the most amazing games I've recently played. This game is a great experience. worth every penny.
A decent reboot, though could use less baysplosions.
Probably one of the best and most beautiful games I have ever had the pleasure to play.
cool
Amazing game. If you've ever played any of the Tomb Raider games you'll find that this installment is the best Tomb Raider so far. I highly recommend this game.

Only recommended for those who enjoy a good action movie, the gameplay is the easiest of all the TR games, the exploration and puzzles are for kiddies, the only thing who saves this game is the story.

Tomb Raider is a reboot done right! Crystal Dynamic has done a solid job reviving the franchise. The gameplay feels like a cross between Uncharted/Batman: Arkham Asylum (which is really good since I loved both) and it still manages to feel like a Tomb Raider game should do. While there is a story featuring a various array of characters, the 'new' Lara steals the spotlight as her character develops in a battle to survive. The upgrades/abilities system is very well fleshed out, with exploration highly rewarding in salvage when completing artifact/journal sets or raiding tombs. Overall, a great action/adventure game that no one should miss out on.
The Tomb Raider the franchise deserved. An amazing ride!

Great game! This TR is remaniscent to the original TR, the first 2D PC game I every played on my Pentium 266. I say this because i loved the first one and this one is AMAZING. I LOVE THIS GAME! I have already gone back and played it again all the way through and now I am wandering the island looking for stuff. so beautiful chalenging and fun. Highly recommend.

The first few hours of this game cast a weird light over the video game landscape. Lara Croft isn't your typical hero anymore; it's certainly interesting to see this girl scream, moan and shriek in pain while some of her friends get killed off.  Then she gets a gun, goes into shock when she kills her first enemy and the rest of the game is a fantastically mo-capped shooter.  As with all the games I guess. Still, it's good, and the story is also good. You should give it a try.

This game blew me away the instant I started. Superb graphics, tight controls and a cool plot. The combat is solid and there is good mix of platforming, puzzles, shooting and stealth so no one part becomes tiresome. The voice acting is great as well. My only complaint is that there seems to be a few to many quick time events. They're easy enough to get through but they're a little annoying. On a side note, the designers of this game think REALLY highly of the Uncharted franchise. Like the always say; Imitation is the most sincere form of flattery.

Jesus christ this game is ♥♥♥♥ing garbage. It would potentially be awesome without the ♥♥♥♥ING CONSOLE ♥♥♥♥ TIME GARBAGE.  But no.  ♥♥♥♥.  Time.  Garbage.  Aside from the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ proliferation of QTEs, the game is actually pretty good once you autohotkey all that QTE garbage.

I have played many of the previous Tomb Raider games and while I found them entertaining, I never really wanted to sit down and complete them. I found this new reboot completely gripping and couldn't put it down. While I could do without the majority of the quick-time events and the play control is a little loose at times, the game generally makes up for it with forgiving A.I. The game auto-saves at checkpoints, of which there are many, throughout the game so you never really have to back track very far if you find yourself acquainted with one of the game's many gruesome death sequences.  I felt that the bow was the most satisfying weapon with the pistol coming in a close second, and on normal difficulty ammo scarcity wan't an issue until the final confrontation. The characters were wonderfully fleshed out and I can't wait to continue down this rebooted series. The game is gorgeous and most of the environments feel like actual environments and not just set pieces. Climbing the radio tower was one of my favourite scenes.  I just hope Square/Enix doesn't pull the same DLC b.s. they did with this game. Save yourself some money and pick up the Survival Edition when it's on sale for $15 to bypass purchasing all the little $1 dlc skill traits.
This game is actually great! For some reason, I wasn't expecting much, but man - so good. Thoroughly enjoyed.
Great new story for Lara, bit actioney and not highly realistic at times but still breathes fresh air into a tiring series that rejuvenates interest into the games again...

In this Tomb Raider reboot, you play as the young Lara Croft on her first ever expedition to find the lost kingdom of Yamatai. Theorizing that Yamatai is situated within the Dragon's Triangle, the ship and its crew sets sail towards the notorious region. Unfortunately, a violent storm shipwrecked the ship and left the crew stranded on an unknown island. As Lara finds her way around the island while battling insane survivors and an evil cult, she starts to discover the secrets and history of the island hidden away by the flow of time.

The Uncharted of multiplatforms. I've played most of the Tomb Raiders that have come out over the years, however, none have really grabbed my interest as much as this latest entry in the series. I've recently moved back into PC gaming from consoles, and I've played through Uncharted, which I always was sad that non-PS3/Vita owners couldn't play such a game. Tomb Raider remedies this by providing stand out gameplay, skill/weapon customisation, lots of things to find throughout the environment and a good story to boot. This truely is a great fun game and in some ways, it even out-shines the Uncharted series. It feels very much like a cross between an open world RPG and a third-person action game. The way the game plays out is great too, allowing exploration without just pushing the player through the story. You can always backtrack and find things later on. All of those things aside, this game is beautiful and if you've got a decent graphics card/SLI setup, put on the TresFX and check out the amazing fluidity of Lara's hair (it might sound silly but it really adds to the immersion). If you were a bit 50/50 on the old Tomb Raiders or you really liked the series, this is definitely a great reboot to the franchise, check it out!

This game is good, but it has its flaws. It's not an adventure like to old Tomb Raider games (1 & 2) but rather trying to be more like Uncharted (with the big set-pieces and movie-like scenes) and an action shooter(cover system and a lot of shooting). The game is still good, the environments are excelent, the game looks good, and plays pretty well, it's just more an action game than an adventure. Also the game is fairly short, I was able to finish it in less than 8 hours... but still it was worth it... I recommend getting the game, but wait for a discount...

Although we've seen a fair amount of 'franchise refreshes' lately, this game is an example of developers doing the gaming community a solid. Excellent controls, gorgeous graphics (especially when pumped up to max), and a compelling protagonist make this a fantastic experience. I would highly recommend this game to those who are fans of adventure/platforming games with a strong cinematic emphasis. Think Uncharted with a female protagonist who is strong, intelligent, and a legitimate character who isn't there as a damsel in distress. She's strong, motivated, and extremely capable. Part coming-of-age, part fantasy adventure, this game is an incredible testament to having a female protagonist in a game that is not simply there for pure T&A factor.  My complaints are few, but pointed. Quicktime events happen fairly regularly, and are extremely infuriating. Often, the QTE happen during what seems to be a cutscene and ends up giving you an untimely and unavoidable death. Once you realize the cutscene was a lead-up to the QTE, you attempt to hit the appropriate keys (oftentimes without really being told WHICH key to hit), and then if you don't respond within what seems like a half-second, you hit your untimely and unavoidable death. The QTE segments really seem to be an exercise in Memory - die, remember the keypress for the next go, die at the next prompt, rinse and repeat. I'm never a huge fan of QTE because it's never a skill-based moment in the game; I always feel it's better to just leave it as a cutscene than to unnecessarily kill the character due to the player not realizing they need to start mashing buttons. I think, in the end, it may just be a more resounding issue of higher-fideclity gaming and engrossing players in a cinematic experience. The trnasition between cutscene and QTE should be more obvious if the developer believes using the QTE crutch is necessary for the storytelling.  Overall, a very hearty recommendation! This is not a game you should wait for the bargain bin unless you absolutely cannot afford $20 for an absolutely fantastic gaming experience.
Though it was my first time playing any tomb raiders i thought the graphics and overall gameplay was amazing. Lots of suprises i thought.
Great game, definately a must have for everybody, not only Lara Croft fans! :) Watch out for discounts on this game, worth every cent!

A pretty solid reboot of the venerable Tomb Raider franchise. I wish it was a bit longer though. It's also a shame that stealth isn't a viable option, say like in Batman. At the beginning of the game you're supposed to be the prey and fight for survival but ammuntion is always aplenty and the enemies don't pose any bigger threat until they start coming in hordes in the later parts of the game. It's a bit of a shame, since I would've welcomed a more stealth-oriented approach. Instead, the game changes into Gears of War with Lara Croft... albeit a little more dynamic as you are required to move around more frequently as the enemies have ways of getting you out of cover. And while fun, it could've used a little bit more variety. Aside from the aforementioned lack of indepth stealth-based mechanics Tomb Raider is really good. And the PC port even runs quite nicely on my old GTX260. Oh, and you can skip the multiplayer.

This game is pretty amazing so far. I really feel like a survivor in an impossible situation, but still can make time to raid those hidden tombs. I just hope that by the later part of the game I don't feel like a commando.

Game looks fantastic for starters. The story and the impressive set pieces come together to create a fun, but arguably dark adventure for young Lara Croft. If you're into third-person shooters, you don't want to miss out on Lara's newest outing.  oh and using the bow is awesome.
Good game with great story and perfect graphic.
YES i recommend this game i definately recommend
10/10 Game   Not only is this a amazing reboot it's a amazing story driven RPG
This game kicks. Get it now.
Best game I've played this year. Love everything about it.

This game is fantastic. I've played a metric ton of games over the years, and this one is easily in the top 10. Has a great story, action packed scenes, and the cut scenes meld very smoothly within the game play... sometimes i was just standing there, not realizing i was supposed to take control.  The game definately feels like a linear story. Some people didn't like that so much, but I personally liked it. It gave me a sense of unfolding a story as I played, matched with great graphics and fun. I HIGHLY recommend this game... there isn't anything quite like it.
good looking game with amazing story
Very nice reboot! Stay in this way please!
Great dialogue, mystery and scavenging make this title one of my favorites.
It's great!

Not amazing but definitly enjoyable, its partially linear and at times its free roam. Predictable storyline with great level design and beautiful visuals. gameplay was fun and interesting and I had fun with it from start to finish.
Love the look of this game. can't stop with the screen shots!
Thoroughly enjoyed playing this game. The graphics are amazing and the gameplay doesn't let you down. Can't wait for the sequel!
Gritty and intense. While I've never played this franchise before, the reboot is off to an excellent start.

If you enjoy dying over and over just because you were staring at Lara's ♥♥♥, than this is the game for you. Seriously this game trumps all other games in the 'Tomb Raider' franchise. Great gameplay, cut scenes, (no more triangle b00bies) and content. :)

This is REALLY the Tomb Raider I've been expecting for years. Beautiful graphics, amazing scenarios and an even more amazing gameplay, with a lot of options to improve your combat and make the game lasts forever, if you desire.  But... there are always the bad part of it. Of course, and I usually don't complain, but this is something that I must talk about. The game is kinda repetitive, you won't get more than 4 weapons, all of them customizable and improvable, but still quite repetitive and annoying.  And... Why the **** am I still writing it? I'm going back to my playing.

An amazing re-imagining of a classic series. Worth about 20 hours of gameplay to complete single player mode at 100%.  The plot is basically LOST meets DIE HARD, but it's enough to keep your attention.  The game play in much more combat oriented than in previous games. Instead of being just filler between rock-climbing puzzles, you actually feel like you have some combat skills and strategy to use, like stealthy melee kills, bow sniping, explosives, fire, etc. The puzzle solving isn't very hard, but it's challenging enough to be fun without a lot of 'I don't understand what I'm supposed to do'. You also get to collect XP to gain bonus skills and parts to upgrade weapons.  The graphics and sound are beautiful if you have the hardware to back it up the 'Normal' graphics settings or higher.  It's not perfect, but it's probably the best Tomb Raider game yet. 9/10
Great game. Never had an interest in Tomb Raider before this came out, now I can't wait for the next entry.

Finally - a triple A game with an interesting female protagonist.  Absolutley stunning graphics and animations, particlularly the lighting.  Immersive gameplay that makes you wince at every bone-numbing tumble. Seamless cutscenes - with QTE's that feel appropriatley frantic.  Tomb Raider is a deliciously gritty cookie for any fan of beleviably tough women. Albeit a rather short cookie for $70. If you can find it for less, I urge you to give it a try.
great graphics smooth gameplay and has a really nice feel to the story as you play through the game

If you've never played a tomb raider game before (like me!) you are in for a treat. The plot doesn't have massively intresting turns here and there but the game plays out like a very well funded hollywood movie. There are likable characters, massive explosions and lots of weapon upgrades that really do make a difference in your play style!  Good game! Plus, if you can get the multiplayer to work without lag it should be fun too :)
Solid, thrilling story.

If you're a fan of cinematic triple-A quality games like Assassin's Creed or Batman: Arkham Origins, Tomb Raider is filled with interactive cutscenes for gamers with quick reflexes. Stealth elements pry themselves into gameplay, forcing you to risk your saftey as you take down enemies with your bow or announce your arrival as the hard-heartened Lara Croft. Puzzles and secrets are peppered into the gourmet storyline, awaiting you to peel back the events that unfold.  Tomb Raider is a great title for the modern gamer looking for a few suprises in an otherwise robust explorer survivor - a la Indiana Jones experience.
Once I said, 'I´ll never play a Tom Raider Game', and then this title came out, It´s too well done, I´m really enjoying it, and the new Lara is very pretty, I truly recomend this game. Thanks Steam!

While this game is pretty solid for a reboot, there is one major issue which made me stop playing after only little time spent ingame: The camera. I haven't seen any game using this much camera shaking and bobbing, it's horrendous. I haven't had any motion sickness problems or similar with any game. but this is really over the top for me.
This game was fun, suspensfull and had a new and creative story. recomend this highly

I want to trash this game for having a terrible storyline, but as I sit here thinking back to the old PS1 Tomb Raider games I realize that this series has always had dog ♥♥♥♥ storylines. Anyway, if you do get this game what you'll be getting is a flat out beautiful game with a good combat system that was made with a lot of attention to detail. There are certain things about the gameplay that annoyed me very early on in the game; However, as you get further along in the game I realized that many of those annoyances were done placed the developers for a purpose. This is a very good game that barely misses being awesome by a few short coarse hairs (if you know me, you know what kind of hairs I'm talking hairs). PEACE!!!
Awesome game.. plays and ends like a movie but still has enjoyable combat.
Biggest surprise 'WOW' this year. Flat out amazing game, a must play.

Wow! This game beats all Tob Raiders before altogether. It's so well made, shows the whole story in such a very good and atmospheric way. I really liked transformation of Lara and realism (which could have been better). I was missing only more of a survival features like at the beggining of the game and it would be better to focus on that and less shooting perhaps. Interface could be a bit better, but apart from that it's totally f*****ing awesome. I finished that game in 3 days!:) And now slowly will focus on completing 100%. Didn't try multi yet caus I'm crappy with shooting. But I hope it's as good as single player game. Solid 9,5/10!
The single player is worth the money. Gameplay wise it is pretty fun to watch Lara got abused by the unforgiving human, animal and nature. They toughen her up and she's became more than a survivor.

This game has a lot of quick time events, which I presonally do not like. It also suffers from other scripted events, invisible walls and ledges and platforms which look accessible but are not. The game does not offer interesting side quests. 'Secret' tombs are propably the most interesting one, but these tombs are not so secret and puzzles are easy, maybe medium difficulty. Everything else is collectibles. The story is the main thing in the game, once you've played it, you don't have much reason to go back to the game.  Despite these setbacks, I do recommend this game because of the nice combat system and good story.

I have played the first couple of games released in the mid 90s. Now, this does not happen often, but I fell in love with this game already in the first 5 minutes or so. Amazing graphics and awesome gameplay. Definitely my current favourite in my games list. Kudos to the developers.
One of the best games of this generation. Stunning graphics, storyline and gameplay. A must buy!
A great reimagining, very different to the original tomb raider series but not a disappointment. A great action-adventure in it's own right and beautifully made.

I know this is backwards, but it plays like a female Uncharted. Regardless, the game is incredible. Voice acting is top notch and the writing is well done. The gun play is tight, also. My complaints are minor. QTEs are annoying and only serve to break up the intensity of the action. Also there are a few situations where an exciting bit of traversing is done for you.  I'd also like to point out that the game looks beautiful and runs like a dream even on old hardware. I have a 6 year old Dell with a 1gig GTX 550ti and with everything except AA turned on High it still plays at 50-60 fps. However, do not use Tressfx, it will tank your performance.
amazing story game.
An absolutely fantastic adventure, filled with action, intrigue and well-acted characters. This game was made with the love and care often absent from modern game development.
Great game! Decent storyline. Liked the flow of gameplay into and out of the cut scenes. Recommended.

Amazing boo... I mean hair physics. And Lara's boo... perseverance is remarkable. During my playthrough all I ever thought about was uncovering her... past interactions with the other crew members. The environmental detail is gorgeous, I still can't get those nice rounded ... hills! out of my mind. Although Tomb Raider might occasionally jiggle, I found it hard to wean myself off of it. Highly recommended.
if you like boobs and jumping 30 feet this is the game for you
This game is amazing. It is beautiful, good story, good gameplay but this game is too fast to clear ( around 10h)

I am glad I picked this up on the 2014 summer sale. I had no interest in it originally, but damn, I almost missed out on a great game.  + Great characters and story. + Minimal UI elements allows you to get immersed into the game world. + Shooting mechanics are solid; headshots are satisfying. + Really good sound design and music. + Among the best looking PC games, and runs well.  PC specific:  * Graphically impressive, best character models and animations I have seen in a game. * Performs very well. With a GTX 760 I am getting 60+ fps on 1080p high / ultra settings, and often times triple digit frame rates. * The game fully supports high refresh rate monitors. There is no arbitrary hard-coded frame rate cap. * Mouse control feels proper, like a mouse. No mouse acceleration like you have in bad ports. Mouse smoothing can be toggled in options. Only bad thing is that horizontal axis mouse movement is slightly faster than vertical, but not a big deal. * In my playthrough, not a single bug, crash, or freeze.

6 out of 10  Take Lara out for a spin on her first adventure. From a time before she became a famous archeologist.  This is an adaptation of a console game. Therein lies what bothers me. It may actually be a very good console game but not a good PC game. To be fair this is not the worst game I have ever played. In fact the second half is quite good. This justifies the thumbs-up. Just a pity the first half is so terrible. I would say that this game is not for serious gamers. It may be very acceptable for a pickup every now and then.  Tomb Raider should be all about exploring, searching for loot, solving puzzles and fantastic locations. Although the game has some of that its more about the action.   The good:  1. Mmmm.. nothing really stands out.  2. There are some nice locations but way too little. Most of the scenery is very standard.  3. Some cool loot. Unfortunately most loot is pointless other than for the achievement.  4. The second half action is quite good.   The bad:  5. Adapted form console, the camera does not flow freely.  6. Very linear game play. Although you have to go back to the few locations to get all the collectibles because you don't have the gear required yet. Very irritating.  7. The game looks good mostly, however Lara and other characters looks like a wax dolls. Skin tone and textures are console like.  8. Why is there a crouch button? It does not work. Lara crouches when she feels it is necessary.  9. Lara keeps on lighting a torch and switching to the pistol. I had to reselect my weapon the whole time.   The Ugly:  10. Some of the most pointless cut-scenes I have ever seen.  11. Be warned some of the death scenes are way too gross. Not for me. There are also heaps and heaps of blood and corpses; amazing number of corpses for a remote island.  12. Awful button pressing sequence scenes. This may work on console but not on PC.

all in all a decent game. If your looking for a classic tomb raider feel well . . . your going to come up short but if you take it as a stand alone game it's graphically appealing, has approachable mechanics and the pacing is decent It also has a solid plot for this type of game.  The downsides, I want to be delicate here which is not my strong suit, but I do this because this game shows a LOOOOT of conceptual potential which can and I feel will inspire later games to refine what they have done here. None of the mechanics are really new, but the way they are used is fresh to me. That said.  Much (To much) of the game was a series of win or try again timing minievents. think GoW boss battles where you have to hit a move that flashes up or you loose your footing and maybe a little life. The way it is used here if you fail you usually have to restart the fight after a bloody death and posibally some dialogue. On the plus side death has little to no meaning as you may just back up 30 sec or so to the start of the cinamatic you were playing. ALL major battles in the game are like that. and the button commands are not displayed over the action at times so you may not see it come up. Which brings up another issue.  due to the quality of the game and the cut scenes it is imposible to tell where one ends and the other starts, this can and will get you killed. as you do not realise you are now incharge of saveing your skin.  There are some areas where by walking in you are automatically noticed, this KILLS the cynamatic tension and mood to that point. and it is counter productive to the hard enforced stealth to survive mechanic.  there is a lot of discovery in this game but the discovery seems shoehorned into the most liniar story I have seen in a long time, this is not a strictly bad thing, you have an established character and a single end in mind but in a more modern sense this seems like a step back. Yes it was done to keep the plot on track and keep the near movie feel. which I say CAN work. but games as an interactive medium need agency or at least a sense of agency. here they have the right tools but they are useing them to often or to strictly and all to often taking the action away from The player only to hand it back without notice.  The camp menu, well it's a mess. it looks neat but does not function all that well. some screens have clickable areas to go back, others you have to use escape. while there are icons to indicate what menu you are in there is not always a way to tell where the menu you want is without memorisation, they do not loop so you will eventually hit an invisible menu wall  there was a hunger mecanic used early on for plot reasons which was quickly dropped. While I agree that the mechanic was unnessary, as a general rule of thumb if you are going to force a player to use a mecanic that mecanic is canon and beyond redaction. so use it regularly or never introduce it.  The Bow is your main weapon, a great all purpose stealthy weapon with very high stopping power. that doubles as a decoy maker, rope launcher, fire starter. For Laura's first adventure I would think she would never leave home without it. Yes Roth uses dual guns and yes you eventually get to use them also but serously as a survivalist I would be taking that bow to the grocery store after this experience. there is no emotional incentive for Ms. Croft to truely fall in love with the guns she is so well known for.  That's it for my griping. Good game Overly scrypted and cinamatic. but great plot and good character development.  I may sound grouchy but I give it a 7 out of 10

As my first Tomb Raider game, I was blown away and understand why the franchise has gained such a mass appeal. This version is a fantastic 'origins' game with a young Lara Croft who must quickly grow up to use all her wits to survive and save her friends. The graphics are stunning and cutscenes well directed. The game play kept me well engaged with the traveling mechanics, from the parkour to the ziplines, and figuring out how to get to my destination and all the bonus items. There's a little sense of RPG with the skill points and which skill set to unlock first as well as the verious gear/weapon mod upgrades to select. Combat may involve stealthing, sniping, and sometimes you just have to get up close and personal to time your melee strikes. The only thing that took getting used to is when the cutscenes ended and game play begins. Don't hesitate to buy the GOTY edition. I'm looking forward to the next sequel. Overall: 9/10  Tip: If you've acquired all the bonus items and challenges but still finished the game at only 99% completion, then you'll want to fast travel to Shipwreck Beach and revisit the Cliffside Bunker (lower rightside of the map) since it's the only place that does not have a fast travel camp. Also, examine all relics as you find them.

An addictive adventure game, with some action in it. I had never been a fan of the Tomb Raider franchise, yet this game managed to keep me stuck to it for many hours. The first thing to notice in the game is obviously its great graphics. The maps and landscapes are beautiful and detailed. Lara's character is the one you are going to admire throughout the game. Being an adventure game, Tomb Raider includes a great number of secrets and areas to discover with lots of collectibles not always easily found. The plot is pretty simple and predictable, but it is a detail that you will not pay much attention to while playing. The game mainly focuses on scavenging items and fighting enemies. The former is actually a greater challenge than the latter, given the enemy AI which may tend to get ridiculous. However, if you like third-person platformer games with lots of walking around, jumping, collecting items, solving simple puzzles and finally, shooting, then you will be satisfied with what the game offers. Apart from the few glitches that I have noticed, it is generally well-made and can keep you interested, or even addicted to it.

As someone who is not a big fan of playing single player campaign games such as tomb raider, I picked this game up on the premise of seeing amazing graphical designs. Everything I was expecting was delivered in pristine packaging, and then some. and then some. and then some. and maybe even a little more. when the game your playing leaves your heart racing and your hands shaking with anticipation and fear, you have got a very prescence-filled game. Many games that I have played recently have either had just graphics and boring content, or poor to medium graphics and great content. Tomb raider though, has both amazing graphics ( and I do mean the best graphics that I have seen in-engine ever) and phenominal storyboarding. Throughout the game you will stumble upon scenic landscapes and brutish natives, both extremes somehow fitting together in perfect harmony. Not just once, but many times was I left sitting in my chair stareing at my monitor as I experienced what was a more beautiful sun rise then I have seen looking out my window. This game will leave you frustrated and scared, but also awestruck by its beauty and complexity. This is the only game I have given the full 10/10.

Decent game all in all. Good revamp for the classic Tomb Raider series.   Storyline is kinda forced, but well told, very gritty and dramatic. Graphics are simply amazing (even for a low end machine like mine), and really helps immersing at the story, especially concerning the landscapes and Lara herself. Gameplay is decent, the controllers are a bit messy but adequate. Difficulty is low, Lara can take more shots than a tank even at the highest difficulty (pretty sad as the enemies' AI is very good), and the puzzles are easy as hell so if you looking for a challenge go elsewhere. Also, too many scavenger hunts, gets tiring after a while.   DLC content isn't worth your while, a few outfits that I didn't use anyway and some multiplayer thingies that I have yet to play, and also another tomb. But tombs are pretty much a single puzzle with some XP and salvage as reward, and no real effect on the story, so... yeah.  Finally the game have some glitches. I just hate the need of having to break the gaming experience searching for a fix to a game-breaker bug, and this game have its good load of them. But at the end of the day, I had a good time with this game. I hope the sequel will be even better.

I really enjoyed this game, for several reasons really. The graphics displayed within were phenomenal; I showed this to several of my friends at school and they actually had troubles attempting to distinguish parts of it with real life! I found no issues with the controls - they were nice, simple and definitely easy to get the hang of and use. I found the atmosphere within the entirety of the game stayed tense, exciting and that it drew you in at every point. I only had one particular issue with it, and that was the lack of explanation for the controls when using a XBox 360 Controller. There wasn't too much latency with it, but aiming with it sure was a pain (especially considering the concept is still relatively new to me!). For this game, I'd recommend it to anyone who loves a good, indepth storyline; adventure; puzzles and action. Just be warned though - it's a little gory in places!

Overall rating: 9.5 out of 10  Gameplay: Combat is very intense and the gunplay is excellent. Entering any battle, Lara's actions and voice acting make the battle feel dangerous and important. Combat is cover-based, but it doesn't detract from the game because Lara can't take too much punishment (At least on Normal or Hard difficulty) and avoiding taking damage is often more important than dealing it. My personal favorite weapon was the pistol and upgrading it only made it more fun to use. Thankfully, weapons that did not receive as many upgrades were still useful in their own situations. Stealth is an option in TR and while it may not be the main focus of the title, it works well enough. Sneaking up on enemies is relatively easy but not being spotted by other enemies while taking out their friends is difficult. Using the bow to take out an entire area is extremely satisfying. If someone strays to far away, an arrow in the neck or head can remove them and strangling enemies in tall grass or bushes works as well. On a downside, alerting one enemy immediately alerts the entire area and they all run directly at you. Adventure exists but the game is very linear with only side paths. Personally, this did not detract from the game but others may be looking for more adventure. Thankfully, the game allows fast travel all over the island but usually it's just to find collectibles you missed or complete challenges.  Story: 'In our darkest moments, we find something to keep us going.' Lara starts off as an innocent archaeologist, but events on the island turn her into a hardened survivor willing to do whatever it takes to protect her friends and stay alive. All of the characters are very human and act/react accordingly. The death of a crewmate is blamed on others, killing results in disgust and fear, crewmates argue among each other as their confusion and fear grow, and while Lara emerges as a leader in the group, the others question and lash out at her. All in all, the characters are very realistic and easy to sympathize with, even the 'evil' ones.  Visuals: Absolutely stunning, this is definitely a high-fidelity AAA title and although my computer can only handle Ultra at 60fps, it looks incredible. Ultimate looks even better but I can't run it at 60fps. If you have a beefy PC, this game will look incredible and it still looks very good on the lower quality levels.

I fully recommend this game as I find it one of the best I have ever played. Lara (nice acting voice too) has transformed into a real human being with all the initial doubts, lack of skills yet lots of determination and curiosity. It is exciting to make her evolve and become the hero as we know her. The scenario of this came is well developed, the setting is rich in all its details, graphics are stunning and the possibilities to explore the island and do a lot more than just kill vilains or jump onto rocks, trees, boats and crashed planes are very well worked out. The same holds for the choice of foreign sound and music. Some of the action scenes are no less than thrilling, with the adrenaline flowing like hell. After finishing the game one feels compelled to go on exploring the island. Though possibilities for that are somewhat limited (whay not disclosing the whole island?), a lot remains to be discovered and - as the sun is setting behind the mountains - to be admired. Well done!

I will recommomend this game because, while it is pretty good, it has 0 replayability. It is a well driven interactive story for the most part. There are some places where you can go 'off the beaten path' to pickup some extras, but these extras are mostly moot towards the end game, plus the 'extras' all require you to do the same basic thing over and over again. The decapitations are nice.

The Good: Great Combat, solid mechanics, strong voice acting, excellent graphics.  The Bad: ...Eh story and characters, multiplayer is apparently dead (could be problematic for achievement hunters)  The Bottom Line: There is absolutely no reason to pass this game up if you catch it on sale and are a fan of the 3rd Person Shooter genre. I'm looking forward to the sequel.

This is the best Uncharted I've ever played.     I really hate the story of this game. It's so bad, and craps all over Lara as a character. What was once an iconic badass female Indiana Jones is now a run of the mill idiotic weakling. At no point in the game did I think 'yeah, that woman could kill a dragon.' or 'I bet if a T-Rex showed up, she'd have no problem with it.' The entire narrative is crafted by someone who loathes Lara as a character, and Tomb Raider as a franchise.  After all, it's called Tomb Raider and there aren't any real tombs. There are tiny puzzle rooms that would disappoint Wheatly with their simplicity. The gameplay used to be smarter. It used to be a third person puzzle game, now it's a third person shooter. Lara herself seems very dumb. It bothers me that I was able to put together the plot a good 4 or 5 hours before her. I was actually surprised when they devoted time to her realization. I couldn't help but think 'Really? She just realizes this now?' This stands in stark contrast to the original Lara who was usually informing the player of the situation. It felt like she was in control, but not anymore.  The politics are what really bug me about the game. Her main threat on this island is the white male and that threat is eventually replaced by rapey cannibal samurai. Any white male that is a good guy is basically a father figure, or a man-child. All of whom die for the sake of her character development. Can you be any more obvious? It's ham-fisted, cynical, and sloppy. Inverse the genders and suddenly this crap is unacceptably sexist. Yet here, there is a pretense of realism. A pretense created by Lara's redesign.   However, while Lara may be a idiotic weakling, you as the player never feel that way. While Lara may struggle in the narrative, you will cut a bloody swath through the island. The automatic cover system is surprisingly flawless, and traversal options make the game a seamless joy to play. The aiming, movement, and shooting feel like a vastly improved version of Uncharted. The guns have more punch. The game overall looks prettier. The aiming is perfect. The challenge is perfect.   This is a game that feels so good to play that I find myself going back to it over and over. I may moan over the poor writing, and I miss real Tombs, but it feels so good destroying everyone on that island. Counting the definitive version on the PS4, I must have played this a good 5 times this year. I've streamed it twice.  What makes a game isn't the politics it so obviously endorses, but the way it plays. And this game plays phenomenally. Overlook the SJW garbage and just enjoy the game part of the ♥♥♥♥ing game.  Worth it at 40 Dollars.

I highly recomend you get this game, even if you've never played a single Tomb Raider game in your life up until now (like me!). Your money will NOT be wasted.

When I first bought Tomb Raider I wasn't really sure if I would enjoy the game at first. The setting looked interesting but I wasn't sure how the gameplay would hold up, as I knew the game employed some quick time events, which are generally not an attractive feature in games. Turns out, this game was a great buy.  To start off, I really liked the fact that this game was a prequel to all other Tomb Raider/Lara Croft games, starting at the original adventure that helped her become who she is. It was really fun to see her character develop throughout the game from a simple archeologist to a battle hardened badass.  The setting and story for this game were amazing and engaging, and with maps and scenery to match. The bare bones of the story is that Lara and her friends, looking for a 'Lost Kingdom', end up crash landing on an unknown island in the Dragon's Triangle, which is described as the Bermuda Triangle of the Pacific Ocean. The land itself is strewn with ancient Japanese ruins which make the scenery beautiful and makes it feel like you're walking(and fighting) through history. Moreover, each section of the game is and feels unique and different from the previous sections as you traverse through the game. The story itself is based on a real historical legend/controversy, and it is very interesting to follow along as you help Lara unravel the mystery of the island and its savage inhabitants.  As for the gameplay, Edios and Square Enix have done a great job of striking a balance between combat sequences and puzzle sequences(as they did in Deus Ex: HR). The amount of combat sequences feels acceptable, as you are not constantly under siege but it is never completely absent from the game. The puzzles, both story -related and optional, are always fun to figure out but not too complicated. There are quite a few collectibles that give small bonuses and aren't particularly difficult to seek out if you wish. However, the game never forces you to go on 'collectible missions', which is a big plus, because nobody likes those. And yes, there are quick time events in this game, but it does not degrade the game 90% of the time, as they are mostly concentrated in the beginning or first half of the game. One or two can be frustrating when you die multiple times because you can't get the right key mashing down, but many of them are there in certain parts once or twice to help teach the player the function of new weapons/gear/etc.  Overall I'm very pleased at how this game turned out, I'm not sure if it's worth 50 bucks(I got it on sale), as it seems to have around 15 hours of singleplayer gameplay(though it does have multiplayer too), this is definitely a great buy, especially for any fans of the series.

The Good    Tomb Raider is your standard 3rd person cover-based shooter with RPG elements. You gain EXP from enemy kills, optional tomb raids, hunting animals, etc. You then get a skill point every level to unlock or improve abilities.  Weapons can be upgraded with scrap collected to improve damage, accuracy or unlock an alt-fire ability.  The voice acting is good, the gameplay is good, the sound is good, and the graphics are great. Basically it's a good game.    The Bad    A few criticisms. The only weapons worth upgrading or using are your pistol and bow. The bow is silent, arrows can be retrieved, and it's alt-fire modes can be utilized to bypass tomb obstacles or storyline obstacles. The pistol is accurate, with a fast rate of fire and gets a silencer later in the game.  Because you are rewarded double EXP for head shots, and many of your gun fights will take place at a distant; neither the shotgun nor the assault rifle are accurate enough to get consistent head shots.  The cinematic aspects of the game are obnoxious. I don't need the camera angle to change as I wade through water and watch as Lara moves under a fallen iron beam. Or having debris fall as I'm climbing up a ladder or rock face. I'm literally holding up, feeling bored and you're dragging out this scene for no other reason then to make it feel like a movie or pad time.  Lara needs to shut her mouth when I'm doing puzzles. If it takes you longer than 2 mins to figure out a puzzle in a tomb, the game will remind you to 'activiate survival instinct' a ping type ability that highlights all interactive objects in your vicinity. If it takes you longer than that Lara will give you an audible hint like 'I need to do X somehow...'  From what I can tell you can't turn this 'feature' off.  If the player is too dumb to figure out the puzzles, then they're too dumb to figure them out. If they want to give up they can easily look up the answer online, but that should be the  PLAYER'S DECISION. I don't need a fu cking Navi over my shoulder spoiling the challenge for me.

Personally, this is one of my favourite games. They've done fantastic work on her character - something which was lacking in previous games of the franchise (she's not just the arrogant, shallow Lady Croft she was in previous games) and you can actually SEE the progression of her character over the course of the game. She's every bit as fantastic as she was in previous games, but this time she's just a little more human.   One of my only problems with this, however, is how quickly her character changes between cutscenes and gameplay - in the cutscene she's horrified by her ordeal and how she actually had to (spoilers) kill someone, and almost as soon as you're thrown back into gameplay, you're taking out dozens of baddies. I understand that it's hard to express the development of a character in a game, but perhaps they could have worked a little harder on making it believable, or even a smoother transition?  Overall, a brilliant game with few flaws. Some have different experiences, but I play for both the game and the story, and as a Lara fan, I think it does quite well in fleshing out her character.

9.5/10 - Excellent interactive story, QTE-haters gonna hate  This is one of those games that you start playing at sunset and then you are surprised to see the sun is still setting, but on the wrong side of your room, until you check the time and realise that a new day is dawning. The game does several things very well. The sense of progress you get from both skill- and item-based rewards, and the pacing of the story, its mysteries beginning to unfold as you explore the island, keep you on your seat for hours. The ambient sound and music are perfectly orchestrated and aligned with the impressive visual art style of the game.  EDIT: I came back to alter my review, because I have the feeling I have judged the game from the wrong point of view. Tomb Raider is a genre mix. It has first-person-shooter, stealth, melee, jump&run, and interactive enviromnent puzzle elements. It does not excel in neither of those and my issues with the game basically result in problems I have with the game mechanics - specifically with the combat mechanics - rather than the product as a whole. When I perceive the combat in Tomb Raider as a storytelling technique, I can live with it as it is. Conflict in all its forms and shades is an itegral part of the whole story. The non-combat elements more than make up for it, however, resulting in an overall exciting gaming experience.  Things the next installment ought to do better: - Visibility is a problem. When enemies immediately know where you are after you shot one of them...with a bow....in the middle of the night...in a dark forest, then you know that visibility is not really part of the game mechanic. Enemy FOV also seems to vary from one scene to the other, ranging between 45 degrees to 210 degrees, resulting in spectacular silent-takedown fumbles. - Hard difficulty does not mean multiplying enemy hitpoints by 100. This just gives players a sense of powerlessness. Increase enemy numbers, frequency of special attack usage etc. instead. - Player insta-kills by adjacent enemy via QTE: just no. Just because I have engaged an enemy in melee, do not penalize me by instantly killing me for doing so. If I am reacting too slowly to an enemy attack animation, ok, then it is my fault. Killing me without any warning sign is just a dumb thing to do and very frustrating. I know this is not Chivalry nor Mount&Blade, but please stop. - Harder and more frequent puzzles.

Looking back at this game I don't find it as impressive as when I played it for the first time. As a long time fan of the series I probably expected the game to feel a little more like... you know, Tomb Raider.  Crystal Dynamics certainly has big plans for the franchise since this whole game is dedicated to Lara herself, rather than what all the other games are dedicated to, which is exploration and tombs. Their fixation on Lara is so strong they had to stick the whole family thing even into the remake of the first game, for god's sake. I didn't like that direction at all.   What bothers me is that this TR had the potential of having big interesting areas that weren't just shanty towns. There could've been way more exploring of the old Japanese palaces, rather than skipping through them in action sequences.   The overall cinematic feel is very Uncharted-like and seems very forced at times. QTEs are also present and I can't stand those. While they claimed there's gonna be so much exploring to do, there's really only two big areas in which some exploring can be done. The rest is pretty small or doesn't feel rewarding. I like the little history facts dropped here and there when picking up collectibles tho, that's what Lara should keep doing.   I just feel like the next game will be the one that really feels like a Tomb Raider. Unless they ONCE AGAIN decide that Lara's character should be the main focus, rather than her abilities and knowledge used in the field, along with exploration and mythology.

Simple, and to the point.... To say this game is Awesome.... is just.... a complete and utter, insulting understatement. I can honestly say this is the best action adventure game i have played in.... a very long time. From the very start of the game you are dropped into a fierce, fight for life, and the action just gets better and better from there on.   From the intense waves of enemies you can encounter if you let them fire off a signal flare, to the absolutely incredible 'Run for your life' sequinces. This is truly a work of art from start to finish. This game will take you on a thrill ride that, at some points, may have you slideing to the edge of your seat as you run and fight your way for survival in the unbelievably beautiful world it drops you in to.  Words elude me, and nothing i can say, can reccomend this game highly enough to do it justice. I found it very difficult to put the controler down once i got started, and once i finished the game, i wanted to play it all over again immediately.

The context-sensitive control scheme in this game is possibly the most beautiful one yet. Lara hides behind cover when near it, and grabs onto things at the right time when jumping around. It's a bit like Assassin's Creed platforming but with pressing buttons (and not too timing-obsessed either) instead of holding them down I suppose, which makes it feel slightly more natural.  Clambering around does go pretty well with cover-based shooting, and the enemies have a healthy supply of grenades to keep the combats bouncy.  Reading the journals and looking at the various priceless artifacts is fun, but the cutscenes make it seem like Lara didn't actually read the (optional) journals, so she seems a bit slow in the head when only figuring out the major plot points at the last possible moment rather than a few hours into the game. On a related note, it's very satisfying that the evil cult is founded on entirely accurate deductions, and not delusional at all.  The stealth sections are a bit pointless, as they're usually faster to beat if you take them head on, and most combats don't let you even try to start them sneakily despite stealth being pretty underpowered.

This is an excellent reboot to a series that has been in desperate need of a change. The game does a good job grounding the series in reality, while at the same time providing some supernatural flair, with a bit global conspiracy mixed in. It also has enough collectables to be fun, but not too many to be insanely time consuming. The game does have a schizophrenic attitude when it comes to Lara and being an empowered female main character though, she shows plenty of emotions through the game but she also ends up being victim to some of the most brutal death scenes I’ve seen in video gaming. This is a great game to get for any action adventure fan.

Wow. Very impressive. A very bold reboot of the series. Besides some vestigial remnants, it is a basically a complete re-imagining of Tomb Raider. Lara Croft is an actual human character now, not some Angelina Jolie-neckbeard fantasy-action-movie-heroine. You will grow fond of the new Lara very quickly. Gameplay is fun and it has some depth to it. There is a levelling system with weapon/equipment upgrades, and interesting items and tombs scattered throughout the world for you to find. Lara, as usual, has a lot of awesome moves, including rock climbing with a climbing axe, scrambling up vertical surfaces, swinging from bars, that sort of thing. Honestly just moving around the map from place to place is a lot of fun. If you can get it on a flash sale or something it is an absolute steal. I paid 4 bucks for it and I actually feel kind of bad.  9/10

Prejudices aside! This game turned out very well and I had a lot of fun playing it.   Here is what you'll get: • an exciting story (you don't know in advance what is going to happen) • a good gameplay • user-friendly controls which are easy to handle (many actions without having to bind 999 keys for every single step) • a healthy amount of killing :)  The only negative aspect about this game are the documents you may collect in a mission. They are numberless and it took me hours to find at least some of them. This is my personal opinion which won't match everyone.  It only remains for me to add that I don't regret the purchase.

Lara Croft does things in this game that would make John Rambo faint like a sissy.   It clocked in around 12 hours, which for an adventure driven story is short but on par with most high-quality campaigns. They were a great 12 hours. I didn't like how scripted everything felt, and you really didn't feel like you were doing anything other than jumping through hoops at particular intervals, but it was still fun.  Gameplay-wise it pulls its punches. Combat is braindead easy and Lara fights like a Delta team commando. Seriously, the mobs of enemies you face in this barely even slow you down, and I was playing on Hard. If you can get past the implausibility of that, it's cool watching her rip all opposition to pieces.  Not bothering with MP. There's better options out there and the combat isn't robust enough to justify any time spent there.  Picked it up for $12.00, and it was worth way more than that. It's a great game to pick up, play,. and finish over a short weekend.

this game truly surprised me  I was expecting some kind of trashy cash in on the Tomb Raider name but in all honesty it's a lot better than the PS1-2 era games  it's more of a metroid-lite than a full on action game which is great in my books  the game is actually amazing looking, the screenshots and youtube videos don't do it any justice, you really need to play it to appreciate it  the environments are quite diverse as well, from a snowcapped mountain base to a dreary shipwreck beach, it really does seem like an island where ♥♥♥♥ just went wrong  the combat is smooth, but it's got the classic problem of obviously being designed with a controller in mind, but aiming as always is smoother with a mouse and keyboard; regardless killing hordes of enemies is pretty easy and headshots feel more rewarding than most other third person shooters  my main gripe is all the collectibles are a tad too easy to find and the weapon upgrades need to be picked up off dead enemies  which means you need to search every single enemy you kill to find them or you could possibly miss a part  it's a dumb system that could have been remedied by just having them all as collectibles throughout the environment  this game honestly blew me away, it was 100% better than I expected and I can safely say that I'll preorder the sequel if it goes the same way as this  ♥♥♥♥'s a hard 9, at the current price of 20.00 it's a steal but for anything less than that, it's a no-brainer

Game starts with your standard everyday ♥♥♥♥ wreckage, you land somewhere on shore and get dragged of to some strange voodoo ritual looking cave (some crazy MFs on this game), you have to free yourself and escape the cave (Teaching you the basic controls and jist of the game), the combat in the game starts off with a couple of lovely looking poodles (aka a dirty pack of wolves), kill them off and follow some story stuff, you are faced with some crazy spetsnaz dude, in which you get your first taste of using a pistol (of which Lara seems highly trained in using, although she starts the game as some innocent little model of whom is scared of everything...).  To some up the game so far, really enjoying the gameplay and its graphically satisifying, i simply can't wait to get a few more hours gameplay in!

Summary review  A wonderful game that takes a character notoriously known for being oversexualized in past installments and turns her into a royal badass.   Detailed review  I heard a lot of great things about this game before buying this, and after trying it out on the PS3 at my father-in-law's apartment, I wanted to purchase this for myself.  I had somewhat of a rocky start with the game crashing every now and again (up to the 'saving a rescuer' mission), but that was only because I was trying to be stupid by using SweetFX with this game. I honestly found myself not needing that mod and the game stopped crashing altogether. Still don't know why that was a factor, and can only guess it was because it was forced to disable certain graphics options.  So fun fact for those getting crashes: If you're using SweetFX, try taking that off and see if that works. If not, I heard turning off tesselation also does the trick, but I haven't had that issue personally.  In any case, the story and gameplay are amazing.  The story, while predictable at some points, is enjoyable from beginning to end. It's amazing to see how someone so innocent that is freaking the hell out in every corner, transforms into a one-woman juggernaut. And it's not one of those types of games where they have one thing happen to them and they suddenly have Rambo powers, no.  This was a long process of enduring with having to fend yourself against a lot of things, both physically and emotionally.  I also give the voice actors and writers a solid A for convincing dialogues and interactivity. If there was a hiccup or two on dialogue, then I didn't notice it. And even enemy interaction was very entertaining. At the beginning, I sometimes forgot that I was supposed to shoot them only because I was expecting more dialogue and that got me killed, so huzzah for immersion.  Then there's the gameplay. Gameplay was super difficult at the beginning, only because everything was thrown into you at once. But that's most likely what the devs wanted to do. Throw everything at your face without knowing exactly everything on what to do, just like how Lara was thrown into everything the first time.  You'll be fumbling a bit yourself, and finding yourself saying 'Oh ♥♥♥♥!' to environmental changes, but as time goes on and as Lara starts adapting to everything around her, you too will find yourself adapting to the game mechanics, from figuring out how new weapons work, to becoming second nature the moment you get a new attachment.  My only downsides to this game is its replay value. Once you play the game from start to finish, you feel more than accomplished, so play at your desired difficulty setting and stick with it. I played on hardcore from beginning to end, and don't regret ever having started off easier and then working my way up to harder.  All in all, I give this game a 5/5, and would recommend this game to anyone who wants a good time.

It's been a really long time since I haven't been severely disappointed in a high-profile-production game but Tomb Raider restored my faith.  For starters it's really well optimized for PC and runs great even on older machines. I could set the graphics to ultra (not ultimate) and get 40-60 fps even with my old GTX560. I really appreciate the extra work that has gone into the PC version.  The level design is great! With everyone and their mother going open world, it's kind of refreshing to see that the devs took a step back and made very interesting linear levels, most of which have multiple options to progress through. You can still travel anywhere on the island and there is fast travel in case you get lost while doing that.  The combat system is great too! You have 4 different weapons plus the option to go melee and each one feels unique.  Even when you fail the game feels rewarding because Lara dies in such gruesome ways that you can't avert your eyes. Also, every death felt justified to me; I immediately knew where my mistake was and was able to correct it in the subsequent attempt. Many games put you in really unfair situations where you die over and over again which leaves you frustrated; Tomb Raider is not like that.  Hands down the best game I played in quite a while. I totally recommend you play it too.

Pros :   Simply put, it's worth every single penny of its purchase price! One of the best action/adventure games you can ever play. The graphics are stunning, the story is great and the gameplay is flawless. The game will last you a petty long while espeially if you go exploring for relics and tombs in he very well designed island.   Cons :  Most of the DLC is multiplayer content... The multiplayer is kinda dead :P Sometimes it feels a bit too easy also.   My rating: 9/10

Firstly,there is no connection to previous games at all but then again it still manages to capture what the character of lara is.So it isn't really a con :p Also,the game as a whole could have been a bit more challenging and there should have been a few more tombs t oexplore just cause they were too much fun to play through

Hello. First of all, I'll mention that this is the first Tomb Raider game I've ever played, so this review is void of nostalgia and such. Okay, so if you're wondering, this is a game somewhat similar to the last Thief game, in the sense that it has you collecting shinnies, sniping people around and doing a couple of parkour tricks with some gadgets. It has a more linear experience, and it's more focused towards fps than stealth tho (although it's also a viable way to play sometimes).  Cons:  - It's rather short, about 12 hours.  - There's so many miracolous escapes from crumbling/being shot/burning/falling apart locations that the suspension of disbelief gets stretched quite a bit.  - Nobody plays the multiplayer, so it's impossible to get half of the achievements.  - It's really easy unless you play with both difficulty and AI difficulty in hard, and even then it's not a game that would be remembered by it's difficulty.  - The optional tombs are a bit tacked in. But nothing horrid, and the puzzles are fine.  Pros:  - Stunning locations. I went around screencapping everything when I entered a new place.  - Surprisingly good combat system, both ranged and melee.  - Some replayability looking for the hidden collectibles, although as I said you won't be getting all the achievements anyway.  - Decent story. Could have been executed with a bit more finesse, but interesting.  - Interesting collectibles with their unique art and descriptions (just like in Thief), in addition to other, generic ones.  Overall: 8.5/10

The reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise that started in 1996, Tomb Raider (2013) is the modern day re imagining of Lara Croft and how 'a survivor is born.' Developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix, the game departs from its 3rd person action-platformer roots into more of a 3rd person shooter. While this change of genre may displease many of the series' older followers, it was good compromise to streamline the gameplay to introduce a new audience and allow the game to work in the next-gen, where very few AAA platformer games are successful.  Much like Christopher Nolan's Batman films, Tomb Raider takes a different approach to its preceding titles. Just like Batman Begins focused on a young and inexperienced Bruce Wayne, Tomb Raider focuses on the origins of a young and vulnerable Lara Croft, before she became one of gaming's most iconic heroine protagonists. After a violent storm shipwrecks Lara and her crew on the lost island Yamatai, Lara is forced to survive the islands hostile inhabitants and find a way to escape. The game holds no bars, indeed throughout the entire game, Lara is beaten, shot, thrown off cliffs. Not for the squeamish, many of the games failure states subject the player to see Lara ravaged by wolves, speared through the head 'Cannibal Holocaust' style, crushed to death by cave-ins, you name it. The darker and grittier gameplay works well in Tomb Raider, making the player care about what happens to Lara. Most of the focus of the game is building Lara's character, transforming her from vulnerable archaeologist at the beginning to the 'tomb raider' character she is known as.  The island of Yamatai is divided into several zones, which serve as the set pieces for the story. While the zones range from forests, beaches, abandoned World War II military camps and makeshift shantytowns, they all incorporate the same formula of base camps where you can spend skillpoints and upgrade weapons or fast-travel, collectables that tell serve to explore the islands mysterious history, journals that expand on the lore of the island and backstory of the games side-characters. Each of the zones are designed very well, each of them feeling different from one another. Scripted on-rails sequences are very enjoyable to play, even towards the end of the game, running from explosions and collapsing buildings never gets old. Combat remains fairly standard as a 3rd person shooter, albeit somewhat clunky at times due to the auto-cover system. The few puzzles there are, optional tombs that you can find, are fairly easy in difficulty, most of them easy enough to figure out for the average gamer just wanting to progress further in the story. Traversing the islands landscape is particularly enjoyable, the 3rd person platforming never feels frustrating to play. It should be said that Tomb Raider was programmed with a controller in mind, while mouse and keyboard is usable, moving the camera and controlling Lara often feels sluggish at times, not being able to get any precise movements with WASD or a mouse.  Special mention should be made for both the art-designers and graphics optimizer. Even on a fairly weak system, Tomb Raider still manages to look absolutely stunning, and runs extremely well. The audio is fairly well done, the weapons sound nice to shoot, and the ambient sounds, particularly at night add well to the islands atmosphere. The soundtrack however does feel fairly generic, with not many tracks standing out throughout the game, with the exception of Lara's theme.  Tomb Raider is not without its flaws. The most obvious is the ludonarrative dissonance between the story and the gameplay. Near the beginning, Lara kills a person for the very first time, shooting him through the head in self-defense. A cutscene immediately after shows her crying and horrified at what she had done. Yet two minutes later (yes I did check how long it took) a 3rd person shooter sequence plays out, with Lara killing two mooks with barely any trouble at all. While Lara's change of character development is well done throughout the course of the game, her development from a vulnerable young girl to John Rambo is done much too fast within the time frame. Tomb Raider would have perhaps benefited from less 3rd person cover shooter sequences and more stealth elements, where emphasis would have been on surviving and avoiding enemies rather than killing waves of generic mooks. Tomb Raider's lead writer Rhianna Pratchett admits this shortcoming in an interview with TotalBiscuit, citing the disconnect between game designers and story writers when it comes to making the game.  Another unnecessary addition was the absurd amount of collectibles to be found in the game. Having a few would have been alright, however Tomb Raider has well over 100 different collectibles to be found throughout. This vast amount to find disrupts the entire flow of the games story, and feels entirely out of place. Why is Lara collecting birds eggs? Why is she lighting statues? It feels all extremely obligatory, like the copy and pasting of the Ubisoft formula. The game would have been much stronger without them. With the exception of Lara herself, side-characters aren't as utilized as well as they could be, all of them feeling a little too cliche. There is the sassy black woman, the young geeky nerd, the wise and experienced mentor, the shifty middle aged man, the adventurous young girl, the crazy preaching bad guy. Their personalities are a little more expanded on in documents you can find throughout the game, but still they feel extremely 2 dimensional, especially compared to Lara herself. It feels like their sole purpose in the game is to act as plot devices for Lara to work with and overcome. I can forgive this a little more however, as Lara's character development is the primary focus of the story, and every character shapes her in some way by the end of the game.  Square Enix famously said that despite selling 3.4 million copies four weeks after Tomb Raider's release, the game was deemed as a 'commercial failure.' While it is sad to see game companies focusing on squeezing as much money out of their customers as possible instead of making a good game, Tomb Raider is undoubtedly a successful title, particularly for a reboot of an aged franchise. With solid mechanics, excellent graphics and an enjoyable story that re-imagines Lara Croft, Tomb Raider is well worth the play.

Greatest Tomb Raider game ever, and I've played all of them. I've had so much fun with this game, the playthroughs never get old for me. Beautiful environments, class A art direction - as always, Tomb Raider games have been consistent with pushing the bar on graphics rendering and effects, and this installment is no exception to that rule. Great gameplay mechanics. Lara's character is more believable now than she ever was, from both the physical aspect - her physical proportions actually approach being realistic for the first time ever, she doesn't look like a blow-up doll for once - as well as her personality - no dry, witty, campy one-liners here. She's a whole different character at this point, and believe me, it's a very good thing.  I also like the more 'mature audience' approach being taken - these elements help to give the game and the characters and environments more believability when considering the desperate reality of their situation. To put it simply, this isn't your typical 'fun for the whole family' Tomb Raider game.  This game isn't afraid to get dirty, bloody, downright gory at times - I don't think I've ever really seen much (if any) bloodshed in earlier Tomb Raider games.  This game isn't afraid to have some strong language, never thought I'd hear someone drop an F-bomb in a Tomb Raider game. Not that strong language is a necessity, and by all means it's not overdone in the slightest in this game, it's not like characters are walking around sounding like drunken sailors. But again, it's a small touch that helps to add to the believability of the characters and the environment they're in. The voice acting is also top notch in just about every aspect.  This game isn't afraid to have a little good old-fashioned graphic violence, after all, it is kind of a 'survival' approach, even if it's not a true 'survival' game. But hey, if you were stranded on an island and constantly being besieged by survivors that have succumbed to barbarism, guess what? You'd do whatever it took to survive, and it probably wouldn't be pretty or sugar-coated in the slightest. Once again, immersion, immersion, immersion. Believability of the game world and its characters.  Crystal Dynamics has done a STELLAR job with the Tomb Raider franchise, they've done wonders to breathe new life into the series and Lara Croft - I've thoroughly enjoyed Legend, Anniversary, and Underworld. The engine they developed starting with Legend made playing Tomb Raider games fun again.  Get this game. You won't be disappointed, unless you're an undying fan of the old 'campy' Lara Croft. Believe me, I was for years, but this reboot has totally won me over, best so far, can't wait for Rise of the Tomb Raider to be released for PC.

Just finished the game and i really liked it. It's a good entry for players who never got into the Tomb Raider series because the whole story starts new here.  This Tomb Raider is a very casual game and the overall difficulty is rather low. This could possibly disappoint some hardcore players seeking a challenge, it didn't spoil my fun though (playing on normal difficulty).   The game has some sneaking but is by far no sneak game. It has some experience based leveling and some equipment upgrading but is by far no RPG. There's quite some shooting but it's not an FPS. It has some ridles, but they are rather easy and won't hurt your brain. Most of the time you will jump, crawl, moan, climb, shoot, burn, slide, run or fall through a really beautiful scenery and impressive levels. The rich setting of the game, taking place at a remote island with caves and tombs to discover and treasures to claim, is the true strength of the game.   The story won't win an oscar and levels and gameplay are pretty linear but the pace is well timed. The game is the opposite to 'harcdore' games like Dark Souls, because Tomb Raider is very forgiving and thus, very rewarding. Auto saves are often, you never loose gathered secrets, experience or loot. The controls are very forgiving in regards of the timings, even difficult jump passages can be mastered at the first try. This leads to fast progression in the game and joyful exploration, i never was frustrated or bored. Even with that steady progression i needed more than 20 hours for the playthrough, so there is plenty of content.   This is not a game for younger children because there are brutal death scences, most of the times of yourself ('What? I'm dead? Is that a pole coming out of my head?!').  Replayability is rather low, you can collect and see everything in the first playthrough. I skipped the multiyplayer part, so no opinion on that. But if you can grab Tomb Raider at a nice price it's definitively worth buying.

I highly recommend this game for its single player campaign. The story is linear but it is very enjoyable. I was hooked after the first half hour. It was like being in a movie. The action sequences were well placed and provided an adrenaline rush. The combat system is fluid. The graphics are beautiful, even playing on a potato laptop. I could only imagine playing this on a dedicated rig. The controls are fluid with a controller. (I have not tried using the mouse and keyboard, though I'd imagine itd be easier to shoot with) I'd give this a solid 8.5/10 A steal on sale and a must for any Tomb Raider fan. It also is a great way for the new generation of gamers to experience Lara Croft. I cant wait for the next one!

Linear First Person Shooters are everywhere, and honestly I get tired of most as most feel like they're just following the formula once again. But the reboot of Tomb Raider stood out for me. The characterization of Lara, the setting, the pacing, action, puzzles and the story all came together seamlessly to create a very good game.   The puzzles no longer feel like enormous out of place contraptions made by insane dwarves, but instead like believable obstacles in the way of Lara's path, and as such there's no jarring switch from puzzle mode to regular travel mode. Sometimes puzzles are just part of the action and you're not even thinking of them as puzzles.  I would like to see the survival aspect expanded on if there's another TR game in the future. It seemed good to need to hunt for food and to make a fire at the beginning of the game, but after that it wasn't ever necessary which didn't make a lot of sense.  Overall the game was up there with Max Payne 3 as both games did a really good job of constantly driving the game forward by perfectly blending really good voice acting, story, cut scenes, level design and overall game mechanics.

I figured that Square Enix would do great, they made other great games, (Kingdom Hearts being the only other one I've played) and before anyone says anything, the other group that worked on this did a great job too. I like the idea of stealth, with a survival atmosphere, it makes ammunition for weapons so much more important and every shot counts. This was an absolutely astonishing game. Everything from the core gameplay to the side quests was amazing. The graphics were quite nice but nothing incredibly impressive, though I noticed some minor sound and texture clipping throughout the game. However, this was all quickly overlooked by the intense ambiance and vehement cutscenes. You genuinely felt like you were Laura and you would stop at nothing to rescue Sam, and you felt the intensity of every axe swing on a cliff that meant life or death. All of this wonderful work is tied in a nice bow that is the story line. While exploring the tombs is not necessary to understand the game, it brings so much into view about the sun queen and why everything is happening. Even if you didn't do any of these side quests, the game has such a rich plot you'll feel like you just exited the movie theatre after watching Braveheart for the first time when you finish this game. Overall, while I don't think the graphics will age very will, the gameplay and story will impress people for years to come. 9/10

An experienced Lara fighting for survival against the elements and a mysterious and deadly cult.  I found myself totally drawn into the story. The action, the set pieces, the grim story, the helplessness, the breathtaking visuals, the atmospheric soundtrack. It's everything I could have hoped for and more.

The story is good and the voice acting is decent too. Top notch game here IMO.
