It's better than I thought it would be. I actually played this a long time ago, and I recently picked up again to prep for the new one. I actually forgot how much fun it is. While the story isn't great and relies on too many old cliches and the voice acting is hit or miss, the gameplay is varied and exciting, kind of like an open world Uncharted.   Everything in the game world is connected creating a great sense that you are on an uncharted island in the middle of the ocean. The graphics are great (for when they came out) and help add to the atmosphere. Water effects and particles are all detailed and clear giving a real sense of weight to the environments.   Gunplay is decent, not fantastic, but good enough to cary the game. Really the best part is the exploration and the puzzles, which sometimes lie a little too far on the easy side, but many are excellently developed and interesting.  Overall, if you like Uncharted or want something with a good blend of action and exploration, give it a try if you already haven't, especially since the release of the sequel.

TL;DR: Great game. If you have played Assassin's Creed and/or Far Cry games and liked them, you'll like Tomb Raider. While I got it for free, I think it's definitely worth purchasing.  I got this game for free when I bought my graphics card, and I can't believe it took me this long to get around to playing it. Overall it's a great game. Tomb Raider feels like a good combination of Far Cry (3) and Assassin's Creed. The situation (trapped on an island controlled by a madman and his goons) and combat (weapons/mechanics/strategy) are very similar to Far Cry, while the climbing and the actual tomb raiding reminded me a lot of the Ezio-era Assassin's Creed games. If you played and liked those games, you'll like Tomb Raider.

If you are like me, you are considering to purchase this game because you played Rise of The Tomb Raider. You will be disappointed.  Tomb Raider(2013) has, unlike the RoTTR(Rise of The Tomb Raider), much more QTE cut scenes. All QTEs are boring and unrealistically fast so it gurantees to kill you 5 times on each QTEs. Every time you failed, you need to load the last checkpoint, forced to waste a time by watching boring and long cut scenes.  Puzzles are more platfrom action oriented than RoTTR so you will fail to solve puzzles even if you know exactly what you should do. Every time you failed, you need to intereact a few things in the narrow timing and do boring platform which also requires narrow timings to waste more time.  Combat is pathetic. Mostly it's too easy. My deathes were because of enemies appearing from thin air. Surely, I can't prepared for that in the first run!  There was one cut scene where you have to fly through the trees by parachute while avoiding trees. I died a few dozen times because of the hitbox of the tree is larger than it appears to be! This game is unforgiving in really annoying way.  Still, I recommend this game because it was cheap.

Ever since multiplayer online gaming became popular it's been difficult for me to go back to single player games. Most single player games seem monotonous; killing, looting, getting stuck and trying to figure out how to proceed and then doing it all over again. This 2013 Tomb Raider was nothing like that. The story was fantastic and had me gripped from the start. The gameplay was anything but monotonous...the puzzles made me think, but never became so overwhelming that I felt stuck at any point in the game. The environment was phenomenal...my thanks to the developers who took the time and effort to bring such an immersive atmosphere; the island was amazing, making me feel like a real explorer/adventurer. The controls to move Lara were smooth and intuitive, I learned very soon how to move pretty fast using all my tools. I also mastered the longbow and became quite adept with it. The graphics for Lara Croft were the best I have ever seen. (She is truly ever man and woman's dream). I am so glad that I decided to purchase and play this game. I completed it with 65%, meaning there are still tombs and missions waiting to be completed. So I should get back to it and not keep Lara waiting. Cheers!

I bought this game a few years ago, never expected to be so good, this game is action-packed, a leap-of-faith simulator, mountain climbing 101 guide, archery simulator 2013 etc. The main story of the game: Lara and her crew get stranded on an island in the Dragon Triangle after their ship was caught in the middle of a storm. Lara gets separated from the crew and she needs to find a way to get back to them. Soon after you get your bow, the first weapon out of 4, this is my favorite weapon just for the fact that you can be a silent assassin and has the most uses. You get fire arrows, rope arrows, penetration arrows, etc. After you manage to find a part of the crew, a man by the name of Mathias (  The bad guy which you need to kill  ) comes and gives you help, only to find yourself in a wolf trap and surrounded by a pack of wolves, luckily you still have your bow and get rid of them. After some time walking in the forest you find russian mercenaries which capture the crew and you. And so you set on to kill every single Russian and rescue your crew. However you can sidetrack and acquire documents, relics and gps-caches that will help you understand whats happening on the island and for that juicy 100% completion rate.   The controls are smooth, but I don't recommend playing this game with a controller, because you will have to do a lot of shooting and dodging, this is where the mouse shines and the music really kicks you into the atmosphere of the game.  Dont expect this game to be easy, sometimes the enemies are on steroids and aim-bot the ♥♥♥♥ out of you, I can't number the amount of times I died just because I was hiding behind a wall and the enemies still managed to hit my head. The game becomes more difficult the more you progress, to a point in which the enemies are armored as hell and you need to dodge, stun, shoot and repeat that until the enemy dies. Not only it's hard but sometimes you are swarned by enemies and can't even dodge because they are shooting you.   Overall, Tomb Raider is a game worth the money and time, the story is fascinating, the game is difficult and it's good for those who want a good challenge and for those who want 100%.

A successful reboot of a long-going series, the new Tomb Raider is pretty much summing up most of the recent gaming trends in one. a story of setting the character, 'a survivor is born', and of Uncharted (yeah, Uncharted is an PS Exclusive but TR has nice booty <3) adventuring in mythic lands with supernatural stuff closer to the end. A point where Tomb Raider loses to the mentioned Uncharted series are the secondary characters they aren't near as likeable as in the latter, and mostly worse written the only character you actually get to like is the one that's given sufficient screen time Conrad Roth. I actually felt sorry for the old warrior. The game's overall tone is gritty and dark, and that's what makes the plot quite inconsistent with the gameplay Lara whines and moans a lot (damn frequently the game actually sounds like a porno), cries over her dead comrades and after making her first kill in the cutscenes, but then the gameplay leads you to brutally murder dozens of random people. The gameplay itself is fun, killing (especially with the bow) feel satisfying, puzzles are short but well-made and actually require you to think and action setpieces are gripping. The campaign is structured as Batman: Arkham Asylum, so it isn't exactly open-world, but you may revisit the deserted locations to finish collecting stuff only you won't really want to do it after the main storyline. As for multiplayer, it's quite bland, a poor version of Uncharted's. To sum up, Tomb Raider is not exactly a gem, it doesn't bring anything new to the genre but it was one helluva ride!

Must have gaming experience! The 2013's remake of the character Lara Croft is amazing. The story is interesting and drives you to keep on playing. From the graphics to the soundeffects and the voice acting.. Everything is just perfect!   This game is regularly on sale, just buy it sometime if you haven't played it already!

It simply isn't a Tomb Raider game. It doesn't concentrate on things previous games in this series did. It doesn't have an atmosphere of being one on one in ancient tombs where you have to figure out puzzles. It packed with constant action and gunfights without compinsating it with enough platforming or puzzle solving.  We had this original 3D planformer (something that almost no one ever nailed before). Then came Uncharted, took a lot of inspiration from Tomb Raider and created itself as another game series. Then Tomb Rider forgot what it suppose to be good at and tried to simply copy its rival - the Uncharted while losing all of its originality that made it into amazing game to begin with. That irony could of not be any heavier. A franchise that drestroyed itself as an original title while trying to mimic its rival that actually took an inspiration from it.  If you want a TRUE Tomb Rider experience - Try out the Anniversary. If you want something slightly more action-packed - try the Uncharted series. Because this game is just one huge mistake. A step in a completely wrong direction for this rebooted franchise.

This review is for the 3D stereoscopic implementation (using nVidia 3D Vision) which i have nominated for the Steam awards. Posting this in 2016 - 3 years on from release - my criteria for nominating any 3D stereoscopic capable game is - near perfect implementation with almost no visual errors and jaw-dropping three dimensional immersion - which this game achieves. Another title that could tie with this is Max Payne 3 - another 3D vision compatible title.  As i have just upgraded to a 27 inch BenQ 3D vision monitor and playing on a GTX 1070 - the experience is sublime - and it saddens me the ship has sailed for this rather immersive technology (when done right) in favor of virtual reality - whose compromises i could not overlook and for me, could not quite not surpass 3D stereoscopic gaming for now.

This was my first Tomb Raider game and I gotta say the developers have won a new fan of the series, the tldr for this review is that you should 100% play the game because it's a blast.  The game is set on a mythical Japanese island called Yamatai, the island has been a graveyard for many ships and planes that have been brought down or wrecked by mysterious storms that plague the area. The design of the different areas of the island are fantastic, every area from forests, beaches, old military bunkers, makeshift towns set up by a cult made up of shipwreck survivors and many more all get a great balance between feeling fresh and individual, but also that they are part of one island. This high level of design is maintained through the largest areas like the Shantytown and Beach, to the smaller through parts like mountainous passes and a radio tower you have to scale. I find this very pleasing to play through, as the team could easily have not put the love and detail into areas of the game you spend small amounts of time in but to see the quality throughout is commendable. The design level remains excellent in the side quests and collectibles, the Tombs were possibly my highlight of the game with many of them making me go 'wow' as they revealed themselves in full, after having to crawl through a tiny crack or hole in a cave, seeing a big beautifully crafted underground Tomb is very cool. They each have a puzzle in them to solve, none are very hard and will at most make you think for 2-3 minutes but as the game is being sold as a big AAA game to a large audience, I don't blame the developers for keeping the puzzles fairly easy. The relics and documents you collect are all interesting and nicely made, they give you nice insights into the islands history and culture, as well as few journals from present day island inhabitants. The best compliment I can pay for these is that I wanted to collect them and did so on my first play through, there is nothing worse than tedious collectables you do t care about and these are as far from that as you can be.   The game begins with Lara and her crew of the ship Endurance trying to locate the aforementioned island of Yamatai to explore its mythical history and the ancient empire ruled by Sun Queen Himiko, the ship is wrecked in a storm and the crew split up, your initial goal is to meetup with your crew and regroup, but thanks to a cult of insane bloodthirsty sun worshippers led by the craziest, most bloodthirsty sun worshipper you could wish to meet quickly make your task far harder. Without revealing too much she ends up delving deeper into the island to reveal its mysteries, and discoveres much more than she imagined. The plot and story is a very effective as an introduction to Lara as the badass woman we know her as for both new players to the series and returning players, the focus is very strongly on Lara and as a result the side cast of island cultists and the Endurance crew are fairly boring and uninteresting but I'm not too fussed about this as the game is about Lara and her beginning and it does a very good job of it.   Gameplay revolves around 4 weapons that you can modify and improve through the game by finding weapon parts and salvage in boxes around the island, animals that you can hunt, and the bodies of enemies. The pistol and assault rifle are pretty standard 3rd person shooter fare and I used both a reasonable amount, the shotgun I found fairly useless apart from blowing up wooden doors that can only be destroyed with said gun, however the star weapon is easily the bow, you start off with a makeshift bow and by the end you have an absolutely amazing competition weapon, with armour piercing, napalm and grenade arrow upgrades. The only down side to the bow is takes a little time to pull back the arrow and release so in an intense firefight you'll probably fall back to the assault rifle where you can quickly hop out of cover and send off a few bullets. You can also upgrade perks in Survivor, Hunter and Brawler categories, early perks are standard, slightly boring stuff like reduced damage taken, extra ammo space etc but by the end there are some decent T3 perks like Cartographer which shows all Tomb and treasure map locations, and instant kill dodges. I do have a bone to pick here though, 4 of the hunter perks unlock execution style finishers for each weapon that earns you bonus XP. In my opinion this does not in any way fit in with Lara's personality, she is in not a killer or muderer for the sake of it and these perks are so against her as a person I can't help but feel they do not fit in. I would also have liked to have seen a greater emphasis on stealth in the game rather than just shooting your way through the whole thing. Other than these I had a lot of fun with the game, flying along zip lines, doing all the mini challenges scattered around the map and exploring the island.  Scores: Design, 10/10. Plot, 9/10, gameplay, 7/10, for an overall score of 26/30.  I had a lot of fun with the game, it's one of the best designed and most interesting I've played in a while and I cannot wait to get my teeth into what I'm sure will be the next blockbuster series (Rise of the tomb raider is downloading as I type), I hope to see a bit more versatility in the gameplay though, I'd hate for it to become a stale shoot em up.

Why write a review for a three+ year old game? I don't know, maybe I'm disgruntled, or disappointed, dismayed maybe?  Tomb Raider was due for a reboot, and it hit during a gaming trend that put it in league with series like Uncharted, Far Cry, and Just Cause. A main character in an 'isolated' region driven to advance, explore, and discover while picking up an array of new gear during the progression of a mostly linear path set inside some otherwise semi-open maps. These games end up being part RPG, part Tell-Tale, and part semi-splash-illusion of sandbox concept. What's very clear in this particular Tomb Raider is that it's intended to bring new people in and give them a stepping stone to Lara Croft's adventures without creating a complex or convoluted experience to deter them.  Experienced FPS/RPG gamers are going to find this game (as like many in its genre/style) a cake walk, and that is one area that was a big sore-spot for me.   Lara is supposed to be somewhat experienced/and/or/developing in her tomb raiding skills for this go-round, yet an expeerienced FPS player can go through and perform flawless headshots and walk her through unscathed and it really breaks the emersion of the story. That's not the game's fault (admittedly), but for her to say 'I'm can't do this, I don't have the skills' and then walk out five minutes later of a crazy scenario going 'Wow, I barely made it,' when the player exerted little effort? I know, first-world gaming problems. Plus, there is a game setting of 'Hard' that, to my regret, does not come with achievement for having completed the game at. The achievement is at least 25% of the reason I'll select the difficult option alongside what (I hope) will be improved tactical/AI response of the in-game enemies. Sadly, with this game, 'Hard' just gives the bad guys more HP, and when any enemy takes 15-20 bullets out of an SMG to hit the dirt? That's just bad form. I would say 'Oh, just headshots all around, ja?' But no, more of the end-game targets start wearing helmets, masks, or shields that require a double or triple tap (or other acrobatics) to eliminate them.  Speaking of eliminating bad guys, there sure are an awful lot of them in this game. Like, a lot. A lot a lot. A decent bulk of my upgrading salvage came from stuff I stripped off guys I killed. I really think there could have been better planning in placement, function, and abilities to make less enemies a more realistic and imposing threat without feeling the need to flood the game with bodies.  Speaking of bodies. There is a lot of gore, dismemberment, and general 'disgusting' in this game. Rivers of blood, mountains of body parts? This is supposed to be an un-traversed-to, generally avoided, and rarely incursioned island. How have there possibly been that many people killed so recently?! There was a clear line of definition between 'old and dusty' dead bodies and 'fresh from the farm' bodies. And the ratio of dusty to fresh was easily 1 to 200. And I wish that was just an exagerrated joke, but I don't think it counts out that way.  There are other reasons about the ending, too, that I am very 'eh' about, but wont spoil. I'd really like a neutral review option for games. I'm not saying I don't recommend this game, but I'm also not saying I'm not not recommending it either. You follow me?  It's not a bad game, but definitely don't play it back-to-back with Far Cry 3, it'll discomfort your sense of game-reality.
